Please see our newest perspectives about the <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/covid-19-implications-for-business">economic and business impact of coronavirus</a> and how to prepare for a postpandemic world. </h4>
<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #36, December 16, 2020</h2>
<h4>Vaccines are here. What can stakeholders do to ensure quick and effective distribution and boost public confidence in vaccination efforts?</h4>
<p><strong>The first COVID-19 vaccines</strong> have been authorized for use and dissemination has begun in several countries, marking a major turning point in the pandemic and bringing fresh optimism for a next normal in the new year. These vaccines were developed four times faster than any other in history, but they will also require a rollout four times greater, amounting to the <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/the-covid-19-vaccines-are-here-what-comes-next">largest simultaneous global public-health initiative ever undertaken</a>. Governments and healthcare professionals will need to collaborate on an incredible scale to allot and deliver vaccine doses and to address challenges from storage and transport to administration and data tracking. Multiple vaccines and changing supply volumes will also necessitate an evolving delivery model.</p>
<p>Stakeholders face another hurdle to widespread vaccine adoption: <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-vaccine-are-consumers-ready">some consumers remain skeptical of COVID-19 immunization</a>. To reach herd immunity, our analysis suggests adoption ranges would need to be greater than those of vaccines for the flu and other diseases. The vast majority of US consumers surveyed believe the vaccine is important to facilitate a return to life as it was, but nearly half are cautious adopters, preferring to <a href="https://covid-tracker.mckinsey.com/vaccine-acceptance">defer vaccination</a> for up to three months to a year, after more data is available. To boost acceptance, healthcare leaders will need to dynamically engage consumers through information campaigns using trusted, influential sources.</p>
<p>New research from the McKinsey Global Institute points to another area of hope in the face of the current crisis: a <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-has-revived-the-social-contract-in-advanced-economies-for-now-what-will-stick-once-the-crisis-abates">renewed social contract</a>. Governments across 22 countries have upped their fiscal spending as a percentage of GDP by around 20 percent compared with last year, and the private sector has made efforts to offer employee protections. Combined, these interventions have provided an economic buffer and some initiatives have the potential to translate into long-term solutions to protect individuals from the immediate effects of future crises.</p>
<p>The COVID-19 pandemic is unleashing a new era of change for businesses as well. Companies have seen the effects of high-consequence, low-likelihood risks firsthand. While corporate decision makers cannot plan for every potential risk, we examined some ways they can <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/the-disaster-you-could-have-stopped-preparing-for-extraordinary-risks">prepare for extraordinary risks</a>, determine which protections are worth the investment, and position themselves for better resiliency. As CEOs continue to develop their <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/as-you-return-from-the-summer-break-can-you-lead-toward-a-covid-exit">COVID-Exit strategies</a>, we analyzed how two companies have found a successful <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/this-way-out-how-leading-companies-chart-a-full-potential-covid-exit">COVID-Exit path</a> with transformations that balance portfolio moves and performance improvements.</p>
<p>Our research shows that companies are already focusing on two areas in particular. A new global survey of more than 800 executives reveals that companies are prioritizing <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/why-business-building-is-the-new-priority-for-growth">business building</a> for organic growth, launching new businesses at an accelerated rate and, in turn, growing faster. The strongest companies are also reinventing themselves through <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/how-covid-19-is-redefining-the-next-normal-operating-model">next-normal operating models</a>, capitalizing on this malleable moment and the resulting spread of agile processes, nimbler ways of working, and increased speed and productivity.</p>
<p>This week, we took a close look at the banking sector, starting with our 2020 update to <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/global-banking-annual-review-archive">McKinseys Global Banking Annual Review</a>. We also highlighted developments in two countries: how banks can provide a credit lifeline to <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/a-credit-lifeline-how-banks-can-serve-smes-in-south-africa-better">small and medium-size enterprises in South Africa</a> and steps <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/nigerias-banking-sector-thriving-in-the-face-of-crisis">Nigerias banking sector</a> can take to thrive amid the crisis.</p>
<p>Our industry experts explored the <a href="/featured-insights/the-next-normal/fashion">future of fashion</a>, how the COVID-19 pandemic has <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/from-no-mobility-to-future-mobility-where-covid-19-has-accelerated-change">disrupted mobility</a> and affected demand for <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-and-in-vitro-diagnostics-new-market-forces-at-play">in vitro diagnostics</a>, and how <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/collaboration-in-crisis-reflecting-on-australias-covid-19-response">Australias COVID-19 response</a> can inform decision makers around the world. Global economist <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/growth-and-prosperity-a-conversation-with-economist-dambisa-moyo">Dambisa Moyo</a> also provided insights on models for growth, stakeholder capitalism, and how to drive enduring change amid uncertainty.</p>
<p>Finally, we launched our new <em>Author Talks</em> series, featuring interviews with noted management thinker and professor <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-roger-martin-on-the-high-price-of-efficiency">Roger Martin</a> on the high price of efficiency and McKinsey Global Institute editorial director <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-on-books/author-talks-mckinsey-global-institutes-peter-gumbel-on-searching-for-identity">Peter Gumbel</a> on searching for identity.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #35, December 9, 2020</h2>
<h4>After a tumultuous year for racial justice, companies are pledging change. McKinsey announces one of our biggest commitments: the Institute for Black Economic Mobility.</h4>
<p><strong>The year 2020 has been one of losses</strong>around the world, and in the United States in particular. More than 46,000 Black Americans have died from COVID-19twice as many, proportionally, as white Americans. This year also saw the murders of George Floyd, Breonna Taylor, and many other Black Americans. The events of this year are emblematic of long-standing inequities and are rooted in a long history of systemic discrimination. The typical Black American family has eight times less wealth than a white American family. The racial wealth gap has profound consequences, for families and the US economy, which misses out on between $1 trillion and $1.5 trillion in GDP output each year.</p>
<p>To make good on these profound inequities, or at least make a start, nearly one-third of Fortune 1000 companies made a public statement on racial equity in recent months, and followed it up with an internal or external commitment. Of those, about 57 percent publicly announced the amount they were committing to racial equity initiatives, pledging a total of $66 billion.</p>
<p>
</p>
<p>This week, we published new research on <a href="/bem/our-insights/its-time-for-a-new-approach-to-racial-equity">five attributes of successful coalitions</a>ideas that can help make sure that the $66 billion pledged achieves maximum impact. Were also proud to announce the <a href="/bem/overview">McKinsey Institute for Black Economic Mobility</a>, which will research the issues, convene stakeholders, and work to convert research findings into real-world impact. This is a critical moment. Corporate America is more focused on the issue of racial justice than it ever has been. It is imperative to ensure that the unprecedented commitment of resources and focus toward racial equity is channeled effectively, proves impactful, delivers a high return on investment for society, and brings about real progress for individuals and communities.</p>
<p>Women and children have also suffered immensely from the global pandemic. The <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/five-fifty-the-pandemics-gender-effect">latest edition</a> of the <em>McKinsey Quarterly Five Fifty</em> distills our gender research to date in an easy-to-read five-minute summary, and provides links for those who want to learn more. One reason women are more affected: two million women (many of them mothers of young children) are thinking about leaving the workforce, or have already left. And our new research on <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-learning-loss-disparities-grow-and-students-need-help">learning loss</a> during the COVID-19 pandemic finds that students have lost a lot of ground. We offer insights to help educators curb losses and accelerate learning.</p>
<p>In two new podcasts, McKinsey experts spoke with our editors about <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/grief-loss-burnout-talking-about-complex-feelings-at-work">grief, loss, and burnout</a> at workand about Americas <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-and-behavioral-health-consequences-for-companies-and-employees">behavioral health crisis</a>. We also published <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/mental-health-in-the-workplace-the-coming-revolution">insights</a> from two leading scholars about the coming revolution in mental health in the workplace.</p>
<p>Also this week, our industry researchers focused on Europe, looking at three topics: <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/how-the-european-union-could-achieve-net-zero-emissions-at-net-zero-cost">decarbonization</a> in various EU industries; new consumer behaviors in <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/how-european-shoppers-will-buy-groceries-in-the-next-normal">grocery shopping</a>; and the impact of the second lockdown on <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-second-covid-19-lockdown-in-europe-implications-for-automotive-retail">automotive retail</a>. <h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #34, December 2, 2020</h2>
<h4>Pandemic fatigue is bad and getting worse. Heres practical advice for leaders to help people reconnect with their jobs, their colleagues, and their purpose.</h4>
<p><strong>Im not sure</strong> how much longer I can keep going like this. Im completely burned out. Pandemic fatigue is here, and while almost everybody is feeling it, and more people are talking about it, no one knows exactly what to do about it. Our new <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/overcoming-pandemic-fatigue-how-to-reenergize-organizations-for-the-long-run">research</a> explains principles and sets out practical steps to get through a potentially prolonged period of disillusionment, grief, and exhaustion. Heres a sampling of the tips on offer:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Leaders need to <em>set and enforce work boundaries</em>; violating these is one of the biggest energy drains.</li>
    <li>They can help people <em>see this time as a quest toward something new</em>, not as a restitution of bygone days, and not as chaos to be muddled through.</li>
    <li>Managers can encourage employees to take a <em>zero-based approach</em> to meetings, to help them choose which ones to attend.</li>
    <li>And they can <em>prioritize the work</em> people do. Now is the time for organizations to finally tackle busyness and focus on the work that matters most. One global organization put a halt to new initiatives for a period of two months to allow for recovery, while another now examines which initiatives to sunset and how to intentionally limit the amount of work in progress.</li>
</ul>
<p>In a companion piece, McKinsey experts spoke with Admiral John Richardson, former US chief of naval operations, about how to lead during long-term crises marked by deep uncertainty. Many of the naval analogies he <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reenergizing-an-exhausted-organization-a-conversation-with-admiral-john-richardson">shared</a> translate well to civilian organizations. Captains rely on the chief of the boat to take the pulse of the crew and represent their needs. Thats one way the captain avoids being the ships single point of safety. If the captain is indispensable, he or she is also overstretched and will inevitably make a mistake. And recovery is critical to mission effectiveness. Organizations need structures that protect time off and teams that make it possible for even their busiest members to take extended time off.</p>
<p>Case counts are rising rapidly in many countries, straining hospital systems. Our new research assesses <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/challenges-emerge-for-the-us-healthcare-system-as-covid-19-cases-rise">how much slack is left</a> in the system. The answer is not encouraging. In many US localities, for example, COVID-19 beds will be full by December 7, based on current trends. We also offer ideas for hospital systems on how to use their resources to the utmost.</p>
<p>Few industries have been as deeply affected by the pandemic as fashion and retail. This week we published <em><a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/state-of-fashion-archive">The State of Fashion 2021</a></em>, our annual report on the industry, issued jointly with the Business of Fashion. Unsurprisingly, we estimate that revenues in 2020 will likely fall by 27 to 30 percent from the year before. Many global fashion companies may be at risk, and the pain extends to workers in low-cost sourcing and manufacturing hubs. But our research also finds that growth should resume in 2021.</p>
<p>This week, our industry researchers also looked at the factors spurring <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/healthtech-in-the-fast-lane-what-is-fueling-investor-excitement">healthtech investment</a>, considered the future of <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-european-payments-strategic-choices-for-banks">European payments</a>, reviewed the potential for <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/private-autonomous-vehicles-the-other-side-of-the-robo-taxi-story">privately owned autonomous vehicles</a>, and detailed ten priorities for <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/rethinking-resilience-ten-priorities-for-governments">governmental resilience</a>.</p>
<p>Finally, our climate experts trained their sights on <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/will-india-get-too-hot-to-work">India</a>, a country that faces a rapidly degrading physical environment. India could become one of the first places in the world to experience heat waves that, in extremis, exceed the survivability limit for healthy people. More generally, heat and humidity will reduce labor productivity and hurt growth in an economy that relies substantially on outdoor work.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #33, November 25, 2020</h2>
<h4>What to make of the promising news on COVID-19 vaccines and  new CEO insights on leading through the pandemic: heres this weeks update.</h4>
<p><strong>The world has cheered recent announcements </strong>about COVID-19-vaccine candidates. Two are showing higher efficacy rates than many dared hope for. Higher efficacy provides greater benefit to any vaccinated individual and may help encourage uptake among some segments of the population. It also reduces the fraction of the population required to reach herd immunity.</p>
<p>While thats highly positive news, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end">McKinsey research</a> also finds that the new vaccines are likely to accelerate only slightly the timetable to the end of the pandemic. In the United States, normalcy is not likely until the second quarter of 2021, and herd immunity is not likely until the third quarter. In other words, the pandemic will not be vanquished soon, and businesses will continue to be challenged. See our latest <a href="/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf">briefing materials</a>129 pages to guide leaders through the difficulties of the next few months.</p>
<p>Leaders can also take inspiration and new ideas from their peers. This week, McKinsey experts spoke with five top executives to learn more about how they are leading through the pandemic. Amrita Ahuja, CFO of Square, spoke about <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-payments-is-frictionless-now-more-than-ever">the future of payments</a>, including the potential for a cashless society and frictionless exchanges made possible by machine learning and even cryptocurrency. Jaime Augusto Zobel de Ayala, CEO of Ayala Corporation, talked about how the Philippines oldest conglomerate has taken on societys pain points in housing, electricity, medicine, and water and his <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/addressing-societys-pain-points-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-ayala-corporation">optimistic outlook for Asia</a>. His main concern? The potential for geopolitics to create several sets of technological standards, producing inefficiencies and raising costs.</p>
<p>Telemedicine is one of the extraordinary growth stories of the pandemic. Annie Lamont, managing partner of Oak HC/FT, shared her insights on what it and other trends mean for <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-shift-to-virtual-and-home-care-an-interview-with-annie-lamont">healthcare investing</a>. Lisa Weiland, CEO of the Massachusetts Port Authority, spoke with us about what it means to run a major transportation hub when passenger volumes are down by two-thirds. Airports are preparing for <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/prepare-for-the-marathon-and-be-ready-for-the-course-to-change-an-interview-with-the-boston-logan-airport-ceo">contactless journeys</a> and other means to improve the customer experience. And Tim Welsh, vice chairman of U.S. Bank, explained how <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/an-environment-where-everybody-can-thrive-a-conversation-with-us-banks-tim-welsh">new skills</a> are helping the nations fifth-largest bank better connect with its customers.</p>
<p>This years McKinsey Global Survey on <a href="/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/global-survey-the-state-of-ai-in-2020">Artificial Intelligence</a> finds no increase in AI adoption. But the technology is far from stalled: one-fifth of companies are deriving at least 5 percent of their earnings from AI, and they plan to further their investments in this still-promising technology. And in the latest installment of McKinseys series with CNBC, senior partner Mary Meaney speaks with IBM CEO Arvind Krishna and Unilever chief HR officer Leena Nair to discuss <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-way-businesses-operate">how companies can organize for the next normal</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #32, November 18, 2020</h2>
<h4>In the pandemic, capitalisms adherents are reconsidering its recent history and its future direction. Two new reports can illuminate the path.</h4>
<p><strong>This week,</strong> McKinsey experts took a step back to consider the effects of the COVID-19 crisis on the economic system in which much of the world operates: capitalism. Two new reports offer complementary views. In <a href="/featured-insights/long-term-capitalism/rethinking-the-future-of-american-capitalism">Rethinking the future of American capitalism</a>, James Manyika, Gary Pinkus, and Monique Tuin trace the extraordinary achievements of the American system and the work still to come, including the need to rectify unequal and increasingly disparate outcomes for people and places, increasing superstar effects, and declining investment in public goods.</p>
<p><a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-case-for-stakeholder-capitalism">The case for stakeholder capitalism</a> considers the role of business in societya role that companies should not resist, lest they find themselves on the wrong side of history  and also at a competitive disadvantage. Vivian Hunt, Bruce Simpson, and Yuito Yamada examine the rising expectations for business, detail five principles for companies to follow, and offer many practical insights as they take action. One tactic is simply to publish your targets: a Danish power company put forth a ten-year plan to switch from coal to renewables; they did it in nine years, while simultaneously increasing profits by 43 percent.</p>
<p>Employees may be the stakeholders that need the most attention. According to our latest <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diverse-employees-are-struggling-the-most-during-covid-19-heres-how-companies-can-respond">research</a>, almost a year into the crisis, employeesespecially women, LGBTQ+ employees, people of color, and working parentsare crying out for more support. Nearly all employers are aware of the challenges and have established polices to help, but they are finding it hard to execute their diversity, equity, and  inclusion (DEI) strategies. Asking and answering a set of tough questions can help companies close the gap.</p>
<p>Our experts also considered the future of corporate training, an expensive and often ineffective activitywhen it did succeed, it was through in-person, hands-on learning. The COVID-19 pandemic brought that to a halt, forcing companies to innovate. In our latest research, we <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/closing-the-capability-gap-in-the-time-of-covid-19">chronicle</a> the advances companies have made in the pandemic and the ways in which the new capabilities they have built have secured their competitive position.</p>
<p>Also this week, our industry researchers looked at datas critical role in two transport industries, <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/data-will-decide-success-in-the-next-normal-of-bulk-and-tanker-shipping">bulk and tanker shipping</a> and <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/airline-data-what-next-beyond-crisis-response">airlines</a>; considered the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic on <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/how-retail-can-adapt-supply-chains-to-win-in-the-next-normal">supply chains in retail</a>; and outlined our latest findings on <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-conflicted-continent-ten-charts-show-how-covid-19-is-affecting-consumers-in-europe">consumer behavior</a>, this time in Europe.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #31, November 11, 2020</h2>
<h4>A vaccine breakthrough and how companies are thinking about  purpose: heres the latest from McKinseys research.</h4>
<p><strong>This week</strong> saw some surprising news about a large COVID-19-vaccine trial: a leading candidate has an efficacy rate of about 90 percent. Theres a lot of green between this particular ball and the pocket, but the news was most welcome. COVID-19 vaccines have been a focus of our research, as seen in our July 2020 <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world">overview</a>, which includes a full discussion of the key issues of manufacturing and distribution, and subsequent articles on <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end">the end of the pandemic</a>, an <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/an-optimistic-scenario-for-the-us-response-to-covid-19">optimistic scenario</a> for the pandemic response in the United States, and the <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/why-tech-transfer-may-be-critical-to-beating-covid-19">technology transfer</a> that may be critical to beating the COVID-19 crisis.</p>
<p>With the end in sight, or at least in fuzzy focus, companies are thinking ahead. A critical challenge for companies in the postcrisis era will be articulating clear, meaningful, and authentic purposes. Some companies seem to have <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/more-than-a-mission-statement-how-the-5ps-embed-purpose-to-deliver-value">the answer</a>: they know their reasons for being, communicate them easily to customers, and enjoy the results. Our new framework can help others think through these knotty issues.</p>
<p>Governments have not lost sight of their purpose, but fulfilling it has become much more difficult. The gap between incoming and outgoing funds may reach <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/closing-the-30-trillion-gap-acting-now-to-manage-fiscal-deficits-during-and-beyond-the-covid-19-crisis">$30 trillion</a> soon. Our latest research shows a particularly effective bridge for governments to consider: <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-public-real-estate-to-fuel-a-postpandemic-recovery">real estate</a>. The public controls a vast amount of acreage, office space, and other assets, and governments can extract much more revenue from them without breaching the public trust. On a related note, as part of their purpose, many businesses will embrace sustainability; <a href="/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-scaling-voluntary-carbon-markets-to-meet-the-climate-challenge">voluntary carbon markets</a> can help them reach their goals.</p>
<p>Cost management may be the yin to purposes yang, but is no less essential. In our new survey of some 300 C-level executives, we look at the ways that the <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reimagine-preparing-for-sga-in-the-next-normal">corporate center</a> is evolving. Our latest observations find that many organizations are accelerating their cost-reduction targets, modifying their operating models on the fly, and redefining their functional priorities.</p>
<p>Our new regional research considers two large economies in Asia. China, the worlds growth engine for the past 25 years, has <a href="/featured-insights/china/china-still-the-worlds-growth-engine-after-covid-19">come back</a>in ways that may surprise you. Consumer behavior has changed, pockets of growth are shifting, and leadership and management practices are in flux; businesses that manufacture and sell in China must be alive to the changes. And in Australia, businesses would be wise to understand todays <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/getting-acquainted-with-a-more-mindful-australian-consumer">more mindful consumers</a>.</p>
<p>Finally, <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast">the <em>McKinsey Podcast</em></a> zeroed in this week on retail, where the talk was all about rapid revenue recovery. Say what? Its true: winners are recognizing the shifts in consumer behavior, adjusting their offerings, and rebuilding their businesses. Successful companies have <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/rapid-revenue-recovery-after-the-crisis-strategies-for-success">five traits</a> in common.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #30, November 4, 2020</h2>
<h4>Scenario planning and a new decision tool are helping executives cut through the murk of the pandemics many confusions.</h4>
<p><strong>Executives have noticed the striking rise in COVID-19 cases</strong> in many parts of the world, yet they remain positiveif a trifle more wary. In the October edition of our <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment">monthly survey</a> of more than 2,000 leaders around the world, fewer executives than in September say that better economic conditions are on the way. But the balance is still tilted toward a positive outlook, especially where profits and customer demand are concerned.</p>
<p>We also asked respondents to vote on which of McKinseys nine pandemic scenarios is most likely. As of October, they are solidly in favor of scenario A1 (a muted recovery) but also see B2 (a prolonged and insufficient recovery) as a scenario to consider. Unsure about the terminology? In a new <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/nine-scenarios-for-the-covid-19-economy">interactive</a>, we explain our scenarios, what executives are thinking, and how that thinking has changed over time.</p>
<p>For decades, McKinsey has <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-use-and-abuse-of-scenarios">advocated</a> for the advantages of scenario planning while also recognizing the ways the approach can <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/overcoming-obstacles-to-effective-scenario-planning">fall short</a>. The pandemic has illustrated both sides of the equation. Enter a new approach: parametric analysis, in the form of an <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/overcoming-obstacles-to-effective-scenario-planning">uncertainty cube</a>. Right now, the businesses facing the greatest uncertainty are limiting themselves to three or four macrolevel scenarios that provide general direction but not much detailed guidance. The uncertainty cube uses several macroeconomic and financing parameters to generate highly specific advice by which to steer such a business.</p>
<p>Operating models, too, have come under pressure at companies facing great uncertainty. Whats needed are <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/when-nothing-is-normal-managing-in-extreme-uncertainty">new structures</a> designed to cope with the unprecedented conditions of 2020 and beyond. One way forward may be to embark, at last, on a true transformation. A new <a href="/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/the-path-to-true-transformation">video</a> explains the logic.</p>
<p>This week, we were delighted to sit down with two executives cutting remarkable paths through the pandemic. Aneel Bhusri, co-CEO of Workday, <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/software-and-the-next-normal-a-talk-with-workdays-cofounder-and-co-ceo">reveals</a> the secrets of life in the pandemic for the finance- and HR-software powerhouse. And Sir Mark Lowcock, under-secretary-general for humanitarian affairs at the United Nations, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/tackling-the-impact-of-covid-19-a-talk-with-the-uns-sir-mark-lowcock">explains</a> the panoply of effects of the crisis on the United Nations and its missions.</p>
<p>Also this week, McKinsey experts assessed the potential for <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/a-new-growth-formula-for-manufacturing-in-india">Indias manufacturing sector</a> to deliver much-needed growth and jobs; reviewed the impact of the pandemic on the <a href="/industries/chemicals/our-insights/the-impact-of-covid-19-on-the-global-petrochemical-industry">global petrochemical industry</a>; and considered the moves that <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/beyond-covid-19-charting-the-road-to-recovery-for-south-african-insurers">South Africas insurers</a> can make to thrive in the long term.</p>
<p>Finally, in the pandemic, many of us are spending more time at home with our families. Children are naturally curious about what parents doand it isnt always easy to explain. At McKinsey, we took a crack at it and developed a new <a href="/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/hungry-fish-baffled-farmers-and-what-happened-next">explainer</a> for the younger crowd. <h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #29, October 28, 2020</h2>
<h4>New views on the postpandemic futures of six sectors.</h4>
<p><strong>The old joke</strong> has it that nostalgia isnt what it used to be. As the unrelenting COVID-19 pandemic rolls on, the future isnt what it used to be, either. What used to be a simple idea now comes freighted with caveats, assumptions, and speculations. In the spirit of illumination, McKinsey researchers this week took a look at how things might develop in six sectors beyond the next few weeks.</p>
<p>The <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/reimagining-the-auto-industrys-future-its-now-or-never">auto industry</a> is one of the worlds largest and has been devastated by the pandemic: sales may drop by 20 to 30 percent in 2020, and we estimate that profits will fall by $100 billion. But automakers can respond. One example: software-subscription services, which enable people to pay for programs that unlock features from heated seating to full self-driving capabilities, allow dealerships to develop a better relationship with consumers while offering drivers additional flexibility and customization.</p>
<p>The US restaurant industry has given many iconic brands to the rest of the world. But today, the sector is in trouble. In our latest <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/whats-ahead-for-us-restaurants">podcast</a>, we review the industrys predicament, which we explored <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/how-restaurants-can-thrive-in-the-next-normal">earlier</a> in some <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/eating-out-side-restaurant-dining-in-the-next-normal">depth</a>, and assess the innovative solutions that companies are devising. Takeout and delivery are here to stay, and restaurants are working to make those experiences better. Menus also need a rethink. People dont order sides, appetizers, and desserts as frequently when theyre ordering for deliverybut as leaders know, those items are often the difference between profit and loss.</p>
<p>For banks, the pandemic has changed everything. Risk-management teams are running hard to catch up with cascades of credit risk, among other challenges. Down the line, we expect that <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/a-fast-track-risk-management-transformation-to-counter-the-covid-19-crisis">automated underwriting</a> will take hold for retail and small-business customers and will both reduce losses and save costs.</p>
<p>Asian insurers are looking at a more consolidated future. Our new <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/insurance-strategy-in-asia-using-programmatic-m-and-a-during-the-pandemic">report</a> argues that insurtechs new, pandemic-oriented products and digital capabilitiesnot least the ability to reach  millions of customers within a few monthsmean that a programmatic approach to M&A is  the surest strategy to overcome the industrys structural weaknesses.</p>
<p>We recently hosted a panel <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/building-a-healthcare-ecosystem-in-india-a-conversation-with-shobana-kamineni">discussion</a> with Shobana Kamineni, executive vice chairperson of Indias Apollo Hospitals, to discuss the evolving nature of healthcare at scale. Apollo Hospitals comprises more than 7,000 physicians and 30,000 other healthcare professionals, and its app is downloaded about 30,000 times a day. Among the findings: publicprivate partnerships are working well and have the potential to influence the future of healthcare.</p>
<p>Finally, we consider five fundamental questions for <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/reimagining-higher-education-in-the-united-states">US higher education</a>, as colleges fashion their pandemic response. Also this week: a new <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-european-small-and-medium-size-enterprises-how-they-are-weathering-the-storm">survey</a> of Europes small and medium-size businesses lays out the extent of the economic damage and owners muted outlook.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #28, October 21, 2020</h2>
<h4>Geopolitics is back. Business leaders need to think through the implications.</h4>
<p><strong>In the 1990s,</strong> adherents of Francis Fukuyama came to believe in the end of history. The COVID-19 pandemic and a host of other factorssuch as climate change, cyberattacks, and terrorismhave helped history stage a resounding comeback. Now, according to Richard Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, the trick for businesses is to adjust and hope that history is just back for a visit and not for revenge. In a <a href="/featured-insights/leadership/james-manyika-speaks-with-richard-haass-about-businesses-as-global-entities">discussion</a> with McKinsey senior partner and cochair of the McKinsey Global Institute (MGI) James Manyika, Haass speaks about the return of geopolitics to the top of the CEO agenda. Supply chains are another critical focus of the renewed attention, as covered in MGIs new <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains">report</a> and partner Susan Lunds <a href="https://www.economist.com/special-report/2020/10/08/changing-places">comments</a> in the <em>Economist</em>.</p>
<p>McKinsey research has documented the disproportionate effects of the crisis on ethnic minorities, both in the <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-impacted-black-white-financial-inequality">United States</a> and elsewhere. Our latest <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/problems-amid-progress-improving-lives-and-livelihoods-for-ethnic-minorities-in-the-united-kingdom">report</a> on the topic looks at the United Kingdom. Key findings: over the past two decades, every ethnic minority group has made progress, in both absolute terms and relative to the white majority, on a range of economic indicators. But the COVID-19 crisis threatens that progress; not only do all ethnic-minority groups have higher age-adjusted COVID-19-related death rates than white people do, but Bangladeshis and Pakistanis, in particular, are concentrated in occupations that have been hard hit by furloughs and layoffs.</p>
<p>This week, our marketing experts zeroed in on <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/these-eight-charts-show-how-covid-19-has-changed-b2b-sales-forever">B2B businesses and how they sell</a>. The classic approach is person to person; think of pharmas armies of detailers. However, the COVID-19 pandemic has moved almost all sales online, often to self-service digital platforms. Everyone seems to be happier with the new arrangements. Some 70 percent of buyers say they prefer digital interactions; sellers like the greater effectiveness. Videoconferences and live chats are helping companies seal the deal; traditional phone calls are now a last resort.</p>
<p>Also this week, our industry researchers examined the latest <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/what-can-other-countries-learn-from-chinas-travel-recovery-path">travel data from China</a> to understand what it might mean for tourism and business travel elsewhere. They also considered the new challenges for <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/reimagining-consumer-goods-innovation-for-the-next-normal">innovation in consumer companies</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #27, October 14, 2020</h2>
<h4>The stock market has many puzzled. Heres our explanation.</h4>
<p><strong>In the middle of the deepest recession in memory,</strong> stock markets are reaching new highs. Why the disconnect? To understand the conundrum, McKinsey experts point to <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/wall-street-versus-main-street-why-the-disconnect">three factors</a>. First, many investors still take a long-term perspective; they are looking ahead to the end of the pandemic. Another factor: five big-tech companies now make up 21 percent of the S&P 500, one of the worlds most-watched markets. And smaller, unlisted companies have absorbed a lot of the economic damage, such as the dramatic rise in unemployment. The overall stock market can do relatively well even when employment and GDP are severely depressed.</p>
<p>Investors may also be focused on the vast differences in resilience at companies. We interviewed leaders at several UK companies that have done better than others during the crisis. What distinguishes them, in a word, is <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/agile-resilience-in-the-uk-lessons-from-covid-19-for-the-next-normal">agility</a>. From a common purpose to rapid decision making to empowered local teams, these companies found ways to respond quickly to COVID-19. A key finding: war-gaming for a no-deal Brexit built a solid foundation for supply-chain resilience.</p>
<p>A new <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/covid-19-and-supply-chain-recovery-planning-for-the-future">podcast</a> this week examined those same supply-chain issues, in the context of McKinsey Global Institutes August 2020 <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains">report</a> on risk and resilience. Experts Ed Barriball and Susan Lund explain the research finding that, on average, companies can expect a disruption to their production lines of one to two monthsa very long timeevery three-and-a-half to four years.</p>
<p>Another podcast lays out the path forward for the <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/the-path-forward-for-the-us-retail-industry">US retail industry</a>; our experts explain what it means for the industry when so many categories are tilting toward online shopping. Short answers, from senior partner Becca Coggins: were in the foothills of what omnichannel-driven convenience will look like and some big innovations will scale, now that consumer expectations have been reset. In another report, we examined the same forces and their effect on <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/how-middle-east-and-africa-retailers-can-accelerate-e-commerce-imperatives-for-now-and-the-next-normal">Middle East and Africa retailers</a>.</p>
<p>Also this week: McKinsey researchers examined the potential for <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/medtech-innovation-in-the-time-of-covid-19-resilience-and-growth-during-a-crisis">medtech innovation</a>, and a <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/insurance-productivity-2030-reimagining-the-insurer-for-the-future">more productive future for insurers</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #26, October 7, 2020</h2>
<h4>As the effects of the pandemic intensify gender inequality, further threaten the economy, and raise hurdles for the health industry, companies actions now could see them through the crisis.</h4>
<p><strong>In the sixth year</strong> of our <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive">Women in the Workplace</a> study, conducted in partnership with LeanIn.Org, we find that the effects of the COVID-19 crisis have exacerbated gender disparities and their implications for women at work, especially for mothers, female senior leaders, and Black women across America. In addition to being laid off and furloughed at higher rates than their male counterparts during the pandemic, women arenotably, for the first time in our research on the topicconsidering downshifting their careers or leaving the workforce altogether at staggering rates.</p>
<p>The exodus might include as many as two million women. That would raise a significant barrier to achieving gender parity in leadership roles in years to come. People are thinking about leaving the workforce for a variety of reasons. While many organizations are providing additional resources related to remote working and employee well-being, there is more to be done to meet employees needs for sustainable, flexible, and empathic work environments, especially for parents and caregivers.</p>
<p>Meanwhile, the global economic contractions resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic have far exceeded those of the Great Recession that ended in 2009 and have occurred at a much faster rate, hitting all sectors and many of the worlds largest employers. As companies plan for various outcomes in 2021, our research shows what companies seeking resilience can do today to achieve <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/the-emerging-resilients-achieving-escape-velocity">escape velocity</a> from the crisis by focusing on EBITDA<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7f81643a-3e15-427a-821a-7e962f76d4b0"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7f81643a-3e15-427a-821a-7e962f76d4b0" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization.</span></span></span></a></span> margins, revenue, and optionality.</p>
<p>An area where companies have already adjusted well is using technology to address changing work environments and to stay competitive. Our new <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever">global survey</a> finds that organizations that are successfully responding to the crisis have deployed more advanced technologies, digital products, and tech talent to speed up innovationand they expect most of these changes to outlast the pandemic.</p>
<p>Our research this week sheds light on two important issues facing healthcare providers. First, similarities in flu and COVID-19 symptoms could lead to a threefold spike in demand for <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/winter-is-coming-whats-next-in-covid-19-testing">COVID-19 testing</a> as flu season in the Northern Hemisphere approaches. Maintaining sufficient capacity for testing and contact tracing will be critical in curbing further outbreaks and protecting high-risk groups. Second, the crisis has also led to a <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/cutting-through-the-covid-19-surgical-backlog">surgical backlog</a> for elective procedures because of lack of hospital capacity, workforce shortages, and new safety protocols. Health systems will need to optimize current clinical operations to address the discrepancies in supply and demand.</p>
<p>This week we also explored how <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-european-marketing-and-sales-leaders-handle-covid-19s-effects">European marketing-and-sales leaders</a> are navigating the effects of the pandemic, the <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-domino-effect-how-sales-leaders-are-reinventing-go-to-market-in-the-next-normal">domino effect</a> for improving sales returns on investment, disruption that is reshaping <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-next-normal-in-construction-material-distribution">construction-material distribution</a>, and <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/covid-19-crisis-how-distributors-can-emerge-stronger-than-before">steps that distributors can take</a> to stabilize operations and outperform competitors.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #25, September 30, 2020</h2>
<h4>Executives are more hopeful about the economy than they have been at any time so far during the COVID-19 crisis. Is an end to the pandemic at hand?</h4>
<p><strong>Six months</strong> after WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic, the responses to our latest McKinsey Global Survey suggest <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment">a positive shift</a> in economic sentiment. More than half of all executives surveyed say economic conditions in their own countries will be better six months from now, while 30 percent say they will worsen. Thats the smallest percentage of pessimists weve seen since the survey in April 2020.</p>
<p>Taking a cue from those executives, our researchers delved deep into <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/an-optimistic-scenario-for-the-us-response-to-covid-19">the US situation</a>, emerging with an understanding of what it will take to deliver an optimistic outcome. The case depends on the progress made to dateand the potential for more. Weve learned much about the natural history and epidemiology of COVID-19. Were developing better diagnostics, including rapid point-of-care tests, a few of which can be completed in about 15 minutes. Case management has improved. And pharmaceutical companies have turned out a remarkably robust pipeline of vaccine and therapeutic candidates. Put it all together, and <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end">an end to the pandemic</a> is potentially within range. </p>
<p>Another new survey reveals the extent of the COVID-19 crisiss <a href="/featured-insights/future-of-work/what-800-executives-envision-for-the-postpandemic-workforce">disruption in working practices and behaviors</a>. One-third of surveyed companies have accelerated the digitization of their supply chains, half have sped up the digitization of their customer channels, and two-thirds have moved faster to adopt artificial intelligence and automation. Many other workforce changes are also in progress. </p>
<p>Managers need to process these changes and many others, and come to grips with <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/as-you-return-from-the-summer-break-can-you-lead-toward-a-covid-exit">the long-term strategic-planning agenda</a>. The essential question: what is the right way to think about 2021 and beyond? Should companies unbatten the hatches, or is it too soon? </p>
<p>For many families, it isnt the workplace but the school that occupies the most attention. McKinseys latest look at education examines the variables that factor into <a href="/industries/education/our-insights/reopening-schools-fostering-a-safe-and-effective-learning-environment">decisions to reopen schools</a>. Also this week, McKinsey researchers focused on <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/moving-from-cash-preservation-to-cash-excellence-for-the-next-normal">cash management through the crisis</a> and on the problems of <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/zero-based-budgeting-for-health-plans-dealing-with-uncertainty-ahead">budgeting in healthcare systems</a>. </p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #24, September 23, 2020</h2>
<h4>A potential end to the pandemic, a bright outlook for electric vehicles, and more.</h4>
<p><strong>In our latest public-health research,</strong> we <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end">assess the prospects</a> for an end to the pandemic. Two standards must be met. In the United States and most other developed economies, <em>herd immunity</em> is most likely to be achieved in the third or fourth quarter of 2021. Key variables are the arrival, efficacy, and coverage of vaccines; we anticipate four scenarios. A <em>return to normalcy</em> might come sooner, possibly in the first or second quarter of 2021. Every day matters, for lives and livelihoods.</p>
<p>On the economic front, the COVID-19 crisis presents the greatest challenge in a decade for the auto sector. Global sales of light vehicles in 2020 might decline 20 to 25 percent from prepandemic forecasts. In the hardest-hit countries, sales could fall by 45 percent. Electric vehicles (EVs) have not been spared. But our new <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electric-mobility-after-the-crisis-why-an-auto-slowdown-wont-hurt-ev-demand">research</a> finds that EV sales may come back quickly in the next couple of years, especially in Asia and Europe, for a few reasons.</p>
<p>The crisis has also set in motion a number of trends in mobility that will affect EVs, internal-combustion engines, and all the other ways that people get around. A second <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/five-covid-19-aftershocks-reshaping-mobilitys-future">report</a> considers five of these trends. One critical finding: as lives become hyperlocal, modes of transport will change. We expect a drastic decrease in private-car usage in some major European cities but only a slight decline in North America. Greater China will become even more reliant on public transit and rail as some drivers are coaxed out of their cars.</p>
<p>Our private-equity research teams chipped in a comprehensive <a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/a-rolling-disruption-covid-19s-implications-for-private-equity-and-portfolio-companies">look</a> at the effects of the crisis on sectors, and what those mean for portfolio companies and firm strategy. Several analyses offer insights; one on debt-service coverage ratios finds that companies in industrial equipment and logistics are among the most vulnerable, along with real estate, travel, and retail. Telecom companies are better situated, as their business has been only mildly disrupted.</p>
<p>Also this week: McKinsey has long been committed to <a href="/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/how-advancing-womens-equality-can-add-12-trillion-to-global-growth">research</a> into gender equality. In 2015, UN signatories set an ambitious target of achieving gender equality and empowering women and girls everywhere. Five years on, we assess the scant progress to date, blunted by COVID-19, and offer <a href="/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/ten-things-to-know-about-gender-equality">ten things that everyone needs to know</a> about gender equality.</p>
<p>Finally, our researchers offer new views on the post-COVID-19 future of the <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/the-travel-industry-turned-upside-down-insights-analysis-and-actions-for-travel-executives">global travel industry</a>, <a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/graphic-paper-producers-boosting-resilience-amid-the-covid-19-crisis">graphic-paper producers</a>, and <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/covid-19s-impact-on-the-global-gold-industry-implications-for-the-next-normal-and-beyond">the global gold industry</a>. And, with disruption everywhere, people miss their old lives. Thats a problem for managers, who can take <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/your-organization-is-grieving-heres-how-you-can-help">three practical steps</a> to help people process their grief.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #23, September 16, 2020</h2>
<h4>Companies return to work after an unusual summerand grapple with an uncertain future.</h4>
<p><strong>What now?</strong> Over the past six months, business leaders have reorganized supply chains, set up remote operations, and made tough financial decisions. The world anxiously awaits an effective COVID-19 vaccine that can be readily distributed. Until then, the priority is to reenergize organizationsto act rather than react. Even as the uncertainties of the COVID-19 crisis multiply, the goal must be to rebuild for the longer term. There are many ways to lead, but regardless of the type of business or geography, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/what-now-decisive-actions-to-emerge-stronger-in-the-next-normal">ten actions</a> can form a path to emerge stronger from the crisis.</p>
<p>We start with an ideathat returning is a <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/return-a-new-muscle-not-just-a-plan">muscle</a> that needs to be exercised, not a plan to be executed once or a date to be achieved. We go on to more specific considerations, such as the need to <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/ready-set-go-reinventing-the-organization-for-speed-in-the-post-covid-19-era">make big moves fast</a> and to be willing to <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-m-and-a-success">rethink entire portfolios</a>, including <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-workforce">where work gets done</a>.</p>
<p>Those are four of the ten actions, and they make for a good starting point. But companies must adjust for the particulars of their industry. Healthcare companies might want to pay strict heed to <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-great-acceleration-in-healthcare-six-trends-to-heed">six trends</a> that are affecting their business. Most were under way before the crisis. But a crisis has a way of bringing things to a head: the coming months might be the best opportunity in memory for healthcare companies to pursue <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-era-of-exponential-improvement-in-healthcare">exponential innovation</a>, which could create an additional $400 billion in value by 2025. And now is the time to claim the hundreds of billions of dollars that could be saved through <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-productivity-imperative-for-healthcare-delivery-in-the-united-states">productivity gains</a>.</p>
<p>McKinseys healthcare researchers also took a close look at the <a href="/industries/social-sector/our-insights/improving-the-fragile-us-supply-of-blood">US blood supply</a>, which was fragile before the pandemic and is now critical. Businesses have a big role to play in the solution. Blood donors frequently cite convenience and social pressure as prompts. Virtual campaigns for blood drives can help blood centers quickly reach large audiences and steer them to the locations most convenient for them.</p>
<p>CFOs have a critical task too: for many, its budgeting season. Our new <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/memo-to-the-cfo-a-new-approach-to-2021-budgeting-starts-now">research</a> finds that the financial-planning process for 2021 presents an opportunity to turn hard-earned lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic into an enduring exercise in linking strategy to value. And leaders across organizations need to consider the problems of <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-hidden-perils-of-unresolved-grief">unresolved grief</a>another issue that the pandemic has dragged into the spotlight.</p>
<p>Our industry research this week looked at <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/detour-an-altered-path-to-profit-for-european-fintechs">fintech</a>, where the news is not altogether bad, though fintech companies may have to find a detour on the road to profitability. We also considered <a href="/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/a-new-prescription-for-m-and-a-in-pharma">M&A in pharma</a>, a long-running trend that should continue. Companies are advised to make sure that three capabilitiescompetitive advantage, capacity, and convictionare up to snuff before pursuing COVID-19-era mergers.</p>
<p>Finally, the pandemic has forced a reckoning for many between the profit motive and a companys social purpose. A team of McKinsey editors recaps how we got <a href="/featured-insights/corporate-purpose/from-there-to-here-50-years-of-thinking-on-the-social-responsibility-of-business">from there to here</a>, and suggests where we might go next.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #22, September 10, 2020</h2>
<h4>McKinsey research focuses on the postpandemic future of developing Asia.</h4>
<p><strong>No nation has escaped</strong> widespread disruption from the COVID-19 pandemic, but some have fared better than others. This week, McKinsey researchers examined the state of the recovery in some of the emerging Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countriesIndonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnamthat began the crisis at a disadvantage and have suffered disproportionate effects. Our new <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/reimagining-emerging-asean-in-the-wake-of-covid-19">report</a> explores a series of trends that the pandemic has caused or accelerated. Within each is a seed of recovery, but stakeholders must be prepared to reimagine their countrys economy in five areas: manufacturing hubs, green infrastructure, investments in digital, talent reskilling, and high-value food industries.</p>
<p>We also looked in detail at developments in two ASEAN countries. In <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/with-effort-indonesia-can-emerge-from-the-covid-19-crisis-stronger">Indonesia</a>, the pandemic is still raging; case counts and fatalities are rising sharply. The first priority is to mitigate and contain the outbreak. But even amid the current hardship and profound uncertainty, Indonesia can reimagine and reform itself by increasing national resilience, accelerating economic transition, rebuilding the tourist sector, and enabling genuine change.</p>
<p>Vietnam, too, is contending with <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/emerging-from-the-pandemic-vietnam-must-position-itself-for-recovery">short-term challenges</a> as it emerges from the pandemic, especially in tourism and manufacturing, two of the countrys strengths. For the long haul, our new <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/what-will-it-take-to-achieve-vietnams-long-term-growth-aspirations">report</a> argues that one essential element of growth is renewable energy. As a country likely to be heavily affected by climate change, Vietnam could accelerate its journey toward a less carbon-intensive future.
