<a id="preventing-future-waves-of-covid-19"></a>
<h2>Preventing future waves of COVID-19: Briefing note #21, August 31, 2020</h2>
<h4>After seven months of responding to the pandemic, we have learned some things. Here are some of the key lessons and how to apply them.</h4>
<h6>By Sarun Charumilind, Matt Craven, Jessica Lamb, and Matt Wilson</h6>
<p><strong>When history books</strong> one day recount the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, it may well be a tale of human ingenuity and adaptiveness. Although the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes COVID-19, has infected more than 24 million people and left more than 800,000 dead as of this writing, the early projections of mortality were much worse.</p>
<p>Fears of millions of deaths by June 2020 have proven wrongnot because the disease is less lethal than anticipated, but because those fears ignored the ability of people to learn and change behaviors. Pockets of resistance against wearing masks and complying with other measures notwithstanding, the global public-health response has saved millions of lives. Increasingly, countries are restarting more aspects of normal life while keeping case numbers tenuously in check.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Pockets of resistance against wearing masks and complying with other measures notwithstanding, the global public health response has saved millions of lives.</p></blockquote></div>
<p>Yet the threat to lives and livelihoods persists. A COVID-19 vaccine may yet <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world">save the world</a>. But even if one proves effective, it will be many months before we will have the capacity to vaccinate everyoneand there are new concerns about reinfection.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="f575fc38-f676-4870-b03e-5c5dad9d0fea"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="f575fc38-f676-4870-b03e-5c5dad9d0fea" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Andrew Joseph, First Covid-19 reinfection documented in Hong Kong, researchers say, STAT, August 24, 2020, statnews.com.</span></span></span></a></span> Therapeutics such as dexamethasone and remdesivir appear to provide important benefits for those with severe cases but are not alone sufficient to stop deaths from COVID-19.</p>
<p>New therapies are possible but by no means guaranteed. Countries will very likely need to plan for almost another year during which public-health measures are their primary tools for saving lives. In the meantime, the world cannot be idle. Societies have been upended, causing unprecedented disruption to economies, education systems, and the day-to-day lives of people everywhere. And as we and others have argued, <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-saving-thousands-of-lives-and-trillions-in-livelihoods">saving lives and opening societies is a false trade-off</a>.</p>
<p>In that area, too, our ability to learn and adapt is proving dispositive. Countries that have successfully reduced their number of COVID-19 cases have generally been more successful at reopening their economies. For them, controlling the virus ultimately has come down to two things:
understanding what to do and executing well. Both have been challenging at various points. For example, the evidence base for the population-wide use of masks only became compelling a few months into the pandemic response. In contrast, the importance of testing has been clear from the earliest days, but many countries have faced operational challenges in ramping up their capacity.</p>
<p>While there is much more to learn, this article summarizes what response leaders have discovered so far about what to do and how to do it. Every jurisdiction is doing some of these things; none of them are new for experts in infectious diseases. But we have tried to describe specific considerations for practitioners looking to adopt and adapt best practices to their management of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the outsize role that businesses are taking in the crisis response in numerous countries, many of the ideas are as relevant to private-sector leaders as to those in the public sector. Interventions are divided into three categoriesdetecting disease, reducing the number of new cases, and limiting mortalityand can be tailored for specific populations and settings.</p>
<h3>Detecting disease</h3>
<p>The ability to detect cases of COVID-19 is a critical prerequisite for effective public-health programs. A comprehensive program might include traditional disease surveillance, cluster analysis to understand local patterns of transmission, and wastewater surveillance for early warning of disease hot spots.</p>
<h4>Disease surveillance</h4>
<p>An ability to collect, analyze, and interpret data is fundamental to the management of infectious diseases. While many people have grown familiar with epidemiological metrics such as test-positivity rates and case-fatality ratios, many countries and regions still rely on 20th-century surveillance systems. The biggest gaps are in data collection and integration: there is no shortage of data-crunching horsepower in the world, but everyone is forced to work from the same imperfect data sets. Even seven months into the COVID-19-pandemic response, there is a surprising level of disagreement about questions as basic as the true number of people who have been infected with SARS-CoV-2 and the number of deaths attributable to it. Continuing to expand testing, as described later in this article, is a big part of improving surveillance.</p>
<p>The best surveillance systems seamlessly combine data from traditional sources with newer data sets, such as anonymized mobility trackingand do so in near real time. They provide a high level of detail and transparency around the characteristics and location of those infected while protecting individual privacy. And they improve over time as a design principle, incorporating new sources of data and improving quality to reduce friction in the response.</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-lg-center" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>The best surveillance systems seamlessly combine data from traditional sources with newer data sets, such as anonymized mobility trackingand do so in near real time.</p></blockquote></div>
<h4>Cluster analysis</h4>
<p>The medical community has learned much about how COVID-19 is passed from person to person and therefore how to prevent transmission. But there is more to learn about the specific nature of transmission in particular geographies. The examination of chains of infectious-disease transmission, or cluster analysis, helps medical professionals understand how, when, where, and between whom transmission occurs.</p>
<p>Locally relevant information can focus public-health measures on steps that will make a difference and deemphasize those that wont. A study of more than 3,000 cases across 61 clusters in Japan, for example, identified healthcare facilities and retirement centers as among the most important centers of transmission.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="44114f68-f227-40e9-b955-96760c4e89cc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="44114f68-f227-40e9-b955-96760c4e89cc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Yuki Furuse et al., Clusters of coronavirus disease in communities, Japan, JanuaryApril 2020, <em>Emerging Infectious Diseases,</em> September 2020, Volume 26, Number 9, pp. 2,1769, cdc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, clusters in the United Kingdom have been identified around retirement homes, in hospitals, and in meatpacking factoriesthe latter also being a source of clusters in Germany.</p>
<p>Cluster analysis has revealed the importance and characteristics of so-called superspreaders (infected individuals who pass the disease to many others). A deeper understanding of transmission dynamics may allow some regions to move from broad-based interventions to targeted ones. It can also allow for more nuanced risk assessments, for example, to determine who can safely access senior-care facilities.</p>
<h4>Wastewater surveillance</h4>
<p>An important advance in surveillance capabilities came with the discovery that SARS-CoV-2 is present in the stool of infected people and is detectable even in highly diluted samples, such as municipal wastewater. Wastewater sampling, used for decades to monitor for polio, appears to detect viral increases of COVID-19 up to six days earlier than diagnostic tests of individuals do.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="38ade20e-22c5-4e38-bde5-29303f5ac108"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="38ade20e-22c5-4e38-bde5-29303f5ac108" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jordan Peccia et al., SARS-CoV-2 RNA concentrations in primary municipal sewage sludge as a leading indicator of COVID-19 outbreak dynamics, medRxiv, June 12, 2020, medrxiv.org.</span></span></span></a></span> While a number of locations, including Queensland in Australia, Ashkelon in Israel, and Boise in the United States,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="db1e051e-b09a-40e5-940d-d82d678bc683"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="db1e051e-b09a-40e5-940d-d82d678bc683" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">AFP and Toi Staff, Israeli tech firm successfully tracks down COVID-19 in Ashkelons sewers, Times of Israel, July 30, 2020, timesofisrael.com; Misty Inglet, Boise city officials work to flush out coronavirus data through continued wastewater testing, KTVB-TV, July 27, 2020, ktvb.com; University of Queensland, Australian researchers trace sewage for early warning COVID-19 spread, Medical Xpress, April 16, 2020, medicalxpress.com.</span></span></span></a></span> are piloting or using this approach to monitor for COVID-19, wastewater remains an underutilized tool globally.</p>
<p>The wastewater-surveillance approach is most applicable in low-prevalence settings where an increase in cases is more noticeable and testing of individuals might otherwise be limited. Ideally, public-health leaders would have the ability to work upstream when increases in viral concentration are detectedfor example, from testing town sewers to determining which neighborhoods are the source of the virus.</p>
<h3>Reducing the number of new cases</h3>
<p>Preventing new cases of COVID-19 ultimately requires reducing the opportunity for infected individuals to pass the disease to others. That can be done by identifying and isolating those who have been infected or are at high risk, ensuring physical distance and airflow management, reducing the risk of the encounters that do happen, and reducing case migration from higher-prevalence areas.
The basic tool kit for the reduction of new cases is well understood by experts and nonexperts alike. It includes canceling mass events, restricting capacity in social settings (particularly indoors or with large numbers of people), implementing confinement measures, and restricting internal movement. Those measures can be reinforced through effective behavior-change communication and focused implementation for high-risk groups or specific geographies. And since COVID-19 vaccines are likely to be approved eventually, leaders may want to start now in preparing to deploy one effectively. In this section, we highlight some second-order or less appreciated lessons from the pandemic response so far.</p>
<h4>Identifying and isolating those infected</h4>
<p>Widespread, accurate, efficiently managed testing and contact-tracing programs allow countries to isolate those who have or are at high risk of contracting COVID-19. Testing and tracing have played major roles in the successful response to various phases of the pandemic in a number of countries, including Austria, Iceland, New Zealand, and South Korea.</p>
<p>Despite the apparent simplicity of testing and tracing, practitioners learned the hard way through early missteps. Among their many lessons are the following:</p>
<ul>
    <li>Communicate clearly with the public about the appropriate uses and limitations of different types of tests, including antigen, molecular, and antibody testing.</li>
    <li>Address supply-chain and logistical challenges to keep expanding testing access until most cases are being detected. Test-positivity rates above 5 percent suggest that too many cases are being missed.</li>
    <li>Make use of pooled testing to boost capacity where needed, especially in low-prevalence settings. Combine testing for surveillance with testing for positive-case identification.</li>
    <li>Accelerate testing turnaround time by ensuring that those performing tests are compensated based on speed and accuracy, not just volume. Accelerate the application of test results by integrating data platforms for testing with those for contact tracing, shortening the time to quarantine.</li>
    <li>Staff enough personnel, as the core of contact-tracing programs is human-to-human conversation. Overinvest in community sensitization to the value of tracing and importance of contact quarantine. Digital contact-tracing tools with high adoption can also accelerate contact identification and shorten the time to quarantine.</li>
    <li>Dont expect contact tracing to work perfectly initially; take a data-centric approach to improving operations and effectiveness over time.</li>
    <li>Recognize that isolating for ten to 14 days is onerous, especially for low-income individuals. Social services and options for out-of-home isolation, such as in converted hotels, can improve the effectiveness of quarantine and make it more tolerable.</li>
</ul>
<h4>Managing risk in encounters between people</h4>
<p>COVID-19 is spread primarily from person to person, including from those not showing symptoms, through the air (either on droplets or by truly being airborne). Close proximity and poor airflow increase the risk of transmission, while the use of facial coverings decreases it. Specific considerations for risk reduction vary depending on risk, context, and other conditions.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a6165a53-5221-4135-bf7e-72c56de45164"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a6165a53-5221-4135-bf7e-72c56de45164" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Considerations for wearing masks: Help slow the spread of COVID-19, Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, August 7, 2020, cdc.gov.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Limited evidence from US states suggests that mask mandates are correlated with greater reductions in new cases than mask recommendations are. Different masks offer varying levels of protection. N95 respirators fitted to users provide the greatest protection,<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="8c15b281-70f6-4f5a-90fd-423893ef64c1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="8c15b281-70f6-4f5a-90fd-423893ef64c1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Masks save lives: Duke study confirms which ones work best, Hartford HealthCare, August 11, 2020, hartfordhealthcare.org.</span></span></span></a></span> protecting both the wearer and those around them. Supply constraints, cost, and user comfort mean that universal N95 use is not practical in many settings. Three-layer surgical masks provide the next greatest protection. Goggles and other eye protection may provide incremental protection to the wearer relative to a mask alone.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6d3aa44f-105b-4f42-8650-a15338da272f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">8</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6d3aa44f-105b-4f42-8650-a15338da272f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Derek K. Chu et al., Physical distancing, face masks, and eye protection to prevent person-to-person transmission of SARS-CoV-2 and COVID-19: A systematic review and meta-analysis, <em>Lancet,</em> June 2020, Volume 395, Number 10,242, pp. 1,97387, thelancet.com.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Frequent hand washing and environmental cleaning reduce the transmission of COVID-19. However, the relative emphasis on environmental cleaning has decreased, as evidence suggests that transmission primarily occurs from person to person rather than via objects in the environment.</p>
<h4>Reducing case migration</h4>
<p>Across the world, countries are taking different approaches to restricting importation of COVID-19 cases. They range from complete bans on international travel to targeted bans on travel from locations with high caseloads to screening and quarantine requirements for arriving travelers. In some countries, including Australia and the United States, some of those measures also apply for travel within countries. In many cases, companies and other institutions are implementing their own policies beyond those required by governments. Measures that are based on consistent, easily understood criteria are more likely to maintain high levels of public buy-in and participation.</p>
<h4>Changing behaviors</h4>
<p>A successful response to the COVID-19 pandemic requires convincing large numbers of people to change their behaviors. Some countries have seen significant resistance to such changes, particularly those around physical-distancing measures and facial-covering mandates. A lack of trust in governments, information overload, and inconsistent messaging over time have all contributed to that opposition. Effective public-health communication can accelerate the adoption of new behaviors.</p>
<p>Effective communication includes segmenting populations based on the combination of channels, influencers, and messages most likely to resonate with individual groups. While there are positive examples from the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the public-health community could learn more from experts in targeting and tailoring political and consumer-marketing messages. The <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-long-haul-how-leaders-can-shift-mindsets-and-behaviors-to-reopen-safely">influence model</a> can help. It suggests that people are most likely to change behaviors when four elements are in place:</p>
<ul>
    <li><em>Understanding and conviction in what is being asked.</em> I believe that wearing a face mask will help protect me and my community from COVID-19.</li>
    <li><em>Reinforcement with formal mechanisms, which may include both carrots and sticks.</em> The grocery store has both a sign, which I can see as I approach, saying that masks are required and a greeter handing them out.</li>
    <li><em>Confidence and skill building in the new behavior.</em> Ive worn a mask enough times that Ive stopped worrying about looking silly.</li>
    <li><em>Role modeling the new behavior.</em> The mayor of my town and almost everyone around me are wearing masks. Those not doing so look like the exceptions.</li>
</ul>
<p>Applying insights from the influence model to COVID-19-related communications is an area in which collaboration might help. Many jurisdictions are enlisting the help of partners, celebrities, and influencers to amplify their messages. For example, in the United States, basketball star Stephen Curry asked questions of infectious-disease expert Anthony Fauci live on Instagram. That served to bring evidence-based public-health information to audiences less likely to access official sources.</p>
<h4>Protecting vulnerable populations</h4>
<p>The COVID-19 pandemic has a <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/insights-on-racial-and-ethnic-health-inequity-in-the-context-of-covid-19">disproportionate impact on a number of vulnerable populations</a>. Such groups include people whose age or health puts them at increased risk and those at greater risk because of socioeconomic factors. Communities with severe housing problems, unemployment rates, incarceration rates, poverty levels, and food insecurity suffer 1.4 to 4.0 times as many COVID-19-related deaths as other communities. Vulnerable populations are less likely to have access to healthcare in most countries and are more likely to have underlying health conditions.</p>
<p>In addition to measuring and tracking the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on vulnerable populations, designing protective interventions requires identifying what makes those groups more vulnerable to infection. Approaches might include prioritizing access to testing, targeting communications, and providing additional support for quarantine and isolation. Interventions will likely need to be multipronged, since the most vulnerable communities are often vulnerable for multiple reasons. Furthermore, the stakeholders best positioned to implement interventions effectively will need resources, which would ideally be allocated proportionately to the outsize impact of COVID-19 infection on vulnerable communities.</p>
<h4>Planning for a vaccine</h4>
<p>It is reasonable to hope that Emergency Use Authorization (or its equivalent) <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world">may be granted to one or more COVID-19-vaccine candidates</a> before the end of 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="2f86b413-98e4-401c-919e-873a8500cbfe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="2f86b413-98e4-401c-919e-873a8500cbfe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Monoclonal antibodies and some drugs also have the potential to prevent COVID-19 cases. Similar principles apply to them, but for simplicity, we refer only to vaccines in this section. China and Russia agencies have also granted conditional use for COVID-19 vaccines in their countries.</span></span></span></a></span> While vaccines will be valuable new tools, their approval will bring a whole new set of questions for leaders.</p>
<p>Planning now will increase the chance of a successful vaccine rollout. Those on point will need to monitor closely the technical characteristics of the most promising vaccine candidates. Such monitoring includes understanding the likely dosing regimen, potential efficacy, and side effects. From there, they will need to develop a clear, scenario-based strategy for prioritizing vaccine access, recognizing the range of potential vaccine outcomes and combinations available.</p>
<p>Every jurisdiction is likely to be vaccine-supply constrained in the short term, so agreeing on grounding principles in advance will make allocation decisions easier down the road. So will designing the end-to-end supply and delivery systems that will be needed. The plan should include systems for ensuring series completion in the case of a multidose vaccine and data systems for tracking those who have been vaccinated. It may include temporarily expanding the roles of medical practitionersfor example, by allowing those with lower levels of qualification to administer vaccines, after training, in uncomplicated cases.</p>
<p>Finally, planners may need to overinvest in addressing vaccine hesitancy in areas where surveys suggest it is a significant concern. Communications around vaccines will be both challenging and important given the likely complexity of information around efficacy, safety, and dosing across multiple vaccine candidates.</p>
<h3>Limiting mortality</h3>
<p>In addition to limiting case numbers, reducing the mortality associated with COVID-19 is a key element of the fight against the disease. Clinicians and health-system leaders have learned much about both the specific clinical management of COVID-19 and how to prepare health systems to manage surges in cases while maintaining essential services.</p>
<h4>Health-system preparedness</h4>
<p>In the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, the world anxiously witnessed many countries health systems strain under the exponential onslaught of cases. <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/critical-care-capacity-the-number-to-watch-during-the-battle-of-covid-19">Critical-care capacity</a> was a bottleneck, given that one in five patients, initially, were dependent on ventilators. Healthcare supply chains, especially for personal protective equipment, were overwhelmed.</p>
<p>To create surge capacity, health systems and consumers ceased elective careseemingly overnight. That resulted in an imbalance of capacity, with overloaded health systems in COVID-19 epicenters transformed into disaster-response hubs. In areas where the disease had not yet spread, care centers sat empty, waiting for an outbreak they were unsure would ever arrive.</p>
<p>We know now that health systems in any developed country should be able to anticipate, plan for, manage, and successfully navigate the pandemic adequately both for <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/understanding-and-managing-the-hidden-health-crisis-of-covid-19-in-europe">patients with COVID-19 and for patients with other diseases</a>. Some require focused action, especially surge capacity, supply availability, workforce readiness, clinical-operations processes, structure for COVID-19-case governance, and financial resiliency.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4fdd8d92-a9d8-4da1-9fee-b0c749541383"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4fdd8d92-a9d8-4da1-9fee-b0c749541383" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Bede Broome, Omar Kattan, Pooja Kumar, and Shubham Singhal, Reassessing Covid-19 needs: How providers can reexamine their surge capacity, supply availability, workforce readiness, and financial resiliency, <em>NEJM Catalyst Innovations in Care Delivery,</em> May 7, 2020, catalyst.nejm.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<h4>Use of therapeutics and clinical management</h4>
<p>The search for effective therapies for COVID-19 has yielded two important advances, so far, but no breakthrough transformative enough to obviate the need to limit cases. Dexamethasone, an injected corticosteroid, was shown to reduce mortality by 35 percent in patients requiring mechanical ventilation and by 18 percent in those requiring oxygen only.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3af60851-348d-4bb9-b9e3-ed04dfc59ecc"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3af60851-348d-4bb9-b9e3-ed04dfc59ecc" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">RECOVERY Collaborative Group, Dexamethasone in hospitalized patients with Covid-19preliminary report, <em>New England Journal of Medicine,</em> July 17, 2020, nejm.org.</span></span></span></a></span> Remdesivir has been shown to reduce recovery time by an average of four days.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a4c59358-5bd2-4f69-9408-753a5a294735"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a4c59358-5bd2-4f69-9408-753a5a294735" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">John H. Beigel et al., Remdesivir for the treatment of Covid-19preliminary report, <em>New England Journal of Medicine,</em> May 22, 2020, nejm.org.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Both drugs emerged from the medical communitys initial focus on repurposing drugs that were already approved or in late-stage development for the treatment of other diseases. The focus is now shifting to new R&D. In the months ahead, additional evidence may support therapies based on other antivirals and monoclonal antibodies. In addition to specific therapeutics for COVID-19, there have
been advances in the nonpharmaceutical management of the disease. For example, there is some evidence to support the use of proningplacing patients face downto reduce the need for mechanical ventilation.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dae2cdd8-261c-409f-8f3c-c0d09da28fa1"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dae2cdd8-261c-409f-8f3c-c0d09da28fa1" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Proning COVID-19 patients reduces need for ventilators, Columbia University, July 2, 2020, cuimc.columbia.edu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Policy makers can continue to keep a close eye on both the evidence for new therapeutics and the standards of clinical practice. Over time and with further advances, strong health systems may succeed in reducing COVID-19-related mortality to the point at which the disease is far less feared.</p>
<hr>
<p>Public-health measures to control the COVID-19 pandemic will be relevant for as long as its risk continues. Many countries and regions have risen to the challenge by combining multiple public-health measures that work for them, although almost all have some room to improve. As we consider what it will take to respond to current and future waves of COVID-19, we can take some comfort from the fact that far more is known about controlling SARS-CoV-2 than was understood seven months ago. It is up to all of us to learn, adapt, and apply those lessons effectively.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #20, August 27, 2020</h2>
<h4>Amid one of the greatest bull markets ever for technology, semiconductor fabs must find ways to keep up. And all advanced-industry companies should organize for speed to sustain their current pace. </h4>
<p><strong>This week, McKinsey healthcare researchers</strong> documented the <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-exposes-a-critical-shortage-of-oxygen-in-developing-countries">shortage of medical oxygen</a> in developing countries, a long-standing problem made worse by COVID-19. New ideas can help these regions meet short-term needs and set the foundation for a better long-term future.</p>
<p>Our industry research focused on semiconductors and the industries that make and use advanced electronics. Chips control everything from toys and smartphones to laptops and thermostats. In the pandemic, demand has soared for many of these productseven as <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains">supply chains</a> have faltered and geopolitical tensions have risen. But will the boom last? Such questions have semiconductor companies thinking about their manufacturing plants. In a winner-take-all industry, even a slight edge in manufacturing can help a company capture an outsize portion of revenues. Our new <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/semiconductor-design-and-manufacturing-achieving-leading-edge-capabilities">report</a> outlines the essential ingredients of tomorrows successful fab.</p>
<p>Chipmakers and other advanced manufacturers have been running hot for six months now, with some notable notches in their belts. One factory recently ran at more than 90 percent capacity with only about 40 percent of the typical workforce. But few leaders think the pace is sustainable. Our new report lays out what it will mean for companies to switch from running on adrenaline to making <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/organizing-for-speed-in-advanced-industries">organizational speed</a> a permanent part of their cultures.</p>
<p>The pace is unlikely to slacken soon. As our new <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-imperatives-for-automation-success">global survey</a> suggests, the appetite for automation has not dimmed. Instead, the factors for success are shifting. More and more, successful organizations are finding ways for people to work in concert with new technologies.</p>
<p>In fact, automation is among the key themes that can lift India to prosperity. Thats the conclusion of a new <a href="/featured-insights/india/indias-turning-point-an-economic-agenda-to-spur-growth-and-jobs">report</a> from McKinsey Global Institute published this week. The pandemic has sounded a clarion call for India to accelerate growth. Our analysis suggests that a program of targeted reforms, including greater productivity in several sectors, can help the country produce the 90 million nonfarm jobs it needs to create by 2030.</p>
<p>This week, McKinsey researchers also examined cash management at <a href="/industries/private-capital/our-insights/seeing-the-savings-toward-transparent-management-of-portfolio-companies">privately owned companies</a> and reviewed lessons from the past for <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/lessons-for-us-governors-and-mayors-planning-a-second-term">US governors and mayors</a> planning a second term.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #19, August 20, 2020</h2>
<h4>McKinseys latest research looks at restoring economic activity, today and tomorrow.</h4>
<p><strong>This week, we returned</strong> to the overarching story of the pandemic: the twin imperatives of saving lives and livelihoods. Our latest research builds on reports we published in <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/safeguarding-our-lives-and-our-livelihoods-the-imperative-of-our-time">April</a> and <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/crushing-coronavirus-uncertainty-the-big-unlock-for-our-economies">May</a> 2020, and on recent academic findings that the stringency of national lockdowns is not well correlated with changes in GDP. In our new <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-saving-thousands-of-lives-and-trillions-in-livelihoods">report</a>, we find that successful control of the virus is the key to unlocking the economy, by restoring the confidence consumers need to reengage in economic activity. In countries that have successfully controlled the coronavirus (near zero countries), economic activity (in the form of discretionary mobility) has returned to normal; in those that have not (balancing act), it is still about 40 percent lower than before the pandemic.</p>
<p>It seems that controlling the virus can get countries back to where they were at the start of the year. But where do we go from there? A companion <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-economic-future">report</a> outlines the future of economic growth in the United States, by looking back at what worked well in the years after the 200809 recession. Federal, state, and local governments can take a range of actions to both improve productivity and stimulate demand. Among the most powerful is investment in inclusive growth  and unlocking the maximum productive potential of all people in communities. For example, achieving <a href="/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/the-power-of-parity-advancing-womens-equality-in-the-united-states">gender equality</a> could add $4 trillion to the US economy, and closing the <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-economic-impact-of-closing-the-racial-wealth-gap">Blackwhite wealth gap</a> could add a further $1.5 trillion.</p>
<p>Businesses, too, are eager to boost productivity and demand. Consumer companies may feel these needs more acutely than most, as two reports published this week demonstrate. McKinsey experts outlined the <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/consumer-organization-and-operating-models-bold-moves-for-the-next-normal">five bold moves</a> that consumer companies should make to adapt their organizations to the exigencies of the crisis. Another requirement is to <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/meet-the-next-normal-consumer">meet the next-normal consumer</a>. Seemingly every consumer behavior has been altered by the crisis; companies need to adapt to big changes in how people get their information, what and where they buy, and how they experience shopping.</p>
<p>This week, we also surveyed executives at <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-and-cell-and-gene-therapy-how-to-keep-innovation-on-track">cell and gene therapy</a> companies about the effects of the pandemic; reviewed the challenges of securing digitally savvy talent at <a href="/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/call-to-action-how-a-and-d-companies-can-build-the-workforce-of-the-future">aerospace and defense</a> companies; calculated the significant impact of COVID-19 on <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/minelens-survey-confirms-the-significant-impact-of-covid-19-on-mining-operations">mining operations</a>; considered the prospects of <a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/reinventing-upstream-oil-and-gas-operations-after-the-covid-19-crisis">upstream oil and gas operations</a>; and surveyed <a href="/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/how-covid-19-and-market-changes-are-shaping-lng-buyer-preferences">liquefied natural gas</a> buyers on their changing preferences.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #18, August 13, 2020</h2>
<h4>As consumer needs change with the ups and downs of the pandemic, and companies look for signs of recovery, McKinsey continues to explore ways to approach the next normal from leadership and operational perspectives.</h4>
<p><strong>The abrupt halt of global travel</strong> during the COVID-19 crisis, aside from delaying personal trips and vacations, has had a major impact on businesses across sectors. Companies with workforces used to frequent travelalong with the airlines and hotels that depend on revenue from that travelhave been particularly affected. As companies continue to enforce travel restrictions and workers resort to virtual meetings, travel-industry players are looking to rebound from the crisis, but it may be a years-long road to recovery. <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/for-corporate-travel-a-long-recovery-ahead">Our latest research</a> shows that, historically, business travel rebounds from crises at a slower pace than leisure travel. As outbreaks in some regions stabilize and travel resumes, travel providers can work to accommodate changing needs and, in turn, boost customer confidence.</p>
<p>Our research this week explores how business operations may change as the travel industry and other sectors reimagine the next normal in a world of physical distancing and evolving consumer behaviors. For operationally intensive sectors, <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/building-the-vital-skills-for-the-future-of-work-in-operations">our analysis</a> suggests that the COVID-19 crisis has accelerated automation and digitization. Upskilling and reskilling the workforce will become even more of a priority. For <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/what-consumer-goods-sales-leaders-must-do-to-emerge-stronger-from-the-pandemic">consumer-goods leaders</a>, reshaping the sales function and fostering collaboration between retailers and manufacturers will be critical.</p>
<p>More broadly, our conversations with executives this week demonstrate that successfully weathering the pandemic will also require a people-centered approach to internal and remote leadership. <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/safeguarding-the-lifeblood-of-american-healthcare-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-amerisourcebergen">Our interview</a> with Steve Collis, CEO of AmerisourceBergen, considers how a daily executive meeting can be used not only for decision making but also as an opportunity to extend empathy to colleagues. Mike Henry, CEO of BHP, similarly <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/prioritize-people-in-times-of-crisis-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-bhp">tells us</a> that prioritizing people and building strong relationships has boosted the companys resilience. He says, Against the backdrop of COVID-19, theres a premium on getting out, demonstrating empathy, and engaging with people to understand what their concerns are.</p>
<p>This week we also analyzed how companies can mitigate risks in <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/reimagining-industrial-supply-chains">industrial supply chains</a> and utilize their <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-role-of-spend-analytics-in-the-next-normal">procurement functions and spend analytics</a> to bolster resilience; explored ways <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/a-holistic-approach-to-addressing-the-us-behavioral-health-crisis-in-the-face-of-the-global-covid-19-pandemic">behavioral-health leaders</a> can build on the current momentum for change in the industry; and looked at how Australia can gauge the scope of the pandemics effects on <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-next-normal-for-australian-industries-and-workforces">different industries and workforces</a> and address <a href="/featured-insights/asia-pacific/australias-next-normal-the-cautious-consumer">cautious consumers</a>.</p>
<p>Also this week: weve added a special collection, <em>The Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital.</em> This 172-page volume is the first of five edited collections produced to accompany <em>Our New Future</em>, a multimedia series we created with CNBC. You can download it <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves">here</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #17, August 6, 2020</h2>
<h4>Banks are using new techniques to find out whos swimming naked. And new MGI research looks at the cost of disruption in global  supply chains.</h4>
<p><strong>Millions of employees have lost their jobs</strong> and cannot pay their credit cards. Restaurants and shops are only slowly reopening; many cannot pay their rent. Industrial companies cant make payments on their equipment leases. Landlords have less income and cannot keep up with their mortgages. Suddenly, the world is awash in credit risk. Our new research shows how banks are tending to a radical surge in demand for one of their most ancient practices: <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/managing-and-monitoring-credit-risk-after-the-covid-19-pandemic">measuring and monitoring credit risk</a>. Leading banks are deploying a new configuration of sector analysis, borrower resilience, and high-frequency analytics. They are moving past sectoral analysis to take subsector views of the probability of default. Some are going even deeper, to understand whats happening in the financial life of their borrowers.</p>
<p>Like credit risk, supply chains have experienced intense disruption. This week, the McKinsey Global Institute <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains">looked</a> at the effects not only of COVID-19 but of all manner of disruptions, including natural disasters, geopolitical uncertainty, climate risk, cyberattacks, and more. A key finding: over the course of a decade, companies can expect disruptions to erase half a years worth of profits.</p>
<p>This week, McKinsey also had the privilege of speaking with three CEOs about what is shaping up to be the defining <a href="/featured-insights/leadership/the-ceo-moment-leadership-for-a-new-era">moment</a> in their careers. Alain Bejjani, CEO of Majid Al Futtaim, told us about the <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/stay-visible-but-dont-be-needed-how-alain-bejjani-is-leading-through-the-unexpected">resilience</a> needed to keep this Dubai-based operator of shopping malls and other consumer real-estate businesses vital and relevant during the crisis. Lance Fritz, CEO of Union Pacific Railroad, <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/rewriting-the-playbook-how-union-pacific-is-conducting-business-during-the-pandemic">talked</a> with us about tactics to stay present in video calls and keep the board informed. <p>Also this week: a new <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-advancing-asian-american-recovery">report</a> documents the disproportionate effect of the pandemic on Asian-American communities. And McKinseys industry research examined the potential for greater collaboration with government in <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/reimagining-the-9-trillion-tourism-economy-what-will-it-take">global tourism</a>, outlined the moves that <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-european-restaurants-for-the-next-normal">European restaurants</a> are taking to thrive in the next normal, considered how <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/rewriting-the-rules-digital-and-ai-powered-underwriting-in-life-insurance">life insurers</a> can use artificial intelligence to better underwrite risk, and reviewed the nascent <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-for-good-helping-the-united-kingdom-improve-lives-and-livelihoods">Tech for Good</a> movement in the United Kingdom.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #16, July 30, 2020</h2>
<h4>Our latest executive survey reveals a darkening outlook. But our review of vaccine research provides a ray of hope. This week, McKinsey covers the yin and yang of the pandemic.</h4>
<p><strong>In North America and in developing markets,</strong> executives have become less hopeful about their countries economies and more cautious in their views on potential scenarios for COVID-19 recovery. Thats a key finding from <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment">our latest poll</a> of more than 2,000 global executives. Leaders in China and India, on the other hand, are growing more upbeat.</p>
<p>One thing that will certainly improve expectations in every country is news of a safe and broadly available vaccine. Our latest <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world">research</a> looks at global vaccine development and finds that early data on safety and immunogenicity in Phase I and II trials are promising, though limited. Our review of historical attrition rates suggests that the current pipeline may yield more than seven approved products over the next few years, with some available for emergency use late this year or early in the next. A new interview with Microsofts chief technology officer explains how <a href="/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence/ai-in-healthcare-microsofts-kevin-scott-on-how-tech-can-treat-a-pandemic">artificial intelligence</a> is aiding vaccine development. After development, its on to production, where we argue that <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/why-tech-transfer-may-be-critical-to-beating-covid-19">tech transfer</a> may be critical to beating the disease.</p>
<p>Our new research on leadership in the crisis turned up several intriguing developments this week, starting with the idea of creating a to be list. Our <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/making-a-daily-to-be-list-how-a-hospital-system-ceo-is-navigating-the-coronavirus-crisis">interview</a> with the CEO of Cincinnati Childrens Hospital talks about how leaders can choose to be generous and genuine with some colleagues, and collaborative and catalytic with others. Leaders can also acquaint their teams with <a href="/featured-insights/leadership/and-now-win-the-peace-ten-lessons-from-history-for-the-next-normal">lessons from the past</a>. We looked at the postWorld War II era, when countries rebuilt from the ashes, to extrapolate ideas that are just as relevant now. Finally, we identified the ways that leaders can <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-long-haul-how-leaders-can-shift-mindsets-and-behaviors-to-reopen-safely">shift mindsets and behaviors</a> to reopen safely.</p>
<p>In the COVID-19 crisis, many companies are finding new leaders in unexpected places, well down the org chart. Some young middle managers are defying the problems and frustrations of this difficult period to achieve far more than others. Leading companies are capitalizing on this by installing <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/to-lead-in-the-postcrisis-tomorrow-put-leadership-and-capabilities-in-place-today">four talent-management practices</a> to thrive beyond the pandemic. These companies are also revisiting <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/hr-says-talent-is-crucial-for-performance-and-the-pandemic-proves-it">the playbook of chief HR officers</a>, to understand how the crisis has changed the game.</p>
<p>McKinseys industry-research teams were active this week, publishing new reports on the resiliency of <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banking-system-resilience-in-the-time-of-covid-19">national banking systems</a>; the future of <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/us-freight-after-covid-19-a-bumpy-road-to-the-next-normal">US freight and logistics</a>; the lessons of past crises for <a href="/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/lessons-from-the-past-informing-the-mining-industrys-trajectory-to-the-next-normal">mining companies</a>; the recovery of <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/ready-for-check-in-lessons-from-the-german-travel-recovery">Germanys travel industry</a>; and the next normal for <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/european-bancassurance-impact-of-covid-19-and-the-next-normal">European bancassurance</a>. Readers interested in banking should also see our <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-the-state-bank-of-india-is-learning-from-crisis">interview</a> with the chairman of the State Bank of India, Indias largest lender and the worlds largest digital bank. And bankers, retailers, and others should consult our must-see guide on how to <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/understanding-and-shaping-consumer-behavior-in-the-next-normal">understand and shape consumer behavior</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #15, July 23, 2020</h2>
<h4>Economic recovery depends on the return of the consumerbut shopping will never be the same. New McKinsey research considers the possibilities.</h4>
<p><em>McKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest <em><em><a href="/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf">briefing materials</a></em></em> (July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies keep pace sustainably.</em></p>
<p><strong>The ubiquitous face mask</strong> does more than protect against viral spread; it also changes the way we look at one anotherand thus symbolizes the mystery of customer behavior in the pandemic. Several new McKinsey research efforts analyze the changes taking place in the homes of consumers, on their phones, and in stores. <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/reimagining-marketing-in-the-next-normal">Reimagining marketing in the next normal</a>, for example, documents six of the biggest shifts emerging from COVID-19. One of the most intriguing is the rising importance of neighborhoods: with travel largely shut down, marketers must figure out how to localize their outreach.</p>
<p>Another momentous shift: customers care more about <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/survey-consumer-sentiment-on-sustainability-in-fashion">sustainability</a>: our survey finds that European consumers want fashion firms to act responsibly by considering their social and environmental impact. This survey is part of McKinseys comprehensive effort to document <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/global-surveys-of-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis">customer sentiment</a> across dozens of countries throughout the pandemic.</p>
<p>Both consumer-goods makers and retailers have everything at stake in understanding these shifts. For <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/how-cpg-companies-can-sustain-profitable-growth-in-the-next-normal">consumer companies</a>, the future is about three things: getting better at predicting demand, being alive to all the ways they might increase their sales, and using agile techniques to sustain the hard-won momentum. For <a href="/industries/retail/our-insights/the-next-normal-in-retail-charting-a-path-forward">retailers</a>particularly grocers, apparel companies, and restaurantsthe way forward starts with new ideas about revenue management (a fundamental rethink of products, pricing, and promotions might be in order) and about operating models (especially store footprints, which will depend on <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/reopening-cities-after-covid-19">how soon cities reopen</a>). Such operational issues are paramount in Africa and Asia; our latest <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/next-generation-operating-models-for-the-next-normal">research</a> collects useful innovations from those regions and around the world.</p>
<p>B2B customers too are changing, and their providers must adapt. Our latest <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/a-post-covid-19-commercial-recovery-strategy-for-b2b-companies">insights</a>, based on a detailed survey, suggest that B2B companies may be too focused on the here and now. In times like these, first movers do better than the competition by finding new pockets of growth and reshaping go-to-market approaches to serve them.</p>
<p>Chief executives can help their marketing chiefs meet these goals, and much more besides. As some of our most senior colleagues argue, this may be <a href="/featured-insights/leadership/the-ceo-moment-leadership-for-a-new-era">the CEO moment</a> of our times. Companies can reset themselves and their potential by embracing four shifts: unlocking bolder (10x) aspirations, making their to be lists just as important as their to do lists, fully embracing stakeholder capitalism, and harnessing the full power of CEO peer networks.</p>
<p>This week, McKinsey researchers also considered <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-unexpected-trip-the-future-of-mobility-in-india-beyond-covid-19">the future of mobility in India</a>, reviewed the changes underway in <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-private-banking-in-europe-preparing-for-accelerated-change">Europes private banks</a>, surveyed <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/physician-employment-the-path-forward-in-the-covid-19-era">physicians</a> about their employment prospects, looked at the reset that <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/resetting-supply-chains-for-the-next-normal">supply chains</a> need, and explored two hot topics in tech: how to get <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/three-actions-ceos-can-take-to-get-value-from-cloud-computing">value from cloud computing</a> and the <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/covid-19-crisis-shifts-cybersecurity-priorities-and-budgets">shifting priorities of cybersecurity</a>.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #14, July 16, 2020</h2>
<h4>As many countries struggle to control the pandemic, McKinsey remains tightly focused on the global healthcare response to it.</h4>
<p><em>McKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest <em><a href="/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf">briefing materials</a></em> (July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies keep pace sustainably.</em></p>
<p>This week, we reviewed the potential for <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/how-south-african-smes-can-survive-and-thrive-post-covid-19">South Africas small businesses</a> to survive during the pandemic and to thrive after it, considered the case for more M&A as <a href="/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/indias-post-covid-19-economic-recovery-the-m-and-a-imperative">corporate India</a> seeks to recover from the crisis, looked at the ways <a href="/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-shared-mobility-is-poised-to-make-a-comeback-after-the-crisis">shared mobility</a> might come back after it ends, offered recommendations on <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-post-covid-19-pricing-imperative-for-p-and-c-insurers">pricing for property and casualty insurers</a>, and pondered the future of <a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/beyond-covid-19-the-next-normal-for-packaging-design">packaging design</a> (including an <a href="/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/safety-and-service-in-the-packaging-industry-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-sealed-air">interview</a> with the CEO of Sealed Air).</p>
<p>But we focused mainly on healthcare systems. Testing is critical for containing COVID-19, yet many countries still struggle with shortages of the necessary materials. Our new <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-overcoming-supply-shortages-for-diagnostic-testing">article</a> looks at five parts of the testing process and examines the bottlenecks in each. Some US laboratories, for example, have reported unused capacity to conduct tests, even as patients and healthcare workers report difficulty securing them. Similar mismatches have arisen in the United Kingdom, and they are also showing up in supplies of reagents, test kits, and other consumables. To fix the problems, countries will have to make capacity more visible by establishing information <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/crisis-nerve-centers-supporting-governments-responses-to-coronavirus">nerve centers</a>.</p>
<p>Another focus of research is airborne transmission of the coronavirus. World Health Organization guidelines now state that it may be possible indoors, especially for people who spend significant amounts of time in crowded, poorly ventilated rooms. Our new <a href="/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/can-hvac-systems-help-prevent-transmission-of-covid-19">article</a> not only offers a primer on air purification, air filtration, and airflow management but also examines the steps that building managers, safety experts, and others might take to optimize airflows and ventilation indoors and to limit the spread of the virus.</p>
<p>This week also saw news about a successful vaccine trial. Thanks to that, the world may be able to look ahead to the pandemics end. But as a McKinsey team writes, <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/not-the-last-pandemic-investing-now-to-reimagine-public-health-systems">this is not the last pandemic</a>. To correct deficiencies in the surveillance of and response to infectious diseases, governments will have to make substantial investmentsbut they will be well worth the money. Our research outlines the shifts needed in healthcare systems.</p>
<p>Ara Darzi, director of the United Kingdoms Institute of Global Health Innovation, has similar aspirations: he is simultaneously focusing on new ideas that can help tame COVID-19 and on the longer term beyond it. In an <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/envisioning-healthcare-after-covid-19-an-interview-with-ara-darzi">interview</a> with McKinseys Rodney Zemmel, Lord Darzi explains how healthcare can transition from a sickness service to a health and well-being service. One critical step is to recognize that we have many pandemicsonly we dont call them pandemics. We have the pandemics of obesity, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes. McKinsey Global Institute covered the substantial upside of addressing these chronic conditions in a new <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity">report</a> published last week.</p>

<h2>COVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #13, July 9, 2020</h2>
<h4>As lockdowns lift, businesses are thinking about their next moves. McKinsey research offers insights into the near future.</h4>
<p><em>McKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest <a href="/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf">briefing materials</a> (July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies sustainably keep pace. You can also see the full <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis">collection </a>of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our <a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts">chart of the day</a>, a curated collection of our <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights">first 100 coronavirus articles</a>, our suite of tools to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat">images</a> that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.</em></p>
<p><strong>Around the world,</strong> economies are cautiously reopening. Businesses are keeping one eye firmly on the here and now but also tentatively looking ahead to whats shaping up as a great reset. Our new research this week offers several takes on this theme.</p>
<p>Start with the global pandemics front line: the healthcare sector. This week, the McKinsey Global Institute published a new <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity">report</a>, <em>Prioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity</em>, which measures the potential of proven interventions to reduce the global burden of disease. Taking advantage of them would not only alleviate a problem exposed by COVID-19people with diabetes, hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder, and obesity have been hit hardestbut also add, in <a href="/industries/healthcare/our-insights/how-prioritizing-health-could-help-rebuild-economies">our estimate</a>, $12 trillion to global GDP in 2040.</p>
<p>Reimagining the workforce is another pressing task. Executives everywhere wonder how to bring people back to the workplace and how they will do their jobs. Our new research takes a <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-workforce">look</a> at the challenges of creating a sense of belonging, common purpose, and shared identity when some people work in their homes and some in offices and factories. Another article considers the great resets tactical challenges, such as <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/a-dual-cybersecurity-mindset-for-the-next-normal">guarding against cyberattacks</a> on remote workers.</p>
<p>Small businesses confront some of these problems. But much as Ginger Rogers danced the same steps as Fred Astaireonly backward and wearing high heelssmall businesses must make the necessary changes at a greater relative cost and with less working capital. Our new research <a href="/industries/public-sector/our-insights/us-small-business-recovery-after-the-covid-19-crisis">examines the struggles</a> of US small businesses in three sectors (restaurants, manufacturing, and retailing) that could be facing a long, hard recovery.</p>
<p>Another sector thinking hard about its future is <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reimagining-infrastructure-in-the-united-states-how-to-build-better">infrastructure</a>. In the United States, two scenarios are possible: a boom spurred by a government stimulus or a bust as tax revenues and user fees dry up. Agencies and investors alike must prepare for both outcomes. One key to generating a rapid impact from infrastructure spending is to repair existing assets.</p>
<p>This week we also look at <a href="/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/global-freight-flows-after-covid-19-whats-next">global freight flows</a> (down 13 to 22 percent this year) and the varied potential for recovery, reviewed the implications of COVID-19 for <a href="/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/us-food-supply-chain-disruptions-and-implications-from-covid-19">the US food supply chain</a>, and considered the challenges of <a href="/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/pricing-through-the-pandemic-getting-ready-for-recovery">pricing</a> in a pandemic.</p>

<p><strong>McKinsey continues to track</strong> economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest <a href="/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf">briefing materials</a>. In 94 pages, we document the situation, show how countries and companies can transition toward the next normal, and offer planning advice across multiple horizons. You can also see the full <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis">collection of our coronavirus-related content</a>, visual insights from our <a href="/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts">chart of the day</a>, a curated collection of our <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights">first 100 coronavirus articles</a>, and our suite of tools to help leaders respond to the pandemic. <em>New this week:</em> a look at how our editors choose <a href="/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat">images</a> that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.</p>
<p>In a week when the global pandemic seemed to gather strength, our new research both shows the grim economic news and reveals a streak of optimism that many are starting to feel. Our monthly <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7baf8ce0fd-20c6-4a37-972c-f54e90309d87%7d%40en">global economic conditions snapshot</a> indicates that 52 percent of executives now say that their national economies are doing substantially worse, up from 10 percent in March 2020. Yet the proportion of executives who expect profits to rise within six months rose by four percentage points, and leaders in retail, high tech, and telecom are increasingly <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment">optimistic</a> about the return of customer demand. In June, many more executives around the world said that the economies of their home countries would soon be doing better than had said so in May.</p>
<p>Another new global <a href="/industries/financial-services/our-insights/a-global-view-of-financial-life-during-covid-19">survey</a> examined sentiment among people who make financial decisions for their households. Across the globe, they are reporting lower income, savings, and spending. In most countries, 20 to 60 percent of these decision makers say they fear for their own jobs. Roughly half have no more than four months of savings.</p>
<p>These grim statistics present a challenge for banks and other consumer-facing businesses, such as telecom companies, retailers, health systems, and utilities. A delicate balancing act <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/reimagining-customer-service-to-manage-delinquencies-after-covid-19">awaits</a> these organizations as they work to ensure that customers receive the necessary supportand that lenders can continue to cultivate relationships with their borrowerswhile preserving shareholder value in the longer term. A detailed perspective on <a href="/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/power-and-people-how-utilities-can-adapt-to-the-next-normal">utilities</a> considers this and other conundrums. So does a new look at <a href="/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/african-banking-after-the-crisis">African banks</a>.</p>
<p>The viruss spread is accelerating, but businesses everywhere are both coping with their urgent needs and looking ahead to the time when their employees can safely return to work. As that moment comes closerlet us hopethree new research efforts show, first, how leaders can <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/covid-19-and-the-employee-experience-how-leaders-can-seize-the-moment">seize the moment</a> to support their employees by building on the trust their early efforts have engendered and, second, how they can <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/communications-get-personal-how-leaders-can-engage-employees-during-a-return-to-work">engage</a> employees through clear and inspiring communication. And our <a href="/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/how-us-companies-are-planning-for-a-safe-return-to-the-workplace">survey</a> of US companies shows that same insistent streak of optimism: respondents expect most employees to be working onsite by December.</p>
<p>One lesson of the crisis is the need for speed: the pandemic obeys no speed limits, so businesses have had to adapt through quick fixes and workarounds. How can they keep these successful innovations going over the long term? Our new research suggests <a href="/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/ready-set-go-reinventing-the-organization-for-speed-in-the-post-covid-19-era">nine ways</a> to reinvent the organization for speed.</p>
<p>This week, we also looked at how companies can <a href="/capabilities/operations/our-insights/resetting-capital-spending-in-the-wake-of-covid-19">reset their capital spending</a>, demystified the role of <a href="/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/demystifying-modeling-how-quantitative-models-can-and-cant-explain-the-world">quantitative models</a>, and talked with two McKinsey experts about how to <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/choosing-the-right-path-to-unlock-the-economy">choose the right path</a> to unlock the economy.</p>
