There\u0026rsquo;s a lot of green between this particular ball and the pocket, but the news was most welcome. COVID-19 vaccines have been a focus of our research, as seen in our July 2020 \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world\"\u003eoverview\u003c/a\u003e, which includes a full discussion of the key issues of manufacturing and distribution, and subsequent articles on \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003ethe end of the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e, an \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/an-optimistic-scenario-for-the-us-response-to-covid-19\"\u003eoptimistic scenario\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for the pandemic response in the United States, and the \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/why-tech-transfer-may-be-critical-to-beating-covid-19\"\u003etechnology transfer\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that may be critical to beating the COVID-19 crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith the end in sight, or at least in fuzzy focus, companies are thinking ahead. A critical challenge for companies in the postcrisis era will be articulating clear, meaningful, and authentic purposes. Some companies seem to have \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/more-than-a-mission-statement-how-the-5ps-embed-purpose-to-deliver-value\"\u003ethe answer\u003c/a\u003e: they know their reasons for being, communicate them easily to customers, and enjoy the results. Our new framework can help others think through these knotty issues.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eGovernments have not lost sight of their purpose, but fulfilling it has become much more difficult. The gap between incoming and outgoing funds may reach \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/closing-the-30-trillion-gap-acting-now-to-manage-fiscal-deficits-during-and-beyond-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003e$30 trillion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;soon. Our latest research shows a particularly effective bridge for governments to consider: \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/using-public-real-estate-to-fuel-a-postpandemic-recovery\"\u003ereal estate\u003c/a\u003e. The public controls a vast amount of acreage, office space, and other assets, and governments can extract much more revenue from them without breaching the public trust. On a related note, as part of their purpose, many businesses will embrace sustainability; \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/sustainability/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-scaling-voluntary-carbon-markets-to-meet-the-climate-challenge\"\u003evoluntary carbon markets\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can help them reach their goals.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCost management may be the yin to purpose\u0026rsquo;s yang, but is no less essential. In our new survey of some 300 C-level executives, we look at the ways that the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reimagine-preparing-for-sga-in-the-next-normal\"\u003ecorporate center\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is evolving. Our latest observations find that many organizations are accelerating their cost-reduction targets, modifying their operating models on the fly, and redefining their functional priorities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur new regional research considers two large economies in Asia. China, the world\u0026rsquo;s growth engine for the past 25 years, has \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/china/china-still-the-worlds-growth-engine-after-covid-19\"\u003ecome back\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;in ways that may surprise you. Consumer behavior has changed, pockets of growth are shifting, and leadership and management practices are in flux; businesses that manufacture and sell in China must be alive to the changes. And in Australia, businesses would be wise to understand today\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/getting-acquainted-with-a-more-mindful-australian-consumer\"\u003emore mindful consumers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-podcast\"\u003ethe \u003cem\u003eMcKinsey Podcast\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;zeroed in this week on retail, where the talk was all about rapid revenue recovery. Say what? It\u0026rsquo;s true: winners are recognizing the shifts in consumer behavior, adjusting their offerings, and rebuilding their businesses. Successful companies have \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/rapid-revenue-recovery-after-the-crisis-strategies-for-success\"\u003efive traits\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in common.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking about the potential for successful vaccines to deliver the next normal. In the October edition of our \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003emonthly survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of more than 2,000 leaders around the world, fewer executives than in September say that better economic conditions are on the way. But the balance is still tilted toward a positive outlook, especially where profits and customer demand are concerned.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also asked respondents to vote on which of McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s nine pandemic scenarios is most likely. As of October, they are solidly in favor of scenario A1 (a muted recovery) but also see B2 (a prolonged and insufficient recovery) as a scenario to consider. Unsure about the terminology? In a new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/nine-scenarios-for-the-covid-19-economy\"\u003einteractive\u003c/a\u003e, we explain our scenarios, what executives are thinking, and how that thinking has changed over time.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor decades, McKinsey has \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-use-and-abuse-of-scenarios\"\u003eadvocated\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for the advantages of scenario planning while also recognizing the ways the approach can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/overcoming-obstacles-to-effective-scenario-planning\"\u003efall short\u003c/a\u003e. The pandemic has illustrated both sides of the equation. Enter a new approach: parametric analysis, in the form of an \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/overcoming-obstacles-to-effective-scenario-planning\"\u003euncertainty cube\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; Right now, the businesses facing the greatest uncertainty are limiting themselves to three or four macrolevel scenarios that provide general direction but not much detailed guidance. The uncertainty cube uses several macroeconomic and financing parameters to generate highly specific advice by which to steer such a business.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOperating models, too, have come under pressure at companies facing great uncertainty. What\u0026rsquo;s needed are \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/when-nothing-is-normal-managing-in-extreme-uncertainty\"\u003enew structures\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;designed to cope with the unprecedented conditions of 2020 and beyond. One way forward may be to embark, at last, on a true transformation. A new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/the-path-to-true-transformation\"\u003evideo\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;explains the logic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we were delighted to sit down with two executives cutting remarkable paths through the pandemic. Aneel Bhusri, co-CEO of Workday, \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/software-and-the-next-normal-a-talk-with-workdays-cofounder-and-co-ceo\"\u003ereveals\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;the secrets of life in the pandemic for the finance- and HR-software powerhouse. And Sir Mark Lowcock, under-secretary-general for humanitarian affairs at the United Nations, \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/tackling-the-impact-of-covid-19-a-talk-with-the-uns-sir-mark-lowcock\"\u003eexplains\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;the panoply of effects of the crisis on the United Nations and its missions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, McKinsey experts assessed the potential for \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/a-new-growth-formula-for-manufacturing-in-india\"\u003eIndia\u0026rsquo;s manufacturing sector\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to deliver much-needed growth and jobs; reviewed the impact of the pandemic on the \u003ca href=\"/industries/chemicals/our-insights/the-impact-of-covid-19-on-the-global-petrochemical-industry\"\u003eglobal petrochemical industry\u003c/a\u003e; and considered the moves that \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/beyond-covid-19-charting-the-road-to-recovery-for-south-african-insurers\"\u003eSouth Africa\u0026rsquo;s insurers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can make to thrive in the long term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, in the pandemic, many of us are spending more time at home with our families. Children are naturally curious about what parents do\u0026mdash;and it isn\u0026rsquo;t always easy to explain. At McKinsey, we took a crack at it and developed a new \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/mckinsey-for-kids/hungry-fish-baffled-farmers-and-what-happened-next\"\u003eexplainer\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for the younger crowd. Hint: it involves fishing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Start with the \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7ba0bc1c78-5546-4070-afc4-d4e908eca4ae%7d%40en\"\u003eMcKinsey Download Hub\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to find McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest research, perspectives, and insights on the management issues that matter most, from leading through the COVID-19 crisis to managing risk and digitizing operations. Also consider our special collection \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The Recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e. The first two installments\u0026mdash;a 172-page \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e on technology and data transformation, and a 130-page \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/transformation/our-insights/the-path-to-true-transformation\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the path to true transformation\u0026mdash;are available now. As the unrelenting COVID-19 pandemic rolls on, the future isn\u0026rsquo;t what it used to be, either. What used to be a simple idea now comes freighted with caveats, assumptions, and speculations. In the spirit of illumination, McKinsey researchers this week took a look at how things might develop in six sectors beyond the next few weeks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/reimagining-the-auto-industrys-future-its-now-or-never\"\u003eauto industry\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is one of the world\u0026rsquo;s largest and has been devastated by the pandemic: sales may drop by 20 to 30 percent in 2020, and we estimate that profits will fall by $100 billion. But automakers can respond. One example: software-subscription services, which enable people to pay for programs that unlock features from heated seating to full self-driving capabilities, allow dealerships to develop a better relationship with consumers while offering drivers additional flexibility and customization.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe US restaurant industry has given many iconic brands to the rest of the world. But today, the sector is in trouble. In our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/whats-ahead-for-us-restaurants\"\u003epodcast\u003c/a\u003e, we review the industry\u0026rsquo;s predicament, which we explored \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/how-restaurants-can-thrive-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eearlier\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in some \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/eating-out-side-restaurant-dining-in-the-next-normal\"\u003edepth\u003c/a\u003e, and assess the innovative solutions that companies are devising. Takeout and delivery are here to stay, and restaurants are working to make those experiences better. Menus also need a rethink. People don\u0026rsquo;t order sides, appetizers, and desserts as frequently when they\u0026rsquo;re ordering for delivery\u0026mdash;but as leaders know, those items are often the difference between profit and loss.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor banks, the pandemic has changed everything. Risk-management teams are running hard to catch up with cascades of credit risk, among other challenges. Down the line, we expect that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/a-fast-track-risk-management-transformation-to-counter-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eautomated underwriting\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will take hold for retail and small-business customers and will both reduce losses and save costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAsian insurers are looking at a more consolidated future. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/insurance-strategy-in-asia-using-programmatic-m-and-a-during-the-pandemic\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;argues that insurtechs\u0026rsquo; new, pandemic-oriented products and digital capabilities\u0026mdash;not least the ability to reach  millions of customers within a few months\u0026mdash;mean that a programmatic approach to M\u0026amp;A is  the surest strategy to overcome the industry\u0026rsquo;s structural weaknesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe recently hosted a panel \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/building-a-healthcare-ecosystem-in-india-a-conversation-with-shobana-kamineni\"\u003ediscussion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with Shobana Kamineni, executive vice chairperson of India\u0026rsquo;s Apollo Hospitals, to discuss the evolving nature of healthcare at scale. Apollo Hospitals comprises more than 7,000 physicians and 30,000 other healthcare professionals, and its app is downloaded about 30,000 times a day. Among the findings: public\u0026ndash;private partnerships are working well and have the potential to influence the future of healthcare.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, we consider five fundamental questions for \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/reimagining-higher-education-in-the-united-states\"\u003eUS higher education\u003c/a\u003e, as colleges fashion their pandemic response. Also this week: a new \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-european-small-and-medium-size-enterprises-how-they-are-weathering-the-storm\"\u003esurvey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of Europe\u0026rsquo;s small and medium-size businesses lays out the extent of the economic damage and owners\u0026rsquo; muted outlook.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Business leaders need to think through the implications.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the 1990s,\u003c/strong\u003e adherents of Francis Fukuyama came to believe in the \u0026ldquo;end of history.\u0026rdquo; The COVID-19 pandemic and a host of other factors\u0026mdash;such as climate change, cyberattacks, and terrorism\u0026mdash;have helped history stage a resounding comeback. Now, according to Richard Haass, president of the Council on Foreign Relations, the trick for businesses is to adjust and hope that history is just back for a visit and not for revenge. In a \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/leadership/james-manyika-speaks-with-richard-haass-about-businesses-as-global-entities\"\u003ediscussion\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with McKinsey senior partner and cochair of the McKinsey Global Institute (MGI) James Manyika, Haass speaks about the return of geopolitics to the top of the CEO agenda. Supply chains are another critical focus of the renewed attention, as covered in MGI\u0026rsquo;s new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and partner Susan Lund\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"https://www.economist.com/special-report/2020/10/08/changing-places\"\u003ecomments\u003c/a\u003e in the \u003cem\u003eEconomist\u003c/em\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey research has documented the disproportionate effects of the crisis on ethnic minorities, both in the \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-impacted-black-white-financial-inequality\"\u003eUnited States\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and elsewhere. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/problems-amid-progress-improving-lives-and-livelihoods-for-ethnic-minorities-in-the-united-kingdom\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the topic looks at the United Kingdom. Key findings: over the past two decades, every ethnic minority group has made progress, in both absolute terms and relative to the white majority, on a range of economic indicators. But the COVID-19 crisis threatens that progress; not only do all ethnic-minority groups have higher age-adjusted COVID-19-related death rates than white people do, but Bangladeshis and Pakistanis, in particular, are concentrated in occupations that have been hard hit by furloughs and layoffs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, our marketing experts zeroed in on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/these-eight-charts-show-how-covid-19-has-changed-b2b-sales-forever\"\u003eB2B businesses and how they sell\u003c/a\u003e. The classic approach is person to person; think of pharma\u0026rsquo;s armies of \u0026ldquo;detailers.\u0026rdquo; However, the COVID-19 pandemic has moved almost all sales online, often to self-service digital platforms. Everyone seems to be happier with the new arrangements. Some 70 percent of buyers say they prefer digital interactions; sellers like the greater effectiveness. Videoconferences and live chats are helping companies seal the deal; traditional phone calls are now a last resort.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week, our industry researchers examined the latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/what-can-other-countries-learn-from-chinas-travel-recovery-path\"\u003etravel data from China\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to understand what it might mean for tourism and business travel elsewhere. They also considered the new challenges for \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/reimagining-consumer-goods-innovation-for-the-next-normal\"\u003einnovation in consumer companies\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Here\u0026rsquo;s our explanation.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the middle of the deepest recession in memory,\u003c/strong\u003e stock markets are reaching new highs. Why the disconnect? To understand the conundrum, McKinsey experts point to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/wall-street-versus-main-street-why-the-disconnect\"\u003ethree factors\u003c/a\u003e. First, many investors still take a long-term perspective; they are looking ahead to the end of the pandemic. Another factor: five big-tech companies now make up 21 percent of the S\u0026amp;P 500, one of the world\u0026rsquo;s most-watched markets. And smaller, unlisted companies have absorbed a lot of the economic damage, such as the dramatic rise in unemployment. The overall stock market can do relatively well even when employment and GDP are severely depressed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eInvestors may also be focused on the vast differences in resilience at companies. We interviewed leaders at several UK companies that have done better than others during the crisis. What distinguishes them, in a word, is \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/agile-resilience-in-the-uk-lessons-from-covid-19-for-the-next-normal\"\u003eagility\u003c/a\u003e. From a common purpose to rapid decision making to empowered local teams, these companies found ways to respond quickly to COVID-19. A key finding: war-gaming for a no-deal Brexit built a solid foundation for supply-chain resilience.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/covid-19-and-supply-chain-recovery-planning-for-the-future\"\u003epodcast\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;this week examined those same supply-chain issues, in the context of McKinsey Global Institute\u0026rsquo;s August 2020 \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on risk and resilience. Experts Ed Barriball and Susan Lund explain the research finding that, on average, companies can expect a disruption to their production lines of one to two months\u0026mdash;a very long time\u0026mdash;every three-and-a-half to four years.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother podcast lays out the path forward for the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-path-forward-for-the-us-retail-industry\"\u003eUS retail industry\u003c/a\u003e; our experts explain what it means for the industry when so many categories are tilting toward online shopping. Short answers, from senior partner Becca Coggins: \u0026ldquo;we\u0026rsquo;re in the foothills of what omnichannel-driven convenience will look like\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;some big innovations will scale, now that consumer expectations have been reset.\u0026rdquo; In another report, we examined the same forces and their effect on \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/how-middle-east-and-africa-retailers-can-accelerate-e-commerce-imperatives-for-now-and-the-next-normal\"\u003eMiddle East and Africa retailers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week: McKinsey researchers examined the potential for \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/medtech-innovation-in-the-time-of-covid-19-resilience-and-growth-during-a-crisis\"\u003emedtech innovation\u003c/a\u003e, and a \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/insurance-productivity-2030-reimagining-the-insurer-for-the-future\"\u003emore productive future for insurers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Also consider our special collection \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The Recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, featuring a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections that accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #26, October 7, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAs the effects of the pandemic intensify gender inequality, further threaten the economy, and raise hurdles for the health industry, companies\u0026rsquo; actions now could see them through the crisis.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn the sixth year\u003c/strong\u003e of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/women-in-the-workplace-archive\"\u003eWomen in the Workplace\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;study, conducted in partnership with LeanIn.Org, we find that the effects of the COVID-19 crisis have exacerbated gender disparities and their implications for women at work, especially for mothers, female senior leaders, and Black women across America. In addition to being laid off and furloughed at higher rates than their male counterparts during the pandemic, women are\u0026mdash;notably, for the first time in our research on the topic\u0026mdash;considering downshifting their careers or leaving the workforce altogether at staggering rates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe exodus might include as many as two million women. That would raise a significant barrier to achieving gender parity in leadership roles in years to come. People are thinking about leaving the workforce for a variety of reasons. While many organizations are providing additional resources related to remote working and employee well-being, there is more to be done to meet employees\u0026rsquo; needs for sustainable, flexible, and empathic work environments, especially for parents and caregivers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMeanwhile, the global economic contractions resulting from the COVID-19 pandemic have far exceeded those of the Great Recession that ended in 2009 and have occurred at a much faster rate, hitting all sectors and many of the world\u0026rsquo;s largest employers. As companies plan for various outcomes in 2021, our research shows what companies seeking resilience can do today to achieve \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/the-emerging-resilients-achieving-escape-velocity\"\u003eescape velocity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rdquo; from the crisis by focusing on EBITDA[[footnote 1]] margins, revenue, and optionality.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn area where companies have already adjusted well is using technology to address changing work environments and to stay competitive. Our new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-covid-19-has-pushed-companies-over-the-technology-tipping-point-and-transformed-business-forever\"\u003eglobal survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that organizations that are successfully responding to the crisis have deployed more advanced technologies, digital products, and tech talent to speed up innovation\u0026mdash;and they expect most of these changes to outlast the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research this week sheds light on two important issues facing healthcare providers. First, similarities in flu and COVID-19 symptoms could lead to a threefold spike in demand for \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/winter-is-coming-whats-next-in-covid-19-testing\"\u003eCOVID-19 testing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as flu season in the Northern Hemisphere approaches. Maintaining sufficient capacity for testing and contact tracing will be critical in curbing further outbreaks and protecting high-risk groups. Second, the crisis has also led to a \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/cutting-through-the-covid-19-surgical-backlog\"\u003esurgical backlog\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for elective procedures because of lack of hospital capacity, workforce shortages, and new safety protocols. Health systems will need to optimize current clinical operations to address the discrepancies in supply and demand.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week we also explored how \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/how-european-marketing-and-sales-leaders-handle-covid-19s-effects\"\u003eEuropean marketing-and-sales leaders\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;are navigating the effects of the pandemic, the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/the-domino-effect-how-sales-leaders-are-reinventing-go-to-market-in-the-next-normal\"\u003edomino effect\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for improving sales returns on investment, disruption that is reshaping \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-next-normal-in-construction-material-distribution\"\u003econstruction-material distribution\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/covid-19-crisis-how-distributors-can-emerge-stronger-than-before\"\u003esteps that distributors can take\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to stabilize operations and outperform competitors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Consider our special collection \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The Recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, featuring a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections that accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Dana Sand, an assistant managing editor in the Atlanta office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #25, September 30, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eExecutives are more hopeful about the economy than they have been at any time so far during the COVID-19 crisis. Is an end to the pandemic at hand?\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eSix months\u003c/strong\u003e after WHO declared COVID-19 a global pandemic, the responses to our latest McKinsey Global Survey suggest \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003ea positive shift\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in economic sentiment. More than half of all executives surveyed say economic conditions in their own countries will be better six months from now, while 30 percent say they will worsen. That\u0026rsquo;s the smallest percentage of pessimists we\u0026rsquo;ve seen since the survey in April 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTaking a cue from those executives, our researchers delved deep into \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/an-optimistic-scenario-for-the-us-response-to-covid-19\"\u003ethe US situation\u003c/a\u003e, emerging with an understanding of what it will take to deliver an optimistic outcome. The case depends on the progress made to date\u0026mdash;and the potential for more. We\u0026rsquo;ve learned much about the natural history and epidemiology of COVID-19. We\u0026rsquo;re developing better diagnostics, including rapid point-of-care tests, a few of which can be completed in about 15 minutes. Case management has improved. And pharmaceutical companies have turned out a remarkably robust pipeline of vaccine and therapeutic candidates. Put it all together, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003ean end to the pandemic\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is potentially within range. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother new survey reveals the extent of the COVID-19 crisis\u0026rsquo;s\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/future-of-work/what-800-executives-envision-for-the-postpandemic-workforce\"\u003edisruption in working practices and behaviors\u003c/a\u003e. One-third of surveyed companies have accelerated the digitization of their supply chains, half have sped up the digitization of their customer channels, and two-thirds have moved faster to adopt artificial intelligence and automation. Many other workforce changes are also in progress. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eManagers need to process these changes and many others, and come to grips with \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/as-you-return-from-the-summer-break-can-you-lead-toward-a-covid-exit\"\u003ethe long-term strategic-planning agenda\u003c/a\u003e. The essential question: what is the right way to think about 2021 and beyond? Should companies unbatten the hatches, or is it too soon? \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor many families, it isn\u0026rsquo;t the workplace but the school that occupies the most attention. McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s latest look at education examines the variables that factor into \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/reopening-schools-fostering-a-safe-and-effective-learning-environment\"\u003edecisions to reopen schools\u003c/a\u003e. Also this week, McKinsey researchers focused on \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/moving-from-cash-preservation-to-cash-excellence-for-the-next-normal\"\u003ecash management through the crisis\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and on the problems of \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/zero-based-budgeting-for-health-plans-dealing-with-uncertainty-ahead\"\u003ebudgeting in healthcare systems\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Consider our special collection \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The Recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, featuring a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections that accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 articles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;related to the coronavirus, our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #24, September 23, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eA potential end to the pandemic, a bright outlook for electric vehicles, and more.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn our latest public-health research,\u003c/strong\u003e we \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/when-will-the-covid-19-pandemic-end\"\u003eassess the prospects\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for an end to the pandemic. Two standards must be met. In the United States and most other developed economies, \u003cem\u003eherd immunity\u003c/em\u003e is most likely to be achieved in the third or fourth quarter of 2021. Key variables are the arrival, efficacy, and coverage of vaccines; we anticipate four scenarios. A \u003cem\u003ereturn to normalcy\u003c/em\u003e might come sooner, possibly in the first or second quarter of 2021. Every day matters, for lives and livelihoods.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOn the economic front, the COVID-19 crisis presents the greatest challenge in a decade for the auto sector. Global sales of light vehicles in 2020 might decline 20 to 25 percent from prepandemic forecasts. In the hardest-hit countries, sales could fall by 45 percent. Electric vehicles (EVs) have not been spared. But our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/electric-mobility-after-the-crisis-why-an-auto-slowdown-wont-hurt-ev-demand\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that EV sales may come back quickly in the next couple of years, especially in Asia and Europe, for a few reasons.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe crisis has also set in motion a number of trends in mobility that will affect EVs, internal-combustion engines, and all the other ways that people get around. A second \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/five-covid-19-aftershocks-reshaping-mobilitys-future\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;considers five of these trends. One critical finding: as lives become hyperlocal, modes of transport will change. We expect a drastic decrease in private-car usage in some major European cities but only a slight decline in North America. Greater China will become even more reliant on public transit and rail as some drivers are coaxed out of their cars.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur private-equity research teams chipped in a comprehensive \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/a-rolling-disruption-covid-19s-implications-for-private-equity-and-portfolio-companies\"\u003elook\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;at the effects of the crisis on sectors, and what those mean for portfolio companies and firm strategy. Several analyses offer insights; one on debt-service coverage ratios finds that companies in industrial equipment and logistics are among the most vulnerable, along with real estate, travel, and retail. Telecom companies are better situated, as their business has been only mildly disrupted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week: McKinsey has long been committed to \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/how-advancing-womens-equality-can-add-12-trillion-to-global-growth\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;into gender equality. In 2015, UN signatories set an ambitious target of achieving gender equality and empowering women and girls everywhere. Five years on, we assess the scant progress to date, blunted by COVID-19, and offer \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/ten-things-to-know-about-gender-equality\"\u003eten things that everyone needs to know\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about gender equality.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, our researchers offer new views on the post-COVID-19 future of the \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/the-travel-industry-turned-upside-down-insights-analysis-and-actions-for-travel-executives\"\u003eglobal travel industry\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/graphic-paper-producers-boosting-resilience-amid-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003egraphic-paper producers\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/covid-19s-impact-on-the-global-gold-industry-implications-for-the-next-normal-and-beyond\"\u003ethe global gold industry\u003c/a\u003e. And, with disruption everywhere, people miss their old lives. That\u0026rsquo;s a problem for managers, who can take \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/your-organization-is-grieving-heres-how-you-can-help\"\u003ethree practical steps\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help people process their grief.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eExecutives everywhere are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Consider our special collection, \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, featuring a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections that accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and\u003c/em\u003e a look at how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #23, September 16, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eCompanies return to work after an unusual summer\u0026mdash;and grapple with an uncertain future.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhat now?\u003c/strong\u003e Over the past six months, business leaders have reorganized supply chains, set up remote operations, and made tough financial decisions. The world anxiously awaits an effective COVID-19 vaccine that can be readily distributed. Until then, the priority is to reenergize organizations\u0026mdash;to act rather than react. Even as the uncertainties of the COVID-19 crisis multiply, the goal must be to rebuild for the longer term. There are many ways to lead, but regardless of the type of business or geography, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/what-now-decisive-actions-to-emerge-stronger-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eten actions\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can form a path to emerge stronger from the crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe start with an idea\u0026mdash;that returning is a \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/return-a-new-muscle-not-just-a-plan\"\u003emuscle\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that needs to be exercised, not a plan to be executed once or a date to be achieved. We go on to more specific considerations, such as the need to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/ready-set-go-reinventing-the-organization-for-speed-in-the-post-covid-19-era\"\u003emake big moves fast\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and to be willing to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/a-blueprint-for-m-and-a-success\"\u003erethink entire portfolios\u003c/a\u003e, including \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-workforce\"\u003ewhere work gets done\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThose are four of the ten actions, and they make for a good starting point. But companies must adjust for the particulars of their industry. Healthcare companies might want to pay strict heed to \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-great-acceleration-in-healthcare-six-trends-to-heed\"\u003esix trends\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that are affecting their business. Most were under way before the crisis. But a crisis has a way of bringing things to a head: the coming months might be the best opportunity in memory for healthcare companies to pursue \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-era-of-exponential-improvement-in-healthcare\"\u003eexponential innovation\u003c/a\u003e, which could create an additional $400 billion in value by 2025. And now is the time to claim the hundreds of billions of dollars that could be saved through \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/the-productivity-imperative-for-healthcare-delivery-in-the-united-states\"\u003eproductivity gains\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s healthcare researchers also took a close look at the \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/improving-the-fragile-us-supply-of-blood\"\u003eUS blood supply\u003c/a\u003e, which was fragile before the pandemic and is now critical. Businesses have a big role to play in the solution. Blood donors frequently cite convenience and social pressure as prompts. Virtual campaigns for blood drives can help blood centers quickly reach large audiences and steer them to the locations most convenient for them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCFOs have a critical task too: for many, it\u0026rsquo;s budgeting season. Our new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/memo-to-the-cfo-a-new-approach-to-2021-budgeting-starts-now\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that the financial-planning process for 2021 presents an opportunity to turn hard-earned lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic into an enduring exercise in linking strategy to value. And leaders across organizations need to consider the problems of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-hidden-perils-of-unresolved-grief\"\u003eunresolved grief\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;another issue that the pandemic has dragged into the spotlight.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur industry research this week looked at \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/detour-an-altered-path-to-profit-for-european-fintechs\"\u003efintech\u003c/a\u003e, where the news is not altogether bad, though fintech companies may have to find a detour on the road to profitability. We also considered \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/a-new-prescription-for-m-and-a-in-pharma\"\u003eM\u0026amp;A in pharma\u003c/a\u003e, a long-running trend that should continue. Companies are advised to make sure that three capabilities\u0026mdash;competitive advantage, capacity, and conviction\u0026mdash;are up to snuff before pursuing COVID-19-era mergers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, the pandemic has forced a reckoning for many between the profit motive and a company\u0026rsquo;s social purpose. A team of McKinsey editors recaps how we got \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/corporate-purpose/from-there-to-here-50-years-of-thinking-on-the-social-responsibility-of-business\"\u003efrom there to here\u003c/a\u003e, and suggests where we might go next.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eAs summer turns to fall in the Northern Hemisphere, executives are thinking through the contours of the next normal. Consider our special collection, \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital,\u003cem\u003e\u0026nbsp;featuring a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections that accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #22, September 10, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eMcKinsey research focuses on the postpandemic future of developing Asia.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eNo nation has escaped\u003c/strong\u003e widespread disruption from the COVID-19 pandemic, but some have fared better than others. This week, McKinsey researchers examined the state of the recovery in some of the emerging Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) countries\u0026mdash;Indonesia, Malaysia, Philippines, Thailand, and Vietnam\u0026mdash;that began the crisis at a disadvantage and have suffered disproportionate effects. Our new \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/reimagining-emerging-asean-in-the-wake-of-covid-19\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;explores a series of trends that the pandemic has caused or accelerated. Within each is a seed of recovery, but stakeholders must be prepared to reimagine their country\u0026rsquo;s economy in five areas: manufacturing hubs, green infrastructure, investments in digital, talent reskilling, and high-value food industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe also looked in detail at developments in two ASEAN countries. In \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/with-effort-indonesia-can-emerge-from-the-covid-19-crisis-stronger\"\u003eIndonesia\u003c/a\u003e, the pandemic is still raging; case counts and fatalities are rising sharply. The first priority is to mitigate and contain the outbreak. But even amid the current hardship and profound uncertainty, Indonesia can reimagine and reform itself by increasing national resilience, accelerating economic transition, rebuilding the tourist sector, and enabling genuine change.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eVietnam, too, is contending with \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/emerging-from-the-pandemic-vietnam-must-position-itself-for-recovery\"\u003eshort-term challenges\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;as it emerges from the pandemic, especially in tourism and manufacturing, two of the country\u0026rsquo;s strengths. For the long haul, our new \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/what-will-it-take-to-achieve-vietnams-long-term-growth-aspirations\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;argues that one essential element of growth is renewable energy. As a country likely to be heavily affected by climate change, Vietnam could accelerate its journey toward a less carbon-intensive future.
