a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n[[Image 1]]\n\u003ca id=\"preventing-future-waves-of-covid-19\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003ePreventing future waves of COVID-19: Briefing note #21, August 31, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAfter seven months of responding to the pandemic, we have learned some things. Here are some of the key lessons and how to apply them.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBy Sarun Charumilind, Matt Craven, Jessica Lamb, and Matt Wilson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eWhen history books\u003c/strong\u003e one day recount the COVID-19 pandemic of 2020, it may well be a tale of human ingenuity and adaptiveness. Although the novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2), the virus that causes COVID-19, has infected more than 24 million people and left more than 800,000 dead as of this writing, the early projections of mortality were much worse.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFears of millions of deaths by June 2020 have proven wrong\u0026mdash;not because the disease is less lethal than anticipated, but because those fears ignored the ability of people to learn and change behaviors. Pockets of resistance against wearing masks and complying with other measures notwithstanding, the global public-health response has saved millions of lives. Increasingly, countries are restarting more aspects of normal life while keeping case numbers tenuously in check.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eYet the threat to lives and livelihoods persists. A COVID-19 vaccine may yet \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world\"\u003esave the world\u003c/a\u003e.\u0026rdquo; But even if one proves effective, it will be many months before we will have the capacity to vaccinate everyone\u0026mdash;and there are new concerns about reinfection.[[footnote 2]] Therapeutics such as dexamethasone and remdesivir appear to provide important benefits for those with severe cases but are not alone sufficient to stop deaths from COVID-19.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eNew therapies are possible but by no means guaranteed. Countries will very likely need to plan for almost another year during which public-health measures are their primary tools for saving lives. In the meantime, the world cannot be idle. Societies have been upended, causing unprecedented disruption to economies, education systems, and the day-to-day lives of people everywhere. And as we and others have argued, \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-saving-thousands-of-lives-and-trillions-in-livelihoods\"\u003esaving lives and opening societies is a false trade-off\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn that area, too, our ability to learn and adapt is proving dispositive. Countries that have successfully reduced their number of COVID-19 cases have generally been more successful at reopening their economies. For them, controlling the virus ultimately has come down to two things:\nunderstanding what to do and executing well. Both have been challenging at various points. For example, the evidence base for the population-wide use of masks only became compelling a few months into the pandemic response. In contrast, the importance of testing has been clear from the earliest days, but many countries have faced operational challenges in ramping up their capacity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile there is much more to learn, this article summarizes what response leaders have discovered so far about what to do and how to do it. Every jurisdiction is doing some of these things; none of them are new for experts in infectious diseases. But we have tried to describe specific considerations for practitioners looking to adopt and adapt best practices to their management of the COVID-19 pandemic. Given the outsize role that businesses are taking in the crisis response in numerous countries, many of the ideas are as relevant to private-sector leaders as to those in the public sector. Interventions are divided into three categories\u0026mdash;detecting disease, reducing the number of new cases, and limiting mortality\u0026mdash;and can be tailored for specific populations and settings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eDetecting disease\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe ability to detect cases of COVID-19 is a critical prerequisite for effective public-health programs. A comprehensive program might include traditional disease surveillance, cluster analysis to understand local patterns of transmission, and wastewater surveillance for early warning of disease hot spots.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eDisease surveillance\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn ability to collect, analyze, and interpret data is fundamental to the management of infectious diseases. While many people have grown familiar with epidemiological metrics such as test-positivity rates and case-fatality ratios, many countries and regions still rely on 20th-century surveillance systems. The biggest gaps are in data collection and integration: there is no shortage of data-crunching horsepower in the world, but everyone is forced to work from the same imperfect data sets. Even seven months into the COVID-19-pandemic response, there is a surprising level of disagreement about questions as basic as the true number of people who have been infected with SARS-CoV-2 and the number of deaths attributable to it. Continuing to expand testing, as described later in this article, is a big part of improving surveillance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe best surveillance systems seamlessly combine data from traditional sources with newer data sets, such as anonymized mobility tracking\u0026mdash;and do so in near real time. They provide a high level of detail and transparency around the characteristics and location of those infected while protecting individual privacy. And they improve over time as a design principle, incorporating new sources of data and improving quality to reduce friction in the response.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[PullQuote 2]]\n\u003ch4\u003eCluster analysis\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe medical community has learned much about how COVID-19 is passed from person to person and therefore how to prevent transmission. But there is more to learn about the specific nature of transmission in particular geographies. The examination of chains of infectious-disease transmission, or cluster analysis, helps medical professionals understand how, when, where, and between whom transmission occurs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLocally relevant information can focus public-health measures on steps that will make a difference and deemphasize those that won\u0026rsquo;t. A study of more than 3,000 cases across 61 clusters in Japan, for example, identified healthcare facilities and retirement centers as among the most important centers of transmission.[[footnote 3]] Similarly, clusters in the United Kingdom have been identified around retirement homes, in hospitals, and in meatpacking factories\u0026mdash;the latter also being a source of clusters in Germany.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCluster analysis has revealed the importance and characteristics of so-called superspreaders (infected individuals who pass the disease to many others). A deeper understanding of transmission dynamics may allow some regions to move from broad-based interventions to targeted ones. It can also allow for more nuanced risk assessments, for example, to determine who can safely access senior-care facilities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eWastewater surveillance\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn important advance in surveillance capabilities came with the discovery that SARS-CoV-2 is present in the stool of infected people and is detectable even in highly diluted samples, such as municipal wastewater. Wastewater sampling, used for decades to monitor for polio, appears to detect viral increases of COVID-19 up to six days earlier than diagnostic tests of individuals do.[[footnote 4]] While a number of locations, including Queensland in Australia, Ashkelon in Israel, and Boise in the United States,[[footnote 5]] are piloting or using this approach to monitor for COVID-19, wastewater remains an underutilized tool globally.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe wastewater-surveillance approach is most applicable in low-prevalence settings where an increase in cases is more noticeable and testing of individuals might otherwise be limited. Ideally, public-health leaders would have the ability to work upstream when increases in viral concentration are detected\u0026mdash;for example, from testing town sewers to determining which neighborhoods are the source of the virus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eReducing the number of new cases\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePreventing new cases of COVID-19 ultimately requires reducing the opportunity for infected individuals to pass the disease to others. That can be done by identifying and isolating those who have been infected or are at high risk, ensuring physical distance and airflow management, reducing the risk of the encounters that do happen, and reducing case migration from higher-prevalence areas.\nThe basic tool kit for the reduction of new cases is well understood by experts and nonexperts alike. It includes canceling mass events, restricting capacity in social settings (particularly indoors or with large numbers of people), implementing confinement measures, and restricting internal movement. Those measures can be reinforced through effective behavior-change communication and focused implementation for high-risk groups or specific geographies. And since COVID-19 vaccines are likely to be approved eventually, leaders may want to start now in preparing to deploy one effectively. In this section, we highlight some second-order or less appreciated lessons from the pandemic response so far.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIdentifying and isolating those infected\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWidespread, accurate, efficiently managed testing and contact-tracing programs allow countries to isolate those who have or are at high risk of contracting COVID-19. Testing and tracing have played major roles in the successful response to various phases of the pandemic in a number of countries, including Austria, Iceland, New Zealand, and South Korea.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDespite the apparent simplicity of testing and tracing, practitioners learned the hard way through early missteps. Among their many lessons are the following:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eCommunicate clearly with the public about the appropriate uses and limitations of different types of tests, including antigen, molecular, and antibody testing.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAddress supply-chain and logistical challenges to keep expanding testing access until most cases are being detected. Test-positivity rates above 5 percent suggest that too many cases are being missed.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMake use of pooled testing to boost capacity where needed, especially in low-prevalence settings. Combine testing for surveillance with testing for positive-case identification.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eAccelerate testing turnaround time by ensuring that those performing tests are compensated based on speed and accuracy, not just volume. Accelerate the application of test results by integrating data platforms for testing with those for contact tracing, shortening the time to quarantine.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eStaff enough personnel, as the core of contact-tracing programs is human-to-human conversation. Overinvest in community sensitization to the value of tracing and importance of contact quarantine. Digital contact-tracing tools with high adoption can also accelerate contact identification and shorten the time to quarantine.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eDon\u0026rsquo;t expect contact tracing to work perfectly initially; take a data-centric approach to improving operations and effectiveness over time.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eRecognize that isolating for ten to 14 days is onerous, especially for low-income individuals. Social services and options for out-of-home isolation, such as in converted hotels, can improve the effectiveness of quarantine and make it more tolerable.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eManaging risk in encounters between people\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCOVID-19 is spread primarily from person to person, including from those not showing symptoms, through the air (either on droplets or by truly being airborne). Close proximity and poor airflow increase the risk of transmission, while the use of facial coverings decreases it. Specific considerations for risk reduction vary depending on risk, context, and other conditions.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLimited evidence from US states suggests that mask mandates are correlated with greater reductions in new cases than mask recommendations are. Different masks offer varying levels of protection. N95 respirators fitted to users provide the greatest protection,[[footnote 7]] protecting both the wearer and those around them. Supply constraints, cost, and user comfort mean that universal N95 use is not practical in many settings. Three-layer surgical masks provide the next greatest protection. Goggles and other eye protection may provide incremental protection to the wearer relative to a mask alone.[[footnote 8]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFrequent hand washing and environmental cleaning reduce the transmission of COVID-19. However, the relative emphasis on environmental cleaning has decreased, as evidence suggests that transmission primarily occurs from person to person rather than via objects in the environment.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eReducing case migration\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAcross the world, countries are taking different approaches to restricting importation of COVID-19 cases. They range from complete bans on international travel to targeted bans on travel from locations with high caseloads to screening and quarantine requirements for arriving travelers. In some countries, including Australia and the United States, some of those measures also apply for travel within countries. In many cases, companies and other institutions are implementing their own policies beyond those required by governments. Measures that are based on consistent, easily understood criteria are more likely to maintain high levels of public buy-in and participation.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eChanging behaviors\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA successful response to the COVID-19 pandemic requires convincing large numbers of people to change their behaviors. Some countries have seen significant resistance to such changes, particularly those around physical-distancing measures and facial-covering mandates. A lack of trust in governments, information overload, and inconsistent messaging over time have all contributed to that opposition. Effective public-health communication can accelerate the adoption of new behaviors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEffective communication includes segmenting populations based on the combination of channels, influencers, and messages most likely to resonate with individual groups. While there are positive examples from the response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the public-health community could learn more from experts in targeting and tailoring political and consumer-marketing messages. The \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-long-haul-how-leaders-can-shift-mindsets-and-behaviors-to-reopen-safely\"\u003einfluence model\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can help. It suggests that people are most likely to change behaviors when four elements are in place:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eUnderstanding and conviction in what is being asked.\u003c/em\u003e \u0026ldquo;I believe that wearing a face mask will help protect me and my community from COVID-19.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReinforcement with formal mechanisms, which may include both \u0026lsquo;carrots\u0026rsquo; and \u0026lsquo;sticks.\u0026rsquo;\u003c/em\u003e \u0026ldquo;The grocery store has both a sign, which I can see as I approach, saying that masks are required and a greeter handing them out.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eConfidence and skill building in the new behavior.\u003c/em\u003e \u0026ldquo;I\u0026rsquo;ve worn a mask enough times that I\u0026rsquo;ve stopped worrying about looking silly.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRole modeling the new behavior.\u003c/em\u003e \u0026ldquo;The mayor of my town and almost everyone around me are wearing masks. Those not doing so look like the exceptions.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eApplying insights from the influence model to COVID-19-related communications is an area in which collaboration might help. Many jurisdictions are enlisting the help of partners, celebrities, and influencers to amplify their messages. For example, in the United States, basketball star Stephen Curry asked questions of infectious-disease expert Anthony Fauci live on Instagram. That served to bring evidence-based public-health information to audiences less likely to access official sources.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eProtecting vulnerable populations\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 pandemic has a \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/insights-on-racial-and-ethnic-health-inequity-in-the-context-of-covid-19\"\u003edisproportionate impact on a number of vulnerable populations\u003c/a\u003e. Such groups include people whose age or health puts them at increased risk and those at greater risk because of socioeconomic factors. Communities with severe housing problems, unemployment rates, incarceration rates, poverty levels, and food insecurity suffer 1.4 to 4.0 times as many COVID-19-related deaths as other communities. Vulnerable populations are less likely to have access to healthcare in most countries and are more likely to have underlying health conditions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to measuring and tracking the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on vulnerable populations, designing protective interventions requires identifying what makes those groups more vulnerable to infection. Approaches might include prioritizing access to testing, targeting communications, and providing additional support for quarantine and isolation. Interventions will likely need to be multipronged, since the most vulnerable communities are often vulnerable for multiple reasons. Furthermore, the stakeholders best positioned to implement interventions effectively will need resources, which would ideally be allocated proportionately to the outsize impact of COVID-19 infection on vulnerable communities.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003ePlanning for a vaccine\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt is reasonable to hope that Emergency Use Authorization (or its equivalent) \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world\"\u003emay be granted to one or more COVID-19-vaccine candidates\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;before the end of 2020.[[footnote 9]] While vaccines will be valuable new tools, their approval will bring a whole new set of questions for leaders.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePlanning now will increase the chance of a successful vaccine rollout. Those on point will need to monitor closely the technical characteristics of the most promising vaccine candidates. Such monitoring includes understanding the likely dosing regimen, potential efficacy, and side effects. From there, they will need to develop a clear, scenario-based strategy for prioritizing vaccine access, recognizing the range of potential vaccine outcomes and combinations available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery jurisdiction is likely to be vaccine-supply constrained in the short term, so agreeing on grounding principles in advance will make allocation decisions easier down the road. So will designing the end-to-end supply and delivery systems that will be needed. The plan should include systems for ensuring series completion in the case of a multidose vaccine and data systems for tracking those who have been vaccinated. It may include temporarily expanding the roles of medical practitioners\u0026mdash;for example, by allowing those with lower levels of qualification to administer vaccines, after training, in uncomplicated cases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, planners may need to overinvest in addressing vaccine hesitancy in areas where surveys suggest it is a significant concern. Communications around vaccines will be both challenging and important given the likely complexity of information around efficacy, safety, and dosing across multiple vaccine candidates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eLimiting mortality\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to limiting case numbers, reducing the mortality associated with COVID-19 is a key element of the fight against the disease. Clinicians and health-system leaders have learned much about both the specific clinical management of COVID-19 and how to prepare health systems to manage surges in cases while maintaining essential services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eHealth-system preparedness\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the early days of the COVID-19 pandemic, the world anxiously witnessed many countries\u0026rsquo; health systems strain under the exponential onslaught of cases. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/critical-care-capacity-the-number-to-watch-during-the-battle-of-covid-19\"\u003eCritical-care capacity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;was a bottleneck, given that one in five patients, initially, were dependent on ventilators. Healthcare supply chains, especially for personal protective equipment, were overwhelmed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eTo create surge capacity, health systems and consumers ceased elective care\u0026mdash;seemingly overnight. That resulted in an imbalance of capacity, with overloaded health systems in COVID-19 epicenters transformed into disaster-response hubs. In areas where the disease had not yet spread, care centers sat empty, waiting for an outbreak they were unsure would ever arrive.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe know now that health systems in any developed country should be able to anticipate, plan for, manage, and successfully navigate the pandemic adequately both for \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/understanding-and-managing-the-hidden-health-crisis-of-covid-19-in-europe\"\u003epatients with COVID-19 and for patients with other diseases\u003c/a\u003e. Some require focused action, especially surge capacity, supply availability, workforce readiness, clinical-operations processes, structure for COVID-19-case governance, and financial resiliency.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eUse of therapeutics and clinical management\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe search for effective therapies for COVID-19 has yielded two important advances, so far, but no breakthrough transformative enough to obviate the need to limit cases. Dexamethasone, an injected corticosteroid, was shown to reduce mortality by 35 percent in patients requiring mechanical ventilation and by 18 percent in those requiring oxygen only.[[footnote 11]] Remdesivir has been shown to reduce recovery time by an average of four days.[[footnote 12]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth drugs emerged from the medical community\u0026rsquo;s initial focus on repurposing drugs that were already approved or in late-stage development for the treatment of other diseases. The focus is now shifting to new R\u0026amp;D. In the months ahead, additional evidence may support therapies based on other antivirals and monoclonal antibodies. In addition to specific therapeutics for COVID-19, there have\nbeen advances in the nonpharmaceutical management of the disease. For example, there is some evidence to support the use of \u0026ldquo;proning\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;placing patients face down\u0026mdash;to reduce the need for mechanical ventilation.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePolicy makers can continue to keep a close eye on both the evidence for new therapeutics and the standards of clinical practice. Over time and with further advances, strong health systems may succeed in reducing COVID-19-related mortality to the point at which the disease is far less feared.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePublic-health measures to control the COVID-19 pandemic will be relevant for as long as its risk continues. Many countries and regions have risen to the challenge by combining multiple public-health measures that work for them, although almost all have some room to improve. As we consider what it will take to respond to current and future waves of COVID-19, we can take some comfort from the fact that far more is known about controlling SARS-CoV-2 than was understood seven months ago. It is up to all of us to learn, adapt, and apply those lessons effectively.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eDownload the \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/preventing future waves of covid 19/preventing-future-waves-of-covid-19.pdf\"\u003earticle\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(PDF\u0026ndash;435KB).\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAbout the authors\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/sarun-charumilind\"\u003eSarun Charumilind\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Philadelphia office, where \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/jessica-lamb\"\u003eJessica Lamb\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner; \u003cstrong\u003eMatt Craven\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Silicon Valley office; and \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/matt-wilson\"\u003eMatt Wilson\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe authors wish to thank Damien Bruce, Penny Dash, Pooja Kumar, and Taylor Ray for their contributions to this article.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Dennis Swinford, a senior editor in the Seattle office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ca id=\"Note20\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #20, August 27, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAmid one of the greatest bull markets ever for technology, semiconductor fabs must find ways to keep up. And all advanced-industry companies should organize for speed to sustain their current pace. \u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis week, McKinsey healthcare researchers\u003c/strong\u003e documented the \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-exposes-a-critical-shortage-of-oxygen-in-developing-countries\"\u003eshortage of medical oxygen\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in developing countries, a long-standing problem made worse by COVID-19. New ideas can help these regions meet short-term needs and set the foundation for a better long-term future.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur industry research focused on semiconductors and the industries that make and use advanced electronics. Chips control everything from toys and smartphones to laptops and thermostats. In the pandemic, demand has soared for many of these products\u0026mdash;even as \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains\"\u003esupply chains\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;have faltered and geopolitical tensions have risen. But will the boom last? Such questions have semiconductor companies thinking about their manufacturing plants. In a winner-take-all industry, even a slight edge in manufacturing can help a company capture an outsize portion of revenues. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/semiconductor-design-and-manufacturing-achieving-leading-edge-capabilities\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;outlines the essential ingredients of tomorrow\u0026rsquo;s successful fab.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChipmakers and other advanced manufacturers have been running hot for six months now, with some notable notches in their belts. One factory recently ran at more than 90 percent capacity with only about 40 percent of the typical workforce. But few leaders think the pace is sustainable. Our new report lays out what it will mean for companies to switch from running on adrenaline to making \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/organizing-for-speed-in-advanced-industries\"\u003eorganizational speed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;a permanent part of their cultures.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pace is unlikely to slacken soon. As our new \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-imperatives-for-automation-success\"\u003eglobal survey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggests, the appetite for automation has not dimmed. Instead, the factors for success are shifting. More and more, successful organizations are finding ways for people to work in concert with new technologies.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn fact, automation is among the key themes that can lift India to prosperity. That\u0026rsquo;s the conclusion of a new \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/india/indias-turning-point-an-economic-agenda-to-spur-growth-and-jobs\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;from McKinsey Global Institute published this week. The pandemic has sounded a clarion call for India to accelerate growth. Our analysis suggests that a program of targeted reforms, including greater productivity in several sectors, can help the country produce the 90 million nonfarm jobs it needs to create by 2030.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey researchers also examined cash management at \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/seeing-the-savings-toward-transparent-management-of-portfolio-companies\"\u003eprivately owned companies\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and reviewed lessons from the past for \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/lessons-for-us-governors-and-mayors-planning-a-second-term\"\u003eUS governors and mayors\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;planning a second term.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownload the \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003efull briefing materials\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDownload the \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 aug 27/covid-19-briefing-note-20-august-27-2020.pdf\"\u003earticle\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe are in the thick of August, the time of year when many people take a break, or at least slow down\u0026mdash;even in a pandemic. With that in mind, McKinsey broadened its \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/we-know-what-you-are-reading-this-summer\"\u003eannual summer reading list\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and asked 60 diverse leaders to share books that have inspired them, that have provided a much-needed respite, or that they look forward to reading. We hope you draw some inspiration from this list and find ways to restore yourself during these unusual times.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpeaking of reading, our special collection, \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, has a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections produced to accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; Our latest research builds on reports we published in \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/safeguarding-our-lives-and-our-livelihoods-the-imperative-of-our-time\"\u003eApril\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/crushing-coronavirus-uncertainty-the-big-unlock-for-our-economies\"\u003eMay\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;2020, and on recent academic findings that the stringency of national lockdowns is not well correlated with changes in GDP. In our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/covid-19-saving-thousands-of-lives-and-trillions-in-livelihoods\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e, we find that successful control of the virus is the key to unlocking the economy, by restoring the confidence consumers need to reengage in economic activity. In countries that have successfully controlled the coronavirus (\u0026ldquo;near zero\u0026rdquo; countries), economic activity (in the form of discretionary mobility) has returned to normal; in those that have not (\u0026ldquo;balancing act\u0026rdquo;), it is still about 40 percent lower than before the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIt seems that controlling the virus can get countries back to where they were at the start of the year. But where do we go from there? A companion \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-economic-future\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;outlines the future of economic growth in the United States, by looking back at what worked well in the years after the 2008\u0026ndash;09 recession. Federal, state, and local governments can take a range of actions to both improve productivity and stimulate demand. Among the most powerful is investment in inclusive growth  and unlocking the maximum productive potential of all people in communities. For example, achieving \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/employment-and-growth/the-power-of-parity-advancing-womens-equality-in-the-united-states\"\u003egender equality\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;could add $4 trillion to the US economy, and closing the \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-economic-impact-of-closing-the-racial-wealth-gap\"\u003eBlack\u0026ndash;white wealth gap\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;could add a further $1.5 trillion.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBusinesses, too, are eager to boost productivity and demand. Consumer companies may feel these needs more acutely than most, as two reports published this week demonstrate. McKinsey experts outlined the \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/consumer-organization-and-operating-models-bold-moves-for-the-next-normal\"\u003efive bold moves\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that consumer companies should make to adapt their organizations to the exigencies of the crisis. Another requirement is to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/meet-the-next-normal-consumer\"\u003emeet the next-normal consumer\u003c/a\u003e. Seemingly every consumer behavior has been altered by the crisis; companies need to adapt to big changes in how people get their information, what and where they buy, and how they experience shopping.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we also surveyed executives at \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-and-cell-and-gene-therapy-how-to-keep-innovation-on-track\"\u003ecell and gene therapy\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;companies about the effects of the pandemic; reviewed the challenges of securing digitally savvy talent at \u003ca href=\"/industries/aerospace-and-defense/our-insights/call-to-action-how-a-and-d-companies-can-build-the-workforce-of-the-future\"\u003eaerospace and defense\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;companies; calculated the significant impact of COVID-19 on \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/minelens-survey-confirms-the-significant-impact-of-covid-19-on-mining-operations\"\u003emining operations\u003c/a\u003e; considered the prospects of \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/reinventing-upstream-oil-and-gas-operations-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eupstream oil and gas operations\u003c/a\u003e; and surveyed \u003ca href=\"/industries/oil-and-gas/our-insights/how-covid-19-and-market-changes-are-shaping-lng-buyer-preferences\"\u003eliquefied natural gas\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;buyers on their changing preferences.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe are in the thick of August, the time of year when many people take a break, or at least slow down\u0026mdash;even in a pandemic. With that in mind, McKinsey broadened its \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/we-know-what-you-are-reading-this-summer\"\u003eannual summer reading list\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and asked 60 diverse leaders to share books that have inspired them, that have provided a much-needed respite, or that they look forward to reading. We hope you draw some inspiration from this list and find ways to restore yourself during these unusual times.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSpeaking of reading, our special collection, \u003c/em\u003eThe Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital\u003cem\u003e, has a 172-page curated volume that you can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003edownload\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;the first of five edited collections produced to accompany \u003c/em\u003eOur New Future\u003cem\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003esuite of tools\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #18, August 13, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAs consumer needs change with the ups and downs of the pandemic, and companies look for signs of recovery, McKinsey continues to explore ways to approach the next normal from leadership and operational perspectives.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe abrupt halt of global travel\u003c/strong\u003e during the COVID-19 crisis, aside from delaying personal trips and vacations, has had a major impact on businesses across sectors. Companies with workforces used to frequent travel\u0026mdash;along with the airlines and hotels that depend on revenue from that travel\u0026mdash;have been particularly affected. As companies continue to enforce travel restrictions and workers resort to virtual meetings, travel-industry players are looking to rebound from the crisis, but it may be a years-long road to recovery. \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/for-corporate-travel-a-long-recovery-ahead\"\u003eOur latest research\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;shows that, historically, business travel rebounds from crises at a slower pace than leisure travel. As outbreaks in some regions stabilize and travel resumes, travel providers can work to accommodate changing needs and, in turn, boost customer confidence.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur research this week explores how business operations may change as the travel industry and other sectors reimagine the next normal in a world of physical distancing and evolving consumer behaviors. For operationally intensive sectors, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/building-the-vital-skills-for-the-future-of-work-in-operations\"\u003eour analysis\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggests that the COVID-19 crisis has accelerated automation and digitization. Upskilling and reskilling the workforce will become even more of a priority. For \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/what-consumer-goods-sales-leaders-must-do-to-emerge-stronger-from-the-pandemic\"\u003econsumer-goods leaders\u003c/a\u003e, reshaping the sales function and fostering collaboration between retailers and manufacturers will be critical.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMore broadly, our conversations with executives this week demonstrate that successfully weathering the pandemic will also require a people-centered approach to internal and remote leadership. \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/safeguarding-the-lifeblood-of-american-healthcare-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-amerisourcebergen\"\u003eOur interview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with Steve Collis, CEO of AmerisourceBergen, considers how a daily executive meeting can be used not only for decision making but also as an opportunity to extend empathy to colleagues. Mike Henry, CEO of BHP, similarly \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/prioritize-people-in-times-of-crisis-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-bhp\"\u003etells us\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that prioritizing people and building strong relationships has boosted the company\u0026rsquo;s resilience. He says, \u0026ldquo;Against the backdrop of COVID-19, there\u0026rsquo;s a premium on getting out, demonstrating empathy, and engaging with people to understand what their concerns are.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week we also analyzed how companies can mitigate risks in \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/reimagining-industrial-supply-chains\"\u003eindustrial supply chains\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and utilize their \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/the-role-of-spend-analytics-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eprocurement functions and spend analytics\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to bolster resilience; explored ways \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/a-holistic-approach-to-addressing-the-us-behavioral-health-crisis-in-the-face-of-the-global-covid-19-pandemic\"\u003ebehavioral-health leaders\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can build on the current momentum for change in the industry; and looked at how Australia can gauge the scope of the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s effects on \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-next-normal-for-australian-industries-and-workforces\"\u003edifferent industries and workforces\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and address \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/australias-next-normal-the-cautious-consumer\"\u003ecautious consumers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week: we\u0026rsquo;ve added a special collection, \u003cem\u003eThe Next Normal: The recovery Will Be Digital.\u003c/em\u003e This 172-page volume is the first of five edited collections produced to accompany \u003cem\u003eOur New Future\u003c/em\u003e, a multimedia series we created with CNBC. You can download it \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/how-six-companies-are-using-technology-and-data-to-transform-themselves\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe\u0026rsquo;ve now reached August, the time of year when many people take a break, or at least slow down\u0026mdash;even in a pandemic. With that in mind, McKinsey broadened its \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/we-know-what-you-are-reading-this-summer\"\u003eannual summer reading list\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and asked 60 diverse leaders to share books that have inspired them, that have provided a much-needed respite, or that they look forward to reading. We hope you draw some inspiration from this list and find ways to restore yourself during these unusual times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003esuite of tools\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe continue to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;(July 6, 2020). In 54 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies keep pace sustainably.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Dana Sand, an assistant managing editor in the Atlanta office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #17, August 6, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eBanks are using new techniques to find out who\u0026rsquo;s \u0026lsquo;swimming naked.\u0026rsquo; And new MGI research looks at the cost of disruption in global  supply chains.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMillions of employees have lost their jobs\u003c/strong\u003e and cannot pay their credit cards. Restaurants and shops are only slowly reopening; many cannot pay their rent. Industrial companies can\u0026rsquo;t make payments on their equipment leases. Landlords have less income and cannot keep up with their mortgages. Suddenly, the world is awash in credit risk. Our new research shows how banks are tending to a radical surge in demand for one of their most ancient practices: \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/managing-and-monitoring-credit-risk-after-the-covid-19-pandemic\"\u003emeasuring and monitoring credit risk\u003c/a\u003e. Leading banks are deploying a new configuration of sector analysis, borrower resilience, and high-frequency analytics. They are moving past sectoral analysis to take subsector views of the probability of default. Some are going even deeper, to understand what\u0026rsquo;s happening in the financial life of their borrowers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike credit risk, supply chains have experienced intense disruption. This week, the McKinsey Global Institute \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/risk-resilience-and-rebalancing-in-global-value-chains\"\u003elooked\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;at the effects not only of COVID-19 but of all manner of disruptions, including natural disasters, geopolitical uncertainty, climate risk, cyberattacks, and more. A key finding: over the course of a decade, companies can expect disruptions to erase half a year\u0026rsquo;s worth of profits.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey also had the privilege of speaking with three CEOs about what is shaping up to be the defining \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/leadership/the-ceo-moment-leadership-for-a-new-era\"\u003emoment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in their careers. Alain Bejjani, CEO of Majid Al Futtaim, told us about the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/stay-visible-but-dont-be-needed-how-alain-bejjani-is-leading-through-the-unexpected\"\u003eresilience\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;needed to keep this Dubai-based operator of shopping malls and other consumer real-estate businesses vital and relevant during the crisis. Lance Fritz, CEO of Union Pacific Railroad, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/rewriting-the-playbook-how-union-pacific-is-conducting-business-during-the-pandemic\"\u003etalked\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with us about tactics to stay present in video calls and keep the board informed. Kristin Peck, the brand-new CEO of animal-health company Zoetis, reflected on the \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/how-zoetiss-new-ceo-reset-priorities-and-empowered-employees-during-the-pandemic\"\u003ecore beliefs\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that have kept her company on track through the crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso this week: a new \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19-and-advancing-asian-american-recovery\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;documents the disproportionate effect of the pandemic on Asian-American communities. And McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s industry research examined the potential for greater collaboration with government in \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/reimagining-the-9-trillion-tourism-economy-what-will-it-take\"\u003eglobal tourism\u003c/a\u003e, outlined the moves that \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/reimagining-european-restaurants-for-the-next-normal\"\u003eEuropean restaurants\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;are taking to thrive in the next normal, considered how \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/rewriting-the-rules-digital-and-ai-powered-underwriting-in-life-insurance\"\u003elife insurers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;can use artificial intelligence to better underwrite risk, and reviewed the nascent \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/tech-for-good-helping-the-united-kingdom-improve-lives-and-livelihoods\"\u003eTech for Good\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;movement in the United Kingdom.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;(July 6, 2020). But our review of vaccine research provides a ray of hope. This week, McKinsey covers the yin and yang of the pandemic.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn North America and in developing markets,\u003c/strong\u003e executives have become less hopeful about their countries\u0026rsquo; economies and more cautious in their views on potential scenarios for COVID-19 recovery. That\u0026rsquo;s a key finding from \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003eour latest poll\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of more than 2,000 global executives. Leaders in China and India, on the other hand, are growing more upbeat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne thing that will certainly improve expectations in every country is news of a safe and broadly available vaccine. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/on-pins-and-needles-will-covid-19-vaccines-save-the-world\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;looks at global vaccine development and finds that early data on safety and immunogenicity in Phase I and II trials are promising, though limited. Our review of historical attrition rates suggests that the current pipeline may yield more than seven approved products over the next few years, with some available for emergency use late this year or early in the next. A new interview with Microsoft\u0026rsquo;s chief technology officer explains how \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/artificial-intelligence/ai-in-healthcare-microsofts-kevin-scott-on-how-tech-can-treat-a-pandemic\"\u003eartificial intelligence\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is aiding vaccine development. After development, it\u0026rsquo;s on to production, where we argue that \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/why-tech-transfer-may-be-critical-to-beating-covid-19\"\u003etech transfer\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;may be critical to beating the disease.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur new research on leadership in the crisis turned up several intriguing developments this week, starting with the idea of creating a \u0026ldquo;to be\u0026rdquo; list. Our \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/making-a-daily-to-be-list-how-a-hospital-system-ceo-is-navigating-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with the CEO of Cincinnati Children\u0026rsquo;s Hospital talks about how leaders can choose to be generous and genuine with some colleagues, and collaborative and catalytic with others. Leaders can also acquaint their teams with \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/leadership/and-now-win-the-peace-ten-lessons-from-history-for-the-next-normal\"\u003elessons from the past\u003c/a\u003e. We looked at the post\u0026ndash;World War II era, when countries rebuilt from the ashes, to extrapolate ideas that are just as relevant now. Finally, we identified the ways that leaders can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/the-long-haul-how-leaders-can-shift-mindsets-and-behaviors-to-reopen-safely\"\u003eshift mindsets and behaviors\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to reopen safely.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the COVID-19 crisis, many companies are finding new leaders in unexpected places, well down the org chart. Some young middle managers are defying the problems and frustrations of this difficult period to achieve far more than others. Leading companies are capitalizing on this by installing \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/to-lead-in-the-postcrisis-tomorrow-put-leadership-and-capabilities-in-place-today\"\u003efour talent-management practices\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to thrive beyond the pandemic. These companies are also revisiting \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/hr-says-talent-is-crucial-for-performance-and-the-pandemic-proves-it\"\u003ethe playbook of chief HR officers\u003c/a\u003e, to understand how the crisis has changed the game.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey\u0026rsquo;s industry-research teams were active this week, publishing new reports on the resiliency of \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/banking-system-resilience-in-the-time-of-covid-19\"\u003enational banking systems\u003c/a\u003e; the future of \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/us-freight-after-covid-19-a-bumpy-road-to-the-next-normal\"\u003eUS freight and logistics\u003c/a\u003e; the lessons of past crises for \u003ca href=\"/industries/metals-and-mining/our-insights/lessons-from-the-past-informing-the-mining-industrys-trajectory-to-the-next-normal\"\u003emining companies\u003c/a\u003e; the recovery of \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/ready-for-check-in-lessons-from-the-german-travel-recovery\"\u003eGermany\u0026rsquo;s travel industry\u003c/a\u003e; and the next normal for \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/european-bancassurance-impact-of-covid-19-and-the-next-normal\"\u003eEuropean bancassurance\u003c/a\u003e. Readers interested in banking should also see our \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-the-state-bank-of-india-is-learning-from-crisis\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with the chairman of the State Bank of India, India\u0026rsquo;s largest lender and the world\u0026rsquo;s largest digital bank. New McKinsey research considers the possibilities.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;(July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies keep pace sustainably.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe ubiquitous face mask\u003c/strong\u003e does more than protect against viral spread; it also changes the way we look at one another\u0026mdash;and thus symbolizes the mystery of customer behavior in the pandemic. Several new McKinsey research efforts analyze the changes taking place in the homes of consumers, on their phones, and in stores. \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/reimagining-marketing-in-the-next-normal\"\u003eReimagining marketing in the next normal\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; for example, documents six of the biggest shifts emerging from COVID-19. One of the most intriguing is the rising importance of neighborhoods: with travel largely shut down, marketers must figure out how to localize their outreach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother momentous shift: customers care more about \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/survey-consumer-sentiment-on-sustainability-in-fashion\"\u003esustainability\u003c/a\u003e: our survey finds that European consumers want fashion firms to act responsibly by considering their social and environmental impact. This survey is part of McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s comprehensive effort to document \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/global-surveys-of-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003ecustomer sentiment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;across dozens of countries throughout the pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBoth consumer-goods makers and retailers have everything at stake in understanding these shifts. For \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/how-cpg-companies-can-sustain-profitable-growth-in-the-next-normal\"\u003econsumer companies\u003c/a\u003e, the future is about three things: getting better at predicting demand, being alive to all the ways they might increase their sales, and using agile techniques to sustain the hard-won momentum. For \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/the-next-normal-in-retail-charting-a-path-forward\"\u003eretailers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026mdash;particularly grocers, apparel companies, and restaurants\u0026mdash;the way forward starts with new ideas about revenue management (a fundamental rethink of products, pricing, and promotions might be in order) and about operating models (especially store footprints, which will depend on \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/reopening-cities-after-covid-19\"\u003ehow soon cities reopen\u003c/a\u003e). Such operational issues are paramount in Africa and Asia; our latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/next-generation-operating-models-for-the-next-normal\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;collects useful innovations from those regions and around the world.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eB2B customers too are changing, and their providers must adapt. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/a-post-covid-19-commercial-recovery-strategy-for-b2b-companies\"\u003einsights\u003c/a\u003e, based on a detailed survey, suggest that B2B companies may be too focused on the here and now. In times like these, first movers do better than the competition by finding new pockets of growth and reshaping go-to-market approaches to serve them.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eChief executives can help their marketing chiefs meet these goals, and much more besides. As some of our most senior colleagues argue, this may be \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/leadership/the-ceo-moment-leadership-for-a-new-era\"\u003ethe CEO moment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our times. Companies can reset themselves and their potential by embracing four shifts: unlocking bolder (\u0026ldquo;10x\u0026rdquo;) aspirations, making their \u0026ldquo;to be\u0026rdquo; lists just as important as their \u0026ldquo;to do\u0026rdquo; lists, fully embracing stakeholder capitalism, and harnessing the full power of CEO peer networks.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey researchers also considered \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/the-unexpected-trip-the-future-of-mobility-in-india-beyond-covid-19\"\u003ethe future of mobility in India\u003c/a\u003e, reviewed the changes underway in \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-future-of-private-banking-in-europe-preparing-for-accelerated-change\"\u003eEurope\u0026rsquo;s private banks\u003c/a\u003e, surveyed \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/physician-employment-the-path-forward-in-the-covid-19-era\"\u003ephysicians\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about their employment prospects, looked at the reset that \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/resetting-supply-chains-for-the-next-normal\"\u003esupply chains\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;need, and explored two hot topics in tech: how to get \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/three-actions-ceos-can-take-to-get-value-from-cloud-computing\"\u003evalue from cloud computing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/covid-19-crisis-shifts-cybersecurity-priorities-and-budgets\"\u003eshifting priorities of cybersecurity\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, our\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003esuite of tools\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose\u0026nbsp;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u0026nbsp;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #14, July 16, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAs many countries struggle to control the pandemic, McKinsey remains tightly focused on the global healthcare response to it.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;(July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies keep pace sustainably.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we reviewed the potential for \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/how-south-african-smes-can-survive-and-thrive-post-covid-19\"\u003eSouth Africa\u0026rsquo;s small businesses\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to survive during the pandemic and to thrive after it, considered the case for more M\u0026amp;A as \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/m-and-a/our-insights/indias-post-covid-19-economic-recovery-the-m-and-a-imperative\"\u003ecorporate India\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;seeks to recover from the crisis, looked at the ways \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/why-shared-mobility-is-poised-to-make-a-comeback-after-the-crisis\"\u003eshared mobility\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;might come back after it ends, offered recommendations on \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/the-post-covid-19-pricing-imperative-for-p-and-c-insurers\"\u003epricing for property and casualty insurers\u003c/a\u003e, and pondered the future of \u003ca href=\"/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/beyond-covid-19-the-next-normal-for-packaging-design\"\u003epackaging design\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(including an \u003ca href=\"/industries/packaging-and-paper/our-insights/safety-and-service-in-the-packaging-industry-an-interview-with-the-ceo-of-sealed-air\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with the CEO of Sealed Air).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eBut we focused mainly on healthcare systems. Testing is critical for containing COVID-19, yet many countries still struggle with shortages of the necessary materials. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/covid-19-overcoming-supply-shortages-for-diagnostic-testing\"\u003earticle\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;looks at five parts of the testing process and examines the bottlenecks in each. Some US laboratories, for example, have reported unused capacity to conduct tests, even as patients and healthcare workers report difficulty securing them. Similar mismatches have arisen in the United Kingdom, and they are also showing up in supplies of reagents, test kits, and other consumables. To fix the problems, countries will have to make capacity more visible by establishing information \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/crisis-nerve-centers-supporting-governments-responses-to-coronavirus\"\u003enerve centers\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother focus of research is airborne transmission of the coronavirus. World Health Organization guidelines now state that it may be possible indoors, especially for people who spend significant amounts of time in crowded, poorly ventilated rooms. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/can-hvac-systems-help-prevent-transmission-of-covid-19\"\u003earticle\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;not only offers a primer on air purification, air filtration, and airflow management but also examines the steps that building managers, safety experts, and others might take to optimize airflows and ventilation indoors and to limit the spread of the virus.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week also saw news about a successful vaccine trial. Thanks to that, the world may be able to look ahead to the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s end. But as a McKinsey team writes, \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/not-the-last-pandemic-investing-now-to-reimagine-public-health-systems\"\u003ethis is not the last pandemic\u003c/a\u003e. To correct deficiencies in the surveillance of and response to infectious diseases, governments will have to make substantial investments\u0026mdash;but they will be well worth the money. Our research outlines the shifts needed in healthcare systems.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAra Darzi, director of the United Kingdom\u0026rsquo;s Institute of Global Health Innovation, has similar aspirations: he is simultaneously focusing on new ideas that can help tame COVID-19 and on the longer term beyond it. In an \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/envisioning-healthcare-after-covid-19-an-interview-with-ara-darzi\"\u003einterview\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Rodney Zemmel, Lord Darzi explains how healthcare can transition from a \u0026ldquo;sickness service\u0026rdquo; to a \u0026ldquo;health and well-being service.\u0026rdquo; One critical step is to recognize that \u0026ldquo;we have many pandemics\u0026mdash;only we don\u0026rsquo;t call them pandemics. We have the pandemics of obesity, cardiovascular disease, and diabetes.\u0026rdquo; McKinsey Global Institute covered the substantial upside of addressing these chronic conditions in a new \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;published last week.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eYou can also see the full \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;of our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e, our \u003cem\u003esuite of tools\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose \u003cem\u003e\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/em\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19 and the great reset: Briefing note #13, July 9, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAs lockdowns lift, businesses are thinking about their next moves. McKinsey research offers insights into the near future.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMcKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(July 6, 2020). In 51 pages, we document the current situation, the economic outlook, the forces shaping the next normal, and the new organizational structures that can help companies sustainably keep pace. You can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection \u003c/a\u003eof our coronavirus-related content, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic, and a look at how our editors choose \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAround the world,\u003c/strong\u003e economies are cautiously reopening. Businesses are keeping one eye firmly on the here and now but also tentatively looking ahead to what\u0026rsquo;s shaping up as a great reset. Our new research this week offers several takes on this theme.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eStart with the global pandemic\u0026rsquo;s front line: the healthcare sector. This week, the McKinsey Global Institute published a new \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/prioritizing-health-a-prescription-for-prosperity\"\u003ereport\u003c/a\u003e, \u003cem\u003ePrioritizing health: A prescription for prosperity\u003c/em\u003e, which measures the potential of proven interventions to reduce the global burden of disease. Taking advantage of them would not only alleviate a problem exposed by COVID-19\u0026mdash;people with diabetes, hypertension, chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder, and obesity have been hit hardest\u0026mdash;but also add, in \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/how-prioritizing-health-could-help-rebuild-economies\"\u003eour estimate\u003c/a\u003e, $12 trillion to global GDP in 2040.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eReimagining the workforce is another pressing task. Executives everywhere wonder how to bring people back to the workplace and how they will do their jobs. Our new research takes a \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-postpandemic-workforce\"\u003elook\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;at the challenges of creating a sense of belonging, common purpose, and shared identity when some people work in their homes and some in offices and factories. Another article considers the great reset\u0026rsquo;s tactical challenges, such as \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/a-dual-cybersecurity-mindset-for-the-next-normal\"\u003eguarding against cyberattacks\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on remote workers.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSmall businesses confront some of these problems. But much as Ginger Rogers danced the same steps as Fred Astaire\u0026mdash;only backward and wearing high heels\u0026mdash;small businesses must make the necessary changes at a greater relative cost and with less working capital. Our new research \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/us-small-business-recovery-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eexamines the struggles\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of US small businesses in three sectors (restaurants, manufacturing, and retailing) that could be facing a long, hard recovery.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother sector thinking hard about its future is \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/reimagining-infrastructure-in-the-united-states-how-to-build-better\"\u003einfrastructure\u003c/a\u003e. In the United States, two scenarios are possible: a boom spurred by a government stimulus or a bust as tax revenues and user fees dry up. Agencies and investors alike must prepare for both outcomes. One key to generating a rapid impact from infrastructure spending is to repair existing assets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week we also look at \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/global-freight-flows-after-covid-19-whats-next\"\u003eglobal freight flows\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;(down 13 to 22 percent this year) and the varied potential for recovery, reviewed the implications of COVID-19 for \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/us-food-supply-chain-disruptions-and-implications-from-covid-19\"\u003ethe US food supply chain\u003c/a\u003e, and considered the challenges of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/pricing-through-the-pandemic-getting-ready-for-recovery\"\u003epricing\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in a pandemic.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #12: July 2, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOne step forward, two steps back: the pandemic is giving new depth of meaning to that well-worn expression. Our new research explores both parts of it.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey continues to track\u003c/strong\u003e economic and epidemiological developments around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e. In 94 pages, we document the situation, show how countries and companies can transition toward the next normal, and offer planning advice across multiple horizons.
