You can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of our coronavirus-related content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our suite of tools to help leaders respond to the pandemic. \u003cem\u003eNew this week:\u003c/em\u003e a look at how our editors choose \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/covid-19-visualizing-the-impact-of-an-invisible-threat\"\u003eimages\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that help readers visualize the impact of an invisible threat.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn a week when the global pandemic seemed to gather strength, our new research both shows the grim economic news and reveals a streak of optimism that many are starting to feel. Our monthly \u003ca href=\"/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7baf8ce0fd-20c6-4a37-972c-f54e90309d87%7d%40en\"\u003eglobal economic conditions snapshot\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;indicates that 52 percent of executives now say that their national economies are doing substantially worse, up from 10 percent in March 2020. Yet the proportion of executives who expect profits to rise within six months rose by four percentage points, and leaders in retail, high tech, and telecom are increasingly \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003eoptimistic\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;about the return of customer demand. In June, many more executives around the world said that the economies of their home countries would soon be doing better than had said so in May.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAnother new global \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/a-global-view-of-financial-life-during-covid-19\"\u003esurvey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;examined sentiment among people who make financial decisions for their households. Across the globe, they are reporting lower income, savings, and spending. In most countries, 20 to 60 percent of these decision makers say they fear for their own jobs. Roughly half have no more than four months of savings.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese grim statistics present a challenge for banks and other consumer-facing businesses, such as telecom companies, retailers, health systems, and utilities. A delicate balancing act \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/reimagining-customer-service-to-manage-delinquencies-after-covid-19\"\u003eawaits\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;these organizations as they work to ensure that customers receive the necessary support\u0026mdash;and that lenders can continue to cultivate relationships with their borrowers\u0026mdash;while preserving shareholder value in the longer term. A detailed perspective on \u003ca href=\"/industries/electric-power-and-natural-gas/our-insights/power-and-people-how-utilities-can-adapt-to-the-next-normal\"\u003eutilities\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;considers this and other conundrums. So does a new look at \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/african-banking-after-the-crisis\"\u003eAfrican banks\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe virus\u0026rsquo;s spread is accelerating, but businesses everywhere are both coping with their urgent needs and looking ahead to the time when their employees can safely return to work. As that moment comes closer\u0026mdash;let us hope\u0026mdash;three new research efforts show, first, how leaders can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/covid-19-and-the-employee-experience-how-leaders-can-seize-the-moment\"\u003eseize the moment\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to support their employees by building on the trust their early efforts have engendered and, second, how they can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/communications-get-personal-how-leaders-can-engage-employees-during-a-return-to-work\"\u003eengage\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;employees through clear and inspiring communication. And our \u003ca href=\"/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/how-us-companies-are-planning-for-a-safe-return-to-the-workplace\"\u003esurvey\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of US companies shows that same insistent streak of optimism: respondents expect most employees to be working onsite by December.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne lesson of the crisis is the need for speed: the pandemic obeys no speed limits, so businesses have had to adapt through quick fixes and workarounds. How can they keep these successful innovations going over the long term? Our new research suggests \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/ready-set-go-reinventing-the-organization-for-speed-in-the-post-covid-19-era\"\u003enine ways\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to reinvent the organization for speed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we also looked at how companies can \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/resetting-capital-spending-in-the-wake-of-covid-19\"\u003ereset their capital spending\u003c/a\u003e, demystified the role of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/demystifying-modeling-how-quantitative-models-can-and-cant-explain-the-world\"\u003equantitative models\u003c/a\u003e, and talked with two McKinsey experts about how to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/choosing-the-right-path-to-unlock-the-economy\"\u003echoose the right path\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to unlock the economy.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #11: June 25, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eEvery industry is adapting to life during a pandemic. New McKinsey research examines the implications for six sectors.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMcKinsey continues to track\u003c/strong\u003e economic and epidemiological developments in Europe and around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e. In 94 pages, we document the current situation and show how countries and companies can transition toward the next normal and plan across multiple horizons. You can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of our coronavirus-related content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week we zeroed in on critical developments in six major industries, starting with \u003cem\u003econsumer goods\u003c/em\u003e. Research we published last year (\u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-consumer-m-and-a-searching-for-growth\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-next-wave-of-consumer-m-and-a-executing-for-value\"\u003ehere\u003c/a\u003e) documented the recent trends in consumer M\u0026amp;A and the ways that successful companies used acquisitions to accelerate revenues and profits at a time when growth was elusive. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/consumer-packaged-goods/our-insights/the-next-normal-in-consumer-implications-for-consumer-goods-m-and-a\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;reveals that COVID-19 has accelerated some of these trends and created new realities. One critical finding: consumers are returning to big brands they know and trust. While these companies accounted for only 16 percent of the industry\u0026rsquo;s growth in 2015\u0026ndash;18, that figure rose to 39 percent in 2018\u0026ndash;19\u0026mdash;and reached 55 percent in the first three weeks of April 2020.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn times of crisis, all eyes focus on the \u003cem\u003einsurance\u003c/em\u003e sector. This week, we \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/what-insurers-can-learn-from-chinas-continuing-covid-19-recovery\"\u003esurveyed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;insurance agents in China, the first country to reopen. The outlook there is complex: some lines, such as health insurance, fared well, while others, such as property and casualty, suffered significant declines and are just now recovering.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt \u003cem\u003esemiconductors\u003c/em\u003e companies, the pandemic has posed questions for every aspect of the business model. Our April 2020 \u003ca href=\"/industries/semiconductors/our-insights/coronavirus-implications-for-the-semiconductor-industry\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;outlined the potential shifts in demand. This week\u0026rsquo;s \u003ca href=\"/industries/industrials-and-electronics/our-insights/how-the-semiconductor-industry-can-emerge-stronger-after-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eupdate\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;offers scenarios in which demand might revive, and the ways that companies can adapt while also preparing the enterprise to emerge stronger in the next normal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eSoftware\u003c/em\u003e makers are also in the midst of (yet another) disruption. For the past ten years, the rise of software as a service (SaaS) has reshaped the enterprise-software industry. Growth accelerated, but industry profitability tumbled. Our research finds that \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/the-next-software-disruption-how-vendors-must-adapt-to-a-new-era\"\u003ethe next ten years\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;will be just as tumultuous. SaaS companies are at a crossroads: COVID-19 will accelerate the footprint of SaaS, given the growth of remote working, the rapid deployment of digital solutions, and the lower up-front costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLike many other industries, \u003cem\u003eengineering and construction\u003c/em\u003e has had to reimagine how work gets done. This week, we \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/meeting-ec-needs-in-and-after-coronavirus-a-qa-with-wsps-paul-dollin\"\u003espoke\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;with an industry leader, who revealed the ways that his company has adapted.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, while \u003cem\u003esmall business\u003c/em\u003e might not be an industry, it is a mighty economic sector that employs tens of millions of people in the United States. Our new \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/americas/which-small-businesses-are-most-vulnerable-to-covid-19-and-when\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;finds that between 1.4 million and 2.1 million US small businesses could close permanently as a result of the first four months of the pandemic. Certain sectors are particularly at risk.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we also examined the \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/india/five-priorities-for-corporate-india-in-the-next-normal-after-covid-19\"\u003epriorities\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for companies in India to thrive in the next normal; reviewed the early returns on post-COVID-19 \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/an-early-view-of-post-covid-19-discretionary-spending-in-asia\"\u003ediscretionary spending\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in China, India, and Indonesia; and considered the lessons of the past that might prove helpful as policy makers seek to \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/lessons-from-the-past-on-how-to-revive-the-us-economy-after-covid-19\"\u003erevive the US economy\u003c/a\u003e. Finally, we were privileged to speak with two remarkable leaders, \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/a-happy-warrior-mellody-hobson-on-mentorship-diversity-and-feedback\"\u003eMellody Hobson\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of Ariel Investments and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/leading-with-purpose-and-humanity-a-conversation-with-hubert-joly\"\u003eHubert Joly\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of Best Buy, about the challenges of leadership in extraordinary times.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #10: June 18, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur latest research focuses on recovery in Europe.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eGovernments worldwide\u003c/strong\u003e have already allocated more than $13 trillion to stabilize economies in freefall and restart growth. These measures, written and delivered at speed, have succeeded in many ways. But as the crisis drags on, new questions are arising. Is the money directed in the best possible way? And is more needed?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, McKinsey researchers looked at ways to fill the gaps that COVID-19 has created in \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-state-transformation-mandate-during-covid-19\"\u003eUS state budgets\u003c/a\u003e. Worldwide, we \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/make-it-better-not-just-safer-the-opportunity-to-reinvent-travel\"\u003eestimate\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that government deficits could reach $30 trillion by 2023. That\u0026rsquo;s a sobering figure. But we believe that if governments and the private sector work together as never before, they can avoid the disastrous consequences of massive deficits, lay the foundations for a new social contract, and begin to shape a postcrisis era of shared, sustainable prosperity.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur new research on \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/navigating-the-post-covid-19-era-a-strategic-framework-for-european-recovery\"\u003eEurope\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggests that governments can start by distinguishing between sectors that can navigate the crisis safely, and others, such as those that were already in decline and were then badly hit by the crisis, that may need structural change. In Germany, for example, you will find both types of sectors in abundance.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey continues to track economic and epidemiological developments in Europe and around the world. For an overview, read our latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e. In 94 pages, we document the current situation and show how countries and companies can transition toward the next normal and plan across multiple horizons. You can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of our coronavirus-related content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week we documented many of the COVID-19-related shifts taking place in Europe. A critical issue now coming to a head concerns \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/privacy-security-and-public-health-in-a-pandemic-year\"\u003eprivacy\u003c/a\u003e: How do companies comply with the European General Data Protection Regulation and also support contact tracing and testing measures? Another is mobility: transportation systems may be permanently altered in the crisis. Our new \u003ca href=\"/industries/automotive-and-assembly/our-insights/moving-forward-how-covid-19-will-affect-mobility-in-the-united-kingdom\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;on the United Kingdom outlines the implications. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSome of those concern the many UK start-ups offering novel transport solutions. This week, \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/how-the-covid-19-crisis-is-affecting-uk-small-and-medium-size-enterprises\"\u003eour new research\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;found that small and medium-size businesses in the United Kingdom face dire prospects: one in five may not survive past August 2020. In the recovery, European governments cannot do all the heavy lifting; our \u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/reimagining-european-philanthropy\"\u003eanalysis\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggests that European foundations have a window of opportunity to step up their actions and play an essential role in national rebuilding and recovery efforts. And we \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/restarting-after-covid-19-a-qa-with-clifford-chances-david-metzger\"\u003einterviewed\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;a leading UK dealmaker on the potential to restart major capital projects through standby agreements and other moves that keep projects on track. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we also presented ideas for retailers to \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/redefining-value-and-affordability-in-retails-next-normal\"\u003eredefine value and affordability\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for newly strapped consumers, addressed big shifts in \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/physicians-examine-options-in-a-post-covid-19-era\"\u003ephysicians\u0026rsquo; behavior\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;explained why insurers need to \u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-insurance-can-prepare-for-the-next-distribution-model\"\u003erevamp their distribution models\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026nbsp;and considered a safer, better \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/make-it-better-not-just-safer-the-opportunity-to-reinvent-travel\"\u003efuture for travel\u003c/a\u003e. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #9: June 11, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur latest research examines the social risks of COVID-19.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEven as societies and businesses\u003c/strong\u003e race to reopen, the global pandemic still poses significant problems. This week, we documented an accelerating one: loneliness. In many parts of the world, the social fabric was already fraying before the pandemic. Now, as former US surgeon general Vivek H. Murthy, MD, \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/avoiding-a-social-recession-a-conversation-with-vivek-murthy\"\u003epoints out\u003c/a\u003e, COVID-19 is disconnecting us further from our human relationships. That might cause a \u0026ldquo;social recession, with profound consequences for our health, for our productivity in the workplace, for how our kids do in school.\u0026rdquo;\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey is tracking developments on all these fronts. For an overview, read our latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing materials\u003c/a\u003e. In 94 pages, we document the current economic and epidemiological situation and show how to transition toward the next normal and to plan across multiple horizons. You can also see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of our coronavirus-related content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis week, we \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/europe/well-being-in-europe-addressing-the-high-cost-of-covid-19-on-life-satisfaction\"\u003einvestigated\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;loneliness and other effects of the lockdown and physical distancing in Europe. Across the Continent, the proportion of people who say that they feel lonely \u0026ldquo;most or all of the time\u0026rdquo; has nearly tripled. Loneliness is higher in countries, such as Bulgaria and Greece, where trust and satisfaction with relationships were already at low levels in 2018. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFor many, the cure for loneliness might be a return to the office, the subject of some of our latest \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/people-and-organizational-performance/our-insights/reimagining-the-office-and-work-life-after-covid-19\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e. Many people say they are happy working from home. But could their happiness be running on fumes of the social capital built up through years of water-cooler conversations, meetings, and social engagements? Has working from home succeeded only because it is viewed as temporary, not permanent? Hundreds of billions in real-estate investment are riding on these questions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMost industries are engaged in similarly momentous discussions. This week we published new perspectives on the \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/a-perfect-storm-for-fashion-marketplaces\"\u003efashion\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/hospitality-and-covid-19-how-long-until-no-vacancy-for-us-hotels\"\u003ehospitality\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/preserving-project-continuity-in-the-face-of-covid-19\"\u003einfrastructure\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/industries/private-capital/our-insights/institutional-investing-in-the-time-of-covid-19\"\u003einstitutional-investing\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/future-of-nursing-supporting-nurses-across-settings\"\u003enursing\u003c/a\u003e, and \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/restoring-public-transit-amid-covid-19-what-european-cities-can-learn-from-one-another\"\u003epublic-transport sectors\u003c/a\u003e. We also reviewed developments in \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/spain-after-covid-19-from-resilience-to-reimagination\"\u003eSpain\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and Africa (\u003ca href=\"/industries/financial-services/our-insights/how-the-covid-19-crisis-may-affect-electronic-payments-in-africa\"\u003epayments\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/middle-east-and-africa/safeguarding-africas-food-systems-through-and-beyond-the-crisis\"\u003efood supplies\u003c/a\u003e), as well as \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/the-10-trillion-dollar-rescue-how-governments-can-deliver-impact\"\u003etrillion-dollar ideas\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;for governments around the world. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough the news is bleak, Vivek Murthy sees \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/avoiding-a-social-recession-a-conversation-with-vivek-murthy\"\u003ecause for optimism\u003c/a\u003e: \u0026ldquo;I think that this could be an extraordinary opportunity for us to step back and ask ourselves if we\u0026rsquo;re leading the kind of lives that we really want to lead. This is our chance to ask ourselves where people fit in our priority list and whether there\u0026rsquo;s a gap between our stated priorities and our lived priorities.\u0026rdquo; \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #8: June 4, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThis has been\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e an extremely painful time for communities across the United States and beyond, even as the pandemic continues to take its toll. We are amplifying our commitment to do our part to ensure that black lives are spoken for and valued, both inside our firm and beyond. Our ongoing research on the US racial-wealth gap and on diversity and inclusion is intended to clarify some of the underlying issues and potential paths forward.\u003c/em\u003e \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/industries/social-sector/our-insights/covid-19-investing-in-black-lives-and-livelihoods\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eResearch\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e we published\u003c/strong\u003e in April called out the disproportionate effects of COVID-19 on black Americans, who are almost twice as likely to live in the counties where the risk to health and economic activity is highest if and when contagion strikes. Many of these places were the scene of this week\u0026rsquo;s anguished protests. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur newest research looks at the pandemic\u0026rsquo;s effects on \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/covid-19s-effect-on-minority-owned-small-businesses-in-the-united-states\"\u003eUS minority-owned small businesses\u003c/a\u003e. Vulnerable even before the pandemic, it has struck them disproportionately hard. Many of them are in the industries most susceptible to health and economic problems, such as accommodations and food services, retail, and healthcare. Owners are innovating and staying flexible, helping their communities to cope with the crisis. But these businesses are highly vulnerable; they need help from the private, public, and social sectors. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSimilar dynamics afflict US minority students. Previous McKinsey \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/the-economic-cost-of-the-us-education-gap\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;has demonstrated the costs of a sizable achievement gap between white students and black and Hispanic ones. Our latest \u003ca href=\"/industries/education/our-insights/covid-19-and-student-learning-in-the-united-states-the-hurt-could-last-a-lifetime\"\u003eresearch\u003c/a\u003e, published this week, finds that the pandemic not only threatens to widen the achievement gap but also poses problems for all learners. The hurt could last a lifetime. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePeople of color are vulnerable to yet another effect of the COVID-19 crisis as it affects large companies. Previous crises show there is a very real risk that as companies adapt to new ways of working, inclusion and diversity may unintentionally recede as strategic priorities. Yet as our latest \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/diversity-and-inclusion/diversity-still-matters\"\u003ereport on inclusion and diversity\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;argues, that would place companies at a disadvantage: they could not only face a backlash from customers and talent now but also, down the line, fail to better position themselves for growth and renewal.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eMcKinsey continues to research many aspects of leadership through the crisis. This week, we reported on dozens of our new research efforts, including the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/coronavirus-15-emerging-themes-for-boards-and-executive-teams\"\u003eemerging themes\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;dominating boardrooms; the post-COVID-19 future for \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/us-freight-after-covid-19-whats-next\"\u003eUS rail and trucking companies\u003c/a\u003e; the lessons learned from \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/a-resilient-return-for-asias-manufacturing-and-supply-chains\"\u003eAsia\u0026rsquo;s manufacturing and supply chains\u003c/a\u003e; a new \u003ca href=\"/industries/travel-logistics-and-infrastructure/our-insights/a-new-approach-in-tracking-travel-demand\"\u003eapproach to tracking demand for travel\u003c/a\u003e; the potential for \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/telehealth-a-quarter-trillion-dollar-post-covid-19-reality\"\u003etelehealth\u003c/a\u003e; and the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/reopening-safely-sample-practices-from-essential-businesses\"\u003esafety protocols\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;that hospitals, grocery stores, and others have used to stay open. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOur latest \u003ca href=\"/~/media/mckinsey/business functions/risk/our insights/covid 19 implications for business/2020 updates/covid 19 nov 11/covid-19-facts-and-insights-oct-30-final.pdf\"\u003ebriefing pack\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;details, across 94 pages, the current economic and epidemiological situation, how to transition to the next normal, and planning across multiple horizons. Please also see the full\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our\u0026nbsp;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our\u0026nbsp;suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the pandemic. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #7, May 27, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eNew insights on consumer sentiment and the return to work.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe Memorial Day weekend\u003c/strong\u003e in the United States, always a somber occasion and never more so than this year, seemed to mark a turning point in the COVID-19 crisis. As spring turned to summer, many US regions started to reopen, as did others in Europe, Latin America, and Asia. Despite ongoing public-health concerns, the desire to spend and shop is palpable. This week, McKinsey published new surveys of consumers in \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-argentinian-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eArgentina\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/industries/retail/our-insights/as-physical-doors-close-new-digital-doors-swing-open\"\u003eAustralia\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-brazilian-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eBrazil\u003c/a\u003e, \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-central-american-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eCentral America\u003c/a\u003e, and the \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-us-consumer-sentiment-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eUnited States\u003c/a\u003e, detailing the strength of the consumer urge in each country. The outlook is brighter. Consumers are \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/helping-us-healthcare-stakeholders-understand-the-human-side-of-the-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eless anxious\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and depressed about health concerns. Business executives are a bit more optimistic \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/the-coronavirus-effect-on-global-economic-sentiment\"\u003ethis month\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;than last. And our new surveys of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-global-b2b-decision-maker-response-to-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eglobal B2B buyers\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and those in \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-asian-b2b-decision-maker-response-to-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eAsia\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;and \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/growth-marketing-and-sales/our-insights/survey-european-b2b-decision-maker-response-to-covid-19-crisis\"\u003eEurope\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;suggest that confidence is holding firm. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThat said, the picture these surveys paint is complex. In a sense, the world is turning from \u0026ldquo;resilience\u0026rdquo; to \u0026ldquo;return\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;the third of the five pandemic elements \u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/beyond-coronavirus-the-path-to-the-next-normal\"\u003ewe sketched out\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;in late March. To get back to business, many companies are running spreadsheets to see how many people spaced six feet apart will fit in an office, planning one-way paths through the workplace, and figuring out adaptations to restrooms, lunchrooms, and entrances. All of those are critical tasks, but they are not enough. What\u0026rsquo;s needed is \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/risk-and-resilience/our-insights/return-a-new-muscle-not-just-a-plan\"\u003ea return \u0026ldquo;muscle\u0026rdquo;\u003c/a\u003e: an enterprise-wide ability to absorb uncertainty and incorporate lessons into the operating model quickly.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOne of the skills that will help with that urgent need is surely analytics, widely recognized for its problem-solving and predictive prowess, which is becoming \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/quantumblack/our-insights/accelerating-analytics-to-navigate-covid-19-and-the-next-normal\"\u003ea modern-day sextant\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;to navigate the COVID-19 crisis. Analytics can help tackle numerous urgent tasks facing businesses today: forecasting demand, identifying potential supply-chain disruptions, targeting support services to at-risk workers, and determining the effectiveness of crisis-intervention strategies, to name a few.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlso on that list: improving the experience of customers, many of them frightened, some jobless, and all of them deeply uncertain about the next normal. To renew and refresh their connections to the people they serve, companies need to \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/operations/our-insights/elevating-customer-experience-excellence-in-the-next-normal\"\u003erecognize what\u0026rsquo;s happening now\u003c/a\u003e, and respond in three ways: digital excellence, safe and contactless engagement, and dynamic customer insights.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThese are just a few of the issues McKinsey has researched and written about in recent days to help companies and countries lead through the crisis. Please see the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection of content\u003c/a\u003e, visual insights from our \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/sustainable-inclusive-growth/charts\"\u003echart of the day\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; a curated collection of our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis/navigating-to-the-next-normal-the-first-100-insights\"\u003efirst 100 coronavirus articles\u003c/a\u003e, and our suite of tools\u0026nbsp;to help leaders respond to the coronavirus outbreak. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis briefing note was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #6, May 13, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eEmerging evidence provides some tantalizing glimpses into the epidemiology of the global pandemic.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBy Matt Craven, Mihir Mysore, and Matthew Wilson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eAs the reopening of economies continues\u003c/strong\u003e across much of Europe and North America, it\u0026rsquo;s worth taking stock of the epidemiological situation and trends that will define the months ahead. At the time of this writing, the official counts of cases and deaths from COVID-19 have passed four million and 280,000, respectively. Recent studies have made increasingly clear that each of these figures is a significant underestimate. Population antibody surveys suggest that official counts are underestimating the true number of cases by a factor of five or more (although in several cases the methodology has been called into question).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eComparisons of 2020 and 2019 mortality rates show that substantially more people are dying this year, although we don\u0026rsquo;t know how much of this is due to missed deaths from COVID-19 rather than excess mortality from other causes.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eThe pandemic and public health\u0026mdash;five trends to watch\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith lives at stake, a thoughtful approach is paramount. Here are the five emerging trends that private-sector leaders need to monitor.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eThere are still many places where the epidemic is getting worse\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile much of the media narrative is about reopening, many countries, including several of the largest emerging economies, are still on the \u0026ldquo;upslope\u0026rdquo; of the epidemic, with daily case counts increasing. While an increasing number of countries and regions have proven that they can use lockdowns to drive a reduction in cases, to date, we have few examples of success outside higher-income countries. The next few weeks will be critical tests of our ability to \u0026ldquo;bend the curve\u0026rdquo; in more countries with varying contexts and healthcare capacity. In some of these countries, the absolute number of deaths is relatively low; interventions against COVID-19 will need to be viewed through the lens of both lives and livelihoods.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eReopening is a massive natural experiment\u0026mdash;make sure you learn from it\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe have never before attempted to shut down the modern global economy, much less reopen it in the setting of an ongoing pandemic. We have a few examples of strategies that seem to work better, or worse, but none of us know with any certainty the best actions. Even places with strong initial responses like Hong Kong and Singapore have faced challenges as they reopen.[[footnote 14]] China has also seen an increase in cases in the past few days.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn the United States, there is only a loose correlation between disease prevalence and plans for reopening. States with more cases generally plan to reopen later, but there are exceptions. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eA similar point can be made about businesses\u0026rsquo; plans to reopen. Companies are planning different approaches, even based on the same underlying fact base. This implies that leaders across the public and private sectors should build learning and adaptation into their reopening plans from the start. Relevant lessons might come from other geographies, other sectors, or from peers and competitors. Leaders should be prepared to incorporate new information and alter their approaches, either incrementally or radically, as new information becomes available.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eResurgence seems to be not a question of if but when, where, and how bad. Many experts are focused on a potential second wave of COVID-19 in the northern hemisphere this autumn.[[footnote 16]] This is certainly possible. But focusing on the risks of autumn and winter causes us to look past the summer, which is risky because it is sooner and because it is when many jurisdictions will be reopening and testing.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eR is important, but so is the absolute number of new cases\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOver the past few months, many have become more familiar with epidemiological concepts like the reproduction number (R) of a virus. R defines the transmissibility of a pathogen, as measured by the average number of people to whom each infected person transmits. R is a measure of change; it tells us how fast the epidemic will expand or shrink. Values greater than one define a growing epidemic, while those less than one define a shrinking one.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eR has been getting a lot of attention, for example, in defining the packages of interventions that can yield R\u0026lt;1 in a given setting. But the absolute number of cases is also important. Imagine two cities, each with an R of 0.9, implying a slightly declining epidemic. But one of the cities has 1,000 new cases per day and the other has ten. The former faces a far higher risk in reopening than the latter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn practice, we are seeing countries and regions take divergent approaches to this question. Hubei Province in China waited until reported cases were near zero to reopen, whereas Italy and Spain took the first steps to reopening with daily case counts at more than 1,000. Every location needs to balance public-health and economic imperatives; we can\u0026rsquo;t say which approach is better, but we are likely to learn more about what works in the weeks and months ahead.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eIt\u0026rsquo;s (still) all about testing, tracing, and targeted quarantine\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSignificant resources are required to run a program of testing, contact tracing, isolation, and quarantine at the required scale, but relative to the economics of lockdowns or global recession, these costs are trivial. Many countries are still far short of where they need to be on testing, and contact-tracing programs remain a patchwork. Our recent \u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/contact-tracing-for-covid-19-new-considerations-for-its-practical-application\"\u003earticle\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;provides more details on contact tracing. Strengthening these programs remains an urgent priority for many geographies. This point is no less important for having been made frequently.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn any country, here are the four metrics to watch in assessing the strength of test, trace, and quarantine efforts:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTest positivity rate,\u003c/em\u003e which measures (imperfectly) the extent to which testing systems are capturing all cases. The World Health Organization recommends a target of less than 10 percent positivity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTests per million population,\u003c/em\u003e a measure of the depth of testing.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eAverage number of contacts identified per case,\u003c/em\u003e which measures how effective contact-tracing systems are at identifying and isolating the likely next generation of cases. The figure will tend to be lower in lockdown settings than when people are moving and interacting freely.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFraction of cases arising from contact lists,\u003c/em\u003e a measure of the portion of cases arising from known sources versus undetected community transmission.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAn element of transmission dynamics now beginning to receive more attention is transmission \u003cem\u003ewithin\u003c/em\u003e households.[[footnote 17]] We may need to rethink the current model of home isolation and develop modified strategies for mild and asymptomatic cases given that isolation can prove difficult for many. Any new model should of course ensure a comfortable experience for those who test positive, so that they\u0026rsquo;re strongly inclined to follow the recommended approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eInnovation\u0026mdash;and clinical evidence\u0026mdash;leads to hope\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe speed and scale of the R\u0026amp;D response to the COVID-19 outbreak is unprecedented in human history, with billions of dollars being spent and committed in pursuit of drugs, vaccines, and diagnostics for the virus. Today, there are more than 150 vaccines in the pipeline, and 200 drug candidates. On diagnostics, beyond the RT-PCR[[footnote 18]] and classic lateral-flow immunoassays already in use for many viral and antibody tests, new technologies such as CRISPR[[footnote 19]] have already been granted emergency-use authorization by the US Food and Drug Administration.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe past few months have seen the launch of numerous trials in an effort to find therapies and vaccines\u0026mdash;with some challenges from studies that are too small in size, or not randomized or controlled. As of early May, more than 1,700 trials are in progress targeting COVID-19 and related complications. More of these are randomized and controlled clinical studies\u0026mdash;and some are starting read out results, providing evidence to support new approaches to prevent and manage COVID-19 infection and associated complications. The expert consensus is that enhanced treatments for COVID-19 will likely be available by the end of 2020; and only 12 to 18 months will likely be needed[[footnote 21]] to bring a vaccine to market at sufficient scale for widespread immunization, compared with the typical five or more years. Some developers have even indicated a vaccine may be available sooner for limited use, with an emergency-use authorization for health workers issued as early as this fall.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHere are five areas to watch:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe great vaccine-platform race.\u003c/em\u003e At the time of writing, 13 vaccines are already in clinical trials, and the full pipeline spans a massive range of platforms, including RNA, DNA, inactivated viruses, protein subunits, and virus-like particles (VLPs). The virus and viral-vector approaches are traditional; others are nascent. Each platform will start to produce data in the months ahead, starting with evidence of vaccine safety and then potentially demonstrations of immunogenicity (and even efficacy) toward the end of the year, though we still need to better understand the link between immunogenicity and correlates of protection. While having multiple platforms in development increases the likelihood of a successful vaccine, each platform has different competitors, ranging from smaller biotech companies to multinationals, as well as distinct manufacturing requirements, with implications for the scale-up of capacity.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eA more nuanced understanding of the uses of different therapeutics.\u003c/em\u003e The initial discussion on drugs has focused almost exclusively on repurposed antivirals and antimalarials for treatment. The 200-plus candidates currently in development cover a broad range of use cases\u0026mdash;from postexposure to prophylaxis, and from mild and moderate to severe cases. The more than 1,700 active trials are expanding the focus from drugs that directly attack the virus to those that confer immunity and to those that target complications of COVID-19 such as cytokine-release syndrome (CRS) and, more recently, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Labs are deploying a wide array of platforms, from repurposed antivirals (as mentioned above) to monoclonal and polyclonal antibodies to neutralize the virus to immune modulators for ARDS/cytokine storms, and even cell-therapy approaches for late-stage disease. The emergency-use authorization for remdesivir is an important milestone for COVID-19 drug development as well. In the coming months, we anticipate that a more nuanced understanding of the different use cases and the types of approaches being tested will help reduce the mortality rate of COVID-19 and also change the standard of care.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eA new normal and unrealized opportunity for data sharing.\u003c/em\u003e Unlike the experience with prior epidemics (including Ebola), COVID-19 has been characterized by unprecedented sharing of prepublication data, analyses, and results via medRxiv, a collaborative platform. This proliferation of information can support innovation and has been rapidly integrated into both the media and policy discussions\u0026mdash;sometimes, however, to unfortunate effect. Looking forward, as the scientific community seeks to make meaningful interpretations of the thousands of running studies, we need to bring together the patient-level data from the hundreds of small, undersize, not-well-controlled, compassionate-use, and observational studies, in a responsible way. Meta-analyses of such studies will help us know if therapies actually work, at what dosing and clinical regimen. There are efforts underway in the ecosystem to address this\u0026mdash;and hopefully a collaborative model emerges that could remain with us postpandemic.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe impact of novel R\u0026amp;D models.\u003c/em\u003e Competitors are collaborating in ways never expected.[[footnote 23]]  Companies are banding together in multilateral collaborations, some formal and some informal, to advance innovation. For example, leading plasma manufacturers are partnering in novel ways to produce a single unbranded immunoglobulin product; more than 15 pharmacos are collaborating in a COVID-19 R\u0026amp;D forum to advance, individually and collectively, the most promising drugs and vaccines; and decades-long competitors Sanofi and GSK are partnering on COVID-19 vaccine development. Novel master protocols, often with inspired names (such as Solidarity, Recovery, and ACTT), are being used to simultaneously test multiple drugs.[[footnote 24]]  Innovators are deploying novel development plans and trial designs as well; for example, Pfizer and BioNTech are simultaneously testing four vaccines in their combined Phase I/II study. These approaches are not without risk given the parallel work in traditionally sequential stage-gated processes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe challenge of separating the signal from the noise.\u003c/em\u003e With Ebola, a substantial R\u0026amp;D mobilization ran into difficulties recruiting patients to test all of the approaches being considered. Some of these same challenges are happening with COVID-19. Ensuring that studies are well controlled and appropriately powered will be critical to understanding what actually works. Further, data sharing will hold the key to advance our understanding and interrogation of the benefit/risk trade-off. Multiple prioritization efforts are attempting to do this but are still in the early stages. In some ways, the scale of the mobilization may be the biggest challenge.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAbout the authors\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatt Craven, MD,\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Silicon Valley office. \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/mihir-mysore\"\u003eMihir Mysore\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Houston office. \u003cstrong\u003eMatt Wilson\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #5, April 13, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur latest perspectives on the coronavirus pandemic.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBy Matt Craven, Mihir Mysore, Shubham Singhal, and Matt Wilson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eIn this note,\u003c/strong\u003e we offer some of our latest insights on the COVID-19 pandemic, starting with a survey of the current epidemiology and the five dynamics leaders need to watch: the efficacy of the surge in critical care, the expansion of testing and other traditional approaches, the development of antibody testing, the unknown nature of immunity, and a wave of innovation that might produce treatments and vaccines.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWe then highlight four of our many recently published articles, each designed to help senior executives think through the challenges of restarting economies. These and many more articles are available in our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e of coronavirus thinking.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe outbreak is moving quickly, and some perspectives here may soon be out of date. This article reflects our perspective as of April 13, 2020. We will update it regularly as the crisis evolves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCOVID-19: Where we are, and where we might be heading\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCOVID-19 continues to spread rapidly around the world. Almost every country has reported cases, but the burden is asymmetrically distributed. In the past seven days (April 6\u0026ndash;12), 46 percent of new confirmed cases have been reported in Europe and 39 percent in the United States. To an extent, that\u0026rsquo;s because countries are at different stages of the pandemic. Some that were effective at initial containment, such as  Singapore and Hong Kong, have seen resurgence and are implementing additional measures to address it. Others, such as many countries in Western Europe, have seen the number of new cases plateau or begin to decline and are debating the right approach to reopening their economies. Some countries appear to be at the peak of infection and are urgently building surge capacity in their health systems. In other parts of the world, the number of cases is rising rapidly. Countries such as Russia and Turkey are seeing a recent acceleration. India too has experienced a significant increase in the number of cases since the beginning of April and has evolved its response strategy, including extending the nationwide lockdown.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe public-health tools and approaches to be deployed vary considerably based on this status. Measures including physical distancing, travel restrictions, effective use of personal protective equipment (PPE), testing and tracing, and healthcare surge capacity require more or less emphasis, depending on epidemic phase and local context. Local use of these measures varies considerably\u0026mdash;physical distancing may be near-impossible in crowded urban settings, for example, and the apps and digital tools for contact tracing like those used in China may not be acceptable in other parts of the world. Another challenge is the dependencies among these measures: to take one example, the timeliness and stringency of physical distancing measures substantially influences how other tools should be deployed.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlthough a consensus has emerged around the use of physical distancing to slow transmission in many high-prevalence settings, a few countries, such as Sweden, are pursuing an alternative \u0026ldquo;herd immunity\u0026rdquo; strategy focused on protecting the most vulnerable populations while using only limited distancing measures to flatten the curve for others. The goals are to maintain many aspects of economic and social life today and, over time, to develop a large enough pool of exposed people (about 70 to 80 percent) to \u0026ldquo;protect the herd.\u0026rdquo; Other countries are closely watching the outcome of this approach.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe months ahead will probably be quite volatile and dynamic. It now appears likely that some places will experience a local resurgence as restrictions are lifted and economies reopen. That will influence countries at the earliest stages. For example, Singapore has seen a resurgence mainly from imported cases, which have led to local transmission; this suggests that restrictions on international travel may continue. As China gradually reopens, the tactics it used (including group-based isolation models and setting a norm of wearing masks in the workplace) and their efficacy will inform approaches around the world. Western Europe\u0026rsquo;s experience in relaxing restrictions, and the most successful approaches there, will inform the approaches deployed in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eConsidering the variety of approaches in use, public understanding and consensus will evolve day by day. We will continue to find out more about the coronavirus\u0026mdash;how it is mutating, the duration of immunity, its transmission dynamics, and so on. For example, it now appears that the virus probably won\u0026rsquo;t be highly seasonal, given the recent rapid growth in a number of hot spots in the Southern Hemisphere. But it is still possible that the arrival of summer in the Northern Hemisphere will slow transmission somewhat, as some studies in both labs and natural contexts suggest.[[footnote 25]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith all this in mind, we believe that leaders should closely watch five health-response dynamics in the coming weeks:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe efficacy of the health-system surge and how it is maintained over time.\u003c/em\u003e Countries with rapidly increasing numbers of cases are finding ways to expand their critical-care capacity massively. Their ability to do so, and to push mortality from COVID-19 to lower levels, will not only save lives but also engender confidence in their health systems\u0026rsquo; ability to manage a resurgence. Over time, as cases plateau and then decline, there will be questions about how long to maintain surge capacity while also guarding against resurgence. Providers will be under pressure to consider the broader context of a capacity surge; for example, in the United States, the mass cancellation of elective medical procedures and the associated financial hardship for many providers is likely to force difficult discussions about which procedures should be allowed to restart, and when. Other effects of surge capacity, on vaccine-preventable diseases and maternal and child health, will also be critical to monitor. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe scaling of traditional public-health approaches.\u003c/em\u003e In parallel with the surge in critical care, countries also need to think about building surge capacity in traditional public-health approaches\u0026mdash;disease surveillance, contact tracing, and targeted quarantines. Such a surge must build on current efforts to scale viral testing rapidly, mostly through RT-PCR[[footnote 26]] machines. There's a somewhat surprising relationship between testing and the number of cases\u0026mdash;generally, countries that have tested more people have diagnosed fewer cases per thousand people. Moreover, to detect and control flare-ups quickly, widespread access to viral testing will become increasingly important as countries and cities prepare to relax distancing measures. In some countries, this testing capacity could be paired with at-scale contact tracing, with privacy-by-design embedded; and quarantine facilities to help localize hot spots and prevent a broader resurgence. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe development of antibody testing and understanding of sero-prevalence.\u003c/em\u003e We have little idea how many people have been exposed to this coronavirus. One recent study in a hard-hit area of Germany showed that about 14 percent of the population has been\u0026mdash;far from the levels of exposure required for herd immunity to emerge but higher than many had expected.[[footnote 27]] A lot of other studies are underway to assess the portion of the population exposed to COVID-19. If individual or herd immunity is to play a meaningful role in reopening, antibody tests to measure exposure must be widely available. While many such tests are being developed, their accuracy and availability have been challenged. The arrival of accurate, widely available antibody tests will help countries understand how close they are to achieving herd immunity and whether they can use immunity as a meaningful signal to start reopening.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe nature of immunity.\u003c/em\u003e People exposed to other coronaviruses have exhibited durable immunity for several years after exposure. Everyone hopes the same holds true for the novel coronavirus, but we don\u0026rsquo;t know for sure. Emerging reports of recovered patients testing positive again on RT-PCR acute-infection tests raise questions about reactivation, as do studies in China showing very low levels of antibodies among some infected people. While it is unlikely that the duration of immunity is short, any new information about this issue would require a significant shift in strategy.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eInnovation.\u003c/em\u003e There has been an unprecedented burst of global pharmaceutical R\u0026amp;D related to COVID-19. Today, more than 130 therapeutic candidates and 80 vaccine candidates are under consideration across a range of modalities and use cases, such as treatment of severe disease and pre-exposure prophylaxis. If drugs already approved for other indications prove effective in treating COVID-19, they could be deployed most quickly, but in coming months readouts on experimental new drugs will also arrive. The massive scale-up of clinical trials\u0026mdash;especially randomized placebo-controlled studies\u0026mdash;will provide evidence to guide clinical decisions. Similarly, the unprecedented consortium of plasma companies generates hope that hyperimmune immunoglobulin can be developed quickly. Seven vaccines are already being tested in humans.[[footnote 28]] Although at-scale production and distribution is not likely for 12 to 18 months after a successful trial, these vaccines would provide a critical element in the armamentarium against COVID-19. For all these innovations, a central challenge will be rapidly scaling up production to meet global needs.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGetting back to work: Four insights\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe pandemic\u0026rsquo;s economic challenges are unprecedented. Since the crisis began, McKinsey has published more than 70 articles on the extraordinary public-health and economic impact, as well as the ideas that government and business leaders need to safeguard lives and livelihoods. In the past week, four articles have captured the attention of leaders around the world. We summarize these articles here and invite you to take in the full \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u0026lsquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/how-to-restart-national-economies-during-the-coronavirus-crisis\"\u003eHow to restart national economies during the coronavirus crisis\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby Andres Cadena, Felipe Child, Matt Craven, Fernando Ferrari, David Fine, Juan Franco, and Matthew Wilson\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe threat of COVID-19 to lives and livelihoods will fully resolve only when enough people are immune to the disease to blunt transmission, either from a vaccine or direct exposure. Until then, governments that want to restart their economies must have public-health systems that are strong enough to detect and respond to cases.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe first and most obvious factor in determining readiness is the number of new cases in a given area. Regions with significant ongoing transmission should expect that restarting economic activity will only lead to more transmission. Case numbers and, more importantly, hospitalizations need to be low enough for a health system to manage individually rather than through mass measures. A second factor in thinking about this is the strength of the systems in place for detecting, managing, and preventing new cases, including adequate medical capacity, especially of intensive care units (ICUs), for those with severe disease; the ability to perform a diagnostic test for COVID-19 with a fast turnaround time; and several other elements.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIf we combine a system\u0026rsquo;s level of strength with an assessment of the intensity of virus transmission, we can evaluate any region\u0026rsquo;s readiness to restart activity. These two dimensions determine four stages of readiness to reopen the economy, with Stage 4 the least ready and Stage 1 the most.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u0026lsquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/public-sector/our-insights/europe-needs-to-prepare-now-to-get-back-to-work-safely\"\u003eEurope needs to prepare now to get back to work\u0026mdash;safely\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby David Chinn, Hauke Engel, Daniel H\u0026auml;rtl, Milena Quittnat, Pal Erik Sjatil, Marja Seidel, Sven Smit, Sebastian Stern, and Eckart Windhagen\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs European countries begin to consider how to exit lockdowns, local leaders are often the people best placed to evaluate conditions and impose measures that maximize economic recovery while protecting public health. Decisions about \u003cem\u003ewhich\u003c/em\u003e measures to deploy, \u003cem\u003ewhen\u003c/em\u003e and \u003cem\u003ewhere\u003c/em\u003e, should be made locally\u0026mdash;if possible, district by district\u0026mdash;because there are material differences in the severity of the crisis and economic circumstances.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAuthorities will need three essential elements to ensure robust implementation. First, leaders will require effective, ready-to-act local-authority structures. In Italy, regional governments collaborated with Rome to establish a national lockdown that allowed regions to apply more stringent rules as necessary.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, solutions and directives must be clear and simple, so that the public and businesses can understand them. This might require using new communication channels, such as mobile messaging.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThird, measures must be consistent. If the guidance one day is that shops can admit five people at a time for six hours a day and in the next week that rule changes to two people for eight hours, the results will be irritation, noncompliance, and the erosion of trust in public authorities. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u0026lsquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/winning-the-local-covid-19-war\"\u003eWinning the (local) COVID-19 war\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby Tom Latkovic, Leah Pollack, and Jordan VanLare, MD\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eLocal US leaders, such as mayors and governors, have an outsized role in the fight against COVID-19. We see six domains for engagement: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFoundational public health.\u003c/em\u003e We assessed 23 public-health interventions and identified the most fundamental ones. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eSocietal compliance.\u003c/em\u003e We monitored different approaches to ensure compliance and found a steeper decline in infections where communities enforced policies tightly (through arrests, for example) than in those that used only fines.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eHealth-system capacity.\u003c/em\u003e To prevent demand for healthcare services from outstripping supply, we found that at least a doubling of critical-care capacity is probably possible and necessary, at least temporarily, across most parts of the United States.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIndustry safeguards.\u003c/em\u003e If the risk of contagion continues for 12 to 18 months, public- and private-sector leaders should promote the most effective adaptations and safeguards to economic activity, including physical barriers, face guards, physical distancing, health screenings before entry, and generous and flexible sick leave. Sectors will vary in how critical they are and their ability to safeguard.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProtection of the vulnerable.\u003c/em\u003e COVID-19 is especially destabilizing for vulnerable populations, including people with chronic physical- or behavioral-health conditions, limited mobility, advanced age, and unmet health-related social needs, such as food and housing insecurity. Each will require targeted interventions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEconomic health.\u003c/em\u003e Local leaders need to develop a fact base on their economies and then ensure that money from new and current programs gets into the hands of citizens quickly and easily. \u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003e\u0026lsquo;\u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/asia-pacific/could-the-next-normal-emerge-from-asia\"\u003eCould the next normal emerge from Asia?\u003c/a\u003e\u0026rsquo;\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eby Oliver Tonby and Jonathan Woetzel\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe COVID-19 outbreak began in Asia\u0026mdash;but so have early indications of containment, new protocols, and the resumption of economic activity. Although the risk of another outbreak remains, economic-activity indicators in China suggest that urban activities are returning to pre-outbreak levels. Traffic congestion and residential-property sales are close to where they stood in early January 2020. Air pollution and coal consumption have returned to 74 and 85 percent, respectively, of their January 1 levels. A recent McKinsey survey of 2,500 Chinese consumers indicates \u0026ldquo;cautious optimism\u0026rdquo;\u0026mdash;a gradual regaining of confidence, which should increase spending. At this moment, strong public-health responses in China, Singapore, and South Korea appear to have been successful. Significant evidence indicates that the curve of cumulative confirmed COVID-19 patients in Asia is becoming flatter.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAs companies in the region resume activity, they may be the world\u0026rsquo;s first to shape the \u0026ldquo;next normal.\u0026rdquo; What will that look like? Four dimensions could define it:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRethinking social contracts.\u003c/em\u003e In crises, the state plays an essential and expanded role, protecting people and organizing the response. This power shift transforms long-held expectations about the roles of individuals and institutions.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDefining the future of work and consumption.\u003c/em\u003e The crisis has propelled new technology across all aspects of Asian life, from e-commerce to remote-working and -learning tools, including Alibaba\u0026rsquo;s DingTalk, WeChat Work, and Tencent Meeting. New working and shopping practices will probably become a permanent fixture of the next normal. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMobilizing resources at speed and scale.\u003c/em\u003e Within weeks, China added tens of thousands of doctors and hospital beds. Several governments invested in new tools to map transmission and rolled out huge economic-stimulus plans. Asia has a proven ability to mobilize resources in a crisis. \u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eMoving from globalization to regionalization.\u003c/em\u003e The pandemic has exposed the world\u0026rsquo;s risky dependence on vulnerable nodes in global supply chains. China, for example, accounts for about 50 to 70 percent of global demand for copper, iron ore, metallurgical coal, and nickel. We could see a massive restructuring as production and sourcing move closer to end users and companies localize or regionalize their supply chains.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eAbout the authors\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eMatt Craven, MD,\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in McKinsey\u0026rsquo;s Silicon Valley office. \u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/mihir-mysore\"\u003eMihir Mysore\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a partner in the Houston office.\u0026nbsp;\u003cstrong\u003e\u003ca href=\"/our-people/shubham-singhal\"\u003eShubham Singhal\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the Detroit office. \u003cstrong\u003eMatt Wilson\u003c/strong\u003e is a senior partner in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis article was edited by Mark Staples, an executive editor in the New York office.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cem\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eCOVID-19: Briefing note #4, March 30, 2020\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003ch4\u003eOur latest perspectives on the coronavirus pandemic.\u003c/h4\u003e\n\u003ch6\u003eBy Matt Craven, Mihir Mysore, Shubham Singhal, Sven Smit, and Matt Wilson\u003c/h6\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe pandemic\u003c/strong\u003e continues to expand. More than 175 countries and territories have reported cases of COVID-19, the disease caused by the coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2). Case growth has accelerated to more than 735,000 cases and 35,000 deaths as of March 30. Some geographies have a handful of cases, others with early community transmission have a few hundred, and those with uncontrolled, widespread transmission have tens of thousands. Governments have launched unprecedented public-health and economic responses. The situation evolves by the day.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eIn this note, we offer some of our latest insights, starting with five likely epidemiologic swing factors that will largely determine the contours of the pandemic in the next year. We then summarize two new articles designed to help senior executives lead through the crisis. In \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/industries/healthcare/our-insights/beyond-coronavirus-the-path-to-the-next-normal\"\u003eBeyond coronavirus: The path to the next normal\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; we outline five time frames to help leaders organize their thinking and responses. And in \u0026ldquo;\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/safeguarding-our-lives-and-our-livelihoods-the-imperative-of-our-time\"\u003eSafeguarding our lives \u003cspan style=\"text-decoration: underline;\"\u003eand\u003c/span\u003e our livelihoods: The imperative of our time\u003c/a\u003e,\u0026rdquo; we explain how business and society can and must take on both spheres of action, right away. These and many more are available in our \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/coronavirus-leading-through-the-crisis\"\u003ecollection\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;of coronavirus thinking. We conclude with a short list of the areas in which executives should be concentrating their thought and attention.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEpidemiological swing factors for COVID-19\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEvery country is looking to join the few that have controlled the epidemic for now and are focusing on preventing a resurgence. The next stages in every country are unknowable. But in our view, the spread or control of the virus in the next year comes down to five factors: \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGrowth of new transmission complexes and evidence of seasonality.\u003c/em\u003e While most countries in the world have at least one case, most counts are relatively low. The extent to which these countries follow the path of countries such as Singapore that have achieved rapid control, versus that of western Europe and the United States, will be a major driver of outcomes. Moreover, these geographies also skew to more tropical climates and will provide some evidence on how much of a mitigating effect heat and humidity will have on the coronavirus. If the virus proves to be seasonal, this has the potential to shape both emerging and existing transmission complexes.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImpact of physical-distancing measures.\u003c/em\u003e We know that rigorous, at-scale physical-distancing measures can drive a significant reduction in the number of new COVID-19 cases. However, given the range of approaches in use\u0026mdash;and the varying stringency with which they are being applied\u0026mdash;there\u0026rsquo;s much still to learn about what exactly works and how long it takes. In the next one to two weeks, we will learn much more, as we begin to see evidence of the impact of physical distancing in Europe and the United States.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEfficacy of health-system surge.\u003c/em\u003e As the world has awakened to the potential risks of COVID-19, there has been a massive effort to add capacity to the healthcare system rapidly. This has rightly focused on adding acute-care capacity, providing ventilators, and building stocks of other critical medical supplies, such as personal protective equipment. If this surge (combined with efforts to reduce the demand on the health system) can prevent health systems from being overwhelmed, mortality from COVID-19 will be significantly lower. The development of clinically validated treatments could be a similar boon, but the emerging evidence on that front is mixed, thus far.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eReadiness of the health system to navigate recurrence.\u003c/em\u003e As authorities begin to think about what\u0026rsquo;s needed to navigate a postpeak environment, the public-health tools deployed will have a different emphasis from today\u0026rsquo;s focus in Europe and the United States. They will include at-scale testing, sophisticated real-time surveillance, rigorous contact tracing, and rapid, targeted quarantine to isolate cases and contacts. This mix of tools is how Korea, Singapore, and Taiwan have rapidly contained COVID-19. An antibody test would be a powerful tool in this arsenal, since it would show which people are at risk and which aren\u0026rsquo;t. Even as public-health authorities negotiate an unprecedented period of demand on the health system, they will need to design and build systems to prevent resurgence of the disease as we pass the peak.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEmergence of herd immunity.\u003c/em\u003e Herd immunity occurs when a sufficient portion of the population isn\u0026rsquo;t susceptible to an infectious disease; at that point, transmission doesn\u0026rsquo;t propagate, for lack of available hosts.
